name: Bugabot Camelot
description:
Just started this thing today. Pulled together a bunch of the names I had written down from the last few months.

This song was very improv-based, in the spirit of fun playing, more than anything else. I think my playing has been very solo-focused as of lately, probably because of having just bought Ziltoid lately, and listening to my old work again, from around the Scary House days. Realized that I haven't had as much improv in terms of writing. It usually starts with a vision, then I make a song "mathematically" around it. That has it's merit, and I love writing like that. I do miss some of these jam sessions though. This harks back to that, in spirit.

With practicing 3 note per string a bunch for some reason, that seems to be the playing style inspiration from this. It is on my Orville, in standard tuning.

I took mixing queues from The Who, Tommy. Love the stereo usage, trying that out again, but with that as a reference. Took some mixing and mastering queues from the Robot Dog Studio channel.

Oh yeah and I think the improv-based playing is inspired by listening to Keneally a ton as of recently, both because I am more into it very much again, but also because I will be going to see him up at The Baked Potato on Wednesday.

This song [Psychosis] was the first time I bounced all of the tracks as stems, then mixed from there, rather than mixing from the takes themselves (configurable DAW plugins; now they are baked in, I have to use mixing to make it work on it's own instead, rather than going back and adjusting the literal tones).

It's a Logic Pro bass amp sim, Neural Amp Modeler for the Mesa-like sound, and another tone with NAM for the clean one. Just Logic drums too, tapped out on my iPad with Logic Remote connected to my Mac with USB-C for ultra-low latency. It very much helps with the MIDI not breaking when I do blast beats.

The artwork wasn't intended to look insanely similar to Scambot 1 [but it does], sorry about that. It seems like it just does though, so yeah, it's a bit on the nose in terms of reference. But that's okay. The music kind of is as well, so aah. haha

Using two stages of compression for guitar takes is killer, don't be afraid of it! I actually don't mind the mix here. It was hackily done, but I used my ear, and I think it's actually fairly clear, while a bit quirky.

I tried using Voxengo for the Mid-Side field, but it didn't sound nice for this specific panning, so I didn't use it here. Was also going to use Sketch Cassette, but it didn't seem like it needed it.

The title of [Psychosis] is about how everyone nowadays is in psychosis because of social media. Because apps use webviews to render their pages, rather than being an actual app (inconsequential, just a funny observation), people are just using the Internet, but through a dumbed-down filter, where the site picks what you search for. So rather than using the Internet where you get to pick where your interest goes, instead you have the site do it for you. And the "app" part of it is made to seem like it's personal to you. Idk. Just making up reasons as to how I came up with that name. Some names I come up with in bed just as I am falling asleep, then I get up probably 10 times as I come up with a different bunch of names and have to go write them down. So they don't necessarily make sense to describe after the fact, it's like the remnants of your thoughts in your mind are circling down the sleepy drain, and you are writing them down as they clear out. Yeah.

So this may turn into a project, we'll see. I like the improv side of things again, and trying out more mixing experiments could be fun with it. Open-ended again. It just feels natural. This is fun right now, that solo-based 3 note per string soloing band kind of sound. I haven't done too too much of it since having moved to Logic, so it is kind of a curiosity as to how it might sound with a good mix and master. :)

Today is the 1/19 by the way, as this probably will be a long-running project :)

edit: A few minutes later, after publishing this :)
I think my playing/recording [in the past] was more driven around what was fun to hear when I was playing, rather than being inspired by what I was listening to. Maybe in some way or another it was inspired by it, but it was very feel-driven before. Like nowadays maybe I would get inspired by a sound, then use that to create the song, in terms of what it was started from. But early on, it was that I would record by ear, like if I were to play a band as myself. Then this is what would get tracked in as a specific song. That's what this is trying out with again. I think I kind of forgot about this kind of writing I used to do. I think my current listening habits might have been inspired by it too, so it kind of goes both ways. So rather than letting the instrument lead the song where it goes, I have been having an inspiration from something in the world, and write around that thing. So maybe it's more emotion-based than I had realized? Maybe just not with words as much. Like when I used to "mess around" on guitar back when, I would have one track that I came up with, then I would listen back and see what else I could come up with for that. It still does that with the inspired-writing, but it has to cater to the aesthetic it's trying to convey or explain. This instead is more about the flow of what the instrument is trying to play.

And by solo-based writing, I mean that in the compositional-sense. The way I am playing the guitar is less about riffs in the genre sense, and more about the building-block sense. It's up to much more interplay, ear-based listening, fun little calls back and forth. So recording a guitar idea, this is more akin to that, than making a song on it's own, at least I feel. The starting clean track for this song is more like what ideas I would record with Music Memos than what I would make a song with now. Again, not good or bad, just great to learn what I use and have used as song structures over time. My early guitar albums were very much driven by this solo-based writing. I miss it! And yeah, I think I forgot how to do it. It does make it to where the work can't have as much of a clear vision though, and maybe that's why I may have moved away from it for some time, to learn how to make music around the vision; even if I didn't know what the vision might be, per se. I get a feeling of where the arrow points, and I follow that. For this, there is no arrow, only vibe. It's like sitting in a hot tub, vs reading a history book. This is the hot tub. And it's fucking bubbly as fuck. Fuck.

Oh yeah. And [Psychosis] wasn't recorded to a click, intentionally. I haven't done that in a while, and that is an aspect to the demo nature of things that was present back then too. Because it was composed as just a demo, that's how it was presented too, at least in terms of how counterparts intermingled and things like that. Note that it's never meant to be demo quality, that's part of why I got so bummed with how my music sounded in 2023. It's supposed to be kind of like a demo in terms of inspiration/improv, but not quality. I like the rawness of first takes, but I want the production quality of albums. That's what I have been aiming for for a long time.

If this song were to be more like something from Tommy, it definitely needs vocals. I do want to look into making vocal songs. Maybe I can find a way to get vocal-based writing onto this project. I think it would probably allow for it somehow. Not sure where it would fit into the writing stage though. A song like this for example, would be too busy with vocals in it. It's already a bit busy, just right on the line I think. If I had turned on Low Latency Monitoring, it would have helped the first 7 minutes of the song. That's okay, now remembered for next time. It's more crucial even more so when the metronome is off.

name: Glide
description:
[from YouTube]
We are lucky to be here. Remember the soil under your feet. Remember to stop and look at that view. Remember to tell your loved ones you love them. Do not take your time here for granted.
[ok back to the original description]

Okay, might be working on a new album, not totally sure. Just making what I am making, and then seeing where it goes. I'm not one usually for singles. But I am too eager to release these, they make me too happy with how they sound. So maybe they will eventually be compiled into a project after the fact. These are the only two songs I have made so far. It's not that I am releasing them out of a selection of songs I don't like. It's just that they feel like they need to be made public right now. I'm just following that intuition. I don't know how they fit together. I just know that they are what I need to be making.

This one was a guitar improvisation with my Orville Les Paul. Used some new plugins, and the new mixing/mastering techniques I mentioned in the previous song.

The song felt like it was to be called Glide. It was going to have a paper airplane on the cover, but I felt like an "improvised" cover might make more sense for the art. Just been feeling that lately. The artwork kind of brought my mind into feel like it's a place or time you "aren't meant to reach". Not in a negative light, but more in that you accessed something very deep, and it's a glimpse of the depths and or beauty that it provides. Might be a metaphor or something, I don't know. The noise on the artwork seemingly pairs nicely with the tape static present in the reverb of the track too. I like that. And the haziness of the blur seems to represent the kind of distortion that seems to occur at the concluding few minutes of the track.

I think it's being very in the moment, and or emotional, this song, this state. Just being, there.

In the logical side of things, I was listening to my compilation album recently, and I think Down in the Rains of Time made a new impression on me again. I love the depth of it.

I tuned my guitar to that "random" open tuning again too, it just felt like it needed to.

Wait, that reminds me. This was actually on my Ibanez Gio. I don't want to tune my Orville up and down a lot.

I think this song might also be a reflection of how much life means to me, even moreso now. Loss changes you. Time changes you. Or rather, it allows you to realize just how fragile this whole "thing" is. Not in that the world is dangerous all of a sudden, but just in that it really is magical to just be here, with those you love, to see the beautiful sky and plants every day. We are lucky to be here. It is amazing to remember that. Don't ever forget that.

[just posted the song]
..and while working on the artwork, I now remember that I was thinking that the album could maybe be called "Creating Experiences". This is an important thing that I am bringing forward in my life because of the key people that shaped me. I miss them dearly, and I wish I could thank them for our time together one more time. I think that will happen one way or another, somehow.

Edit: one day later, the night.

Listening to this song after having listened to Nonkertompf all the way though, again. Man, that album explains so much without using any words. I don't know if Nonkertompf even has any words or lyrics in it. I love how expressive it is.

The conclusion of the listening of that led me to my song here. I have been wary lately to not compare my songs to other artists, in that sometimes it comes from a place of lack. This time I let myself go to my song though, it felt like it was coming from a place of love, understanding, relation, curiosity, something like that.

What I had gathered while listening to this song, is that it very much seems to come from a place seemingly similar to Nonkertompf, maybe. Again, these are feelings. Usually when I write these feelings out, it tends to make me start to not believe them, because I can see them on the page. Maybe that's something I struggle with.

But, okay. At least in terms of listening habits, this song gathers from a lot of my inspirations. I think it gathers from my recent additions of DTP Ghost, Nonkertompf, and Devin/Keneally in general. The tape degradation feeling/sonic portrayal comes from Steven Wilson's influence. It's not that these things are literal concepts that I am explicitly using with intention. I think it's that it kind of works in parallel, or reciprocally. I seem to gravitate towards music which describes how I feel. I then learn to use those sounds and feelings and paint types in my music. Then it makes it visible as to where I gathered those paint feelings/aesthetics from. So it's not just that it's a composition technique only, it's also the way I felt while listening to the music when I found it. I am re-gathering those feelings again, and using those to paint my music with. So say I felt a certain way while listening to In Absentia for example (I am thinking right now of the intro to Gravity Eyelids for some reason; it's the mellotron that I love). The sound of that, the worbley effect, the emotions I felt from it, or rather how I felt the message it conveys, was perceived by me, that's the thing I am painting with. Not that In Absentia is specific to this song, that's just a relation to this.

While listening to Nonkertompf, I was reading about all of Keneally's work over the years. The more and more I dive into his work, the more I love what he does, how he does it, and am thankful to have someone to look up to like that. It's that he does what he does because it's his story, and he's telling it, and documents it because it's important. In saying that, my own radar says "that sounds like being full of yourself!". My feeling is the total opposite. That's what's so beautiful and inspiring about it. In a way, it reminds me of that thing of when you are a kid, and you have your dreams, and you bring them to fruition. The reasoning of why it is logical or not, we aren't present with yet. I find it beautiful to be able to discern when that logical "no" is unbeneficial, and isn't helping you be happy. In some sense of things, that's why I am loving the music process so much. It's a way for you to become your own advocate, and to do what you do.

I don't want to take the emotion out of this. I tend to explain things very literally. I feel very happy and relatable to so much of his process. It's the safety in feeling the innocence, and to let the process drive the work, rather than some other way.

It's hard to explain how a mental shift affects your life. It's not visible. People might not even perceive that you've changed. But this is what I am trying to articulate. It's unbelievable. I don't know how to explain it to others who don't know what it is. Not like it's some higher-knowledge extravaganza or something (or maybe it is?? lol). It's just that it's only something you can relate to if you've experienced it.

Much also like what this song was rooted in, in an emotional basis, I haven't "understood" loss, until now. I don't know how people experience it, or if it's the same. Of course people handle it differently, but I'm not sure everyone has the same realizations because of it. That in mind, so much of my world has changed because of it too. Let alone the loss of the person or people you love, but the unknown of not having them in your life anymore. It's the finality of it. It's that you grew up and they were always there. You knew they would be gone at some point, not to be blatant or anything. But the realization that they weren't always there either, that's also odd. And realizing that they are just like you, they were young. Not that they were the same them, but young. It's that they had to go through the ropes, just like you. You come to think that they have always known the world. When they are no longer with you, it is shattering. It's not just that they are gone. It's that you realize that they weren't always there. They didn't always know the answers. They taught you everything they learned because you are to do the same. For lack of soul-shattering words, it's beautiful. How this whole "thing" life works, it's amazing. The amount of depth to it is awesome. I'm not even talking about our first-person perception of everyday things, like trees, nature, the world. All of those deserve their own conversations too. Just, the experience of being here, in "now". It's amazing. One recurring thought I keep having is that I am thankful for having been on the same timeline as them. Because that is unfathomably lucky. Luck or not, whatever metric you'd like. The point is that I am so thankful for the time together. It's not even that it's finite. I mean, it is, but the point is that even that was more than the world, you know? This has made everything so good for me, yet also very very very heavy. I already have discerned my time against things I do or don't want to do. But now it means even more now. If I am a bit brash for wanting to stay away from negativity that would only hinder other positive things from coming about, I don't care now. Time is of the essence. We have the ability to decide what we spend our time, our focus, our connections here together. It's not about being "preachy" for good and bad. What does your heart say? Follow it. Put your best foot forward, because that's how you want to be remembered. It's not that you "*should* be remembered nicely". It's that you have the power of so much in front of you. Why get stuck focusing on things that don't matter? Getting mad that someone cut you off in traffic? Silly. Don't waste anymore energy on it. Don't skirt around an uncomfortable conversation because you don't feel like having it. It's just a feeling. It will feel better to go through with it. And the truth is out in the open. It's not doing it for the sake of doing it. It's that you are living by your heart. If people can't handle that, then you don't want them in your life. Make room for those you do care about. Rather than being mad at that other driver, go home and hug your spouse, make them a cake. Take them out to dinner, thank them for the time you have together, and how much they mean the world to you. Those are the moments you want to foster, and to bring forth for you, and for them.

Again, I don't know how to communicate this without being literal. There is a void in where I feel like I don't understand how they can not be here. Is this what existential feelings are all about? I am mourning the times cherished together have now concluded. I am cherishing that what I grew up with is now in the past. I know I am my age, that's not new. But I am realizing how "my age" is now not what it's felt like for the longest time. "Being an adult" is not new, I am a few years into it. Albeit I am still working on independence, making progress! That's surface-level stuff though. On an emotional level, I think I have been young for a long time. Something has changed. I feel it. I know it. I knew "about" the world, but I didn't *understand* it. Now I understand it. And it's soul-rattling. Realizing that people get mad at each other over something they misunderstood. Realizing that people hold grudges because of miscommunication. Realizing that people love each other but don't know how to communicate it. Realizing how much we all need each other. Very much. Realizing how "negative" everyone is. I now see why people say that kids are so happy. Is it because of these realizations about the world we live in? Or is it just another set of misunderstandings which are gained at a certain age? People start to believe that the world is out for them. People think that the world hates them. People think that others hate them. We fuel our own problems, whether cognizant or not. We also fuel our own progress, whether cognizant or not. Kids seems to "work" naturally, making friends, helping before not helping. The environments we grow up in tend to remove this positive light, or rather obstruct it. That's what I am working on and possibly am trying to explain. This light is still there. It's belief in things working out. You may even have factual evidence that things won't work out. But that doesn't mean that you stop trying. That's the whole point. Because what you put in is what you get out, and vice versa. What you don't put in is what you don't get out.

We learn to be okay with getting in our own way, because it's what we're "supposed to do". It's "what everyone else does". It's "being an adult". Fuck it. I won't do that.

name: Can't Quite Quantify
description:
Started a new folder on my iPad, getting back into my "classic inspirations" for how I used to write. I miss it, and I am happy about it again. Even if it's covering familiar ground, I am now seeing that I have a lot to cover there in terms of bringing up the production quality.

So yeah, this was recorded with GarageBand, exactly like the old days. Line out cable from my Line 6 Spider IV (yes), and bass amp sim from GarageBand. Drums tapped out by fingers, my own to be precise. Ibanez Gio.

The change here is that this was then mixed a few days later, and with Logic Pro. I then mastered it, properly, too. I say that because I realized I have been using compressors and limiters wrong, because I didn't realize that they don't activate if the input signal path isn't loud enough. So yeah, makes sense. Just another thing to have learned though, so all good!

Really digging this song! Hear lots of my influences and previous works in it.

Was intending for this to be a full project, and this just would be the first on that. But I think right now might still be a bit taxing with all of the plans I have going on at the moment. I also am just now getting over being sick, this song took a few days longer because of that. Recorded it before I started feeling bad, then had to wait to mix and master it. Finally recouping thankfully.

The big changes in production for this are mainly:
- Flat EQ curve for monitoring while mixing/mastering
- Beyerdynamic DT 990 Pro 250 Ohm (thanks Dad!!)
- Proper compression gain staging
- Direction panning instead of fader panning (they are different!)
- Room volume adjustments (don't just plop reverb on the mix bus, each instrument should have a different amount of reverb on it, accordingly)
- Voxengo Mid Side mastering (ties together both sides of the stereo field)
- Linear Phase EQ for mastering
- Normalization per stem (makes it easier to see unwanted spikes)
- Limiter before Compression and EQ for stems (cut off those spikes just mentioned; not sure if this is good practice, but it does seem to allow the track to behave more consistently)

Not new for this song specifically, but:
- Channel EQ cuts which allow each instrument to breath in it's main EQ slot (thanks Devy!)
- Mixing according to the mix, rather than by buses (I used to "mix" one track at a time, rather than mixing for the whole mix; You mix each track according to how they all work with each other; mindblowing, and makes a lot more sense)
- Compression for each track (specifically as according to what the mix needs as a whole)
- Mastering to LUFS rather than merely -0.1db (While it may still reach -0.1db, the goal is to master to -12 LUFS. I don't know if this is the number that I want specifically for what I need, I have to learn about which apply to what, but so far it seems to sound great. I just don't want to have it anymore where things sound harsh and inconsistent in loudness throughout a track or album. Mastering seems to help with that in general though, even if you don't use LUFS. I think I did for Recreational Outrage though, that was one of the only other projects I did that with. I used it on Izalea recently too, just the other day. That's because I am getting into using it again though. Still have to learn about how applicable it is for what I need. I do want consistent volume levels though, and no piercing high end)
- Adjusting region offsets to account for recording latency (this one is highly significant. So much of my older work was affected by this, heavily. I thought it was my playing that was unable to stay in time [um, it still could be, but that's besides the point ðŸ˜œ], but it's the delay that effects introduce. Or it just might be GB iOS being GB iOS. Idk. It doesn't seem to happen when tracking with Logic on Mac though. I enjoy recording on iPad more though, so this is my solution to it. You can still hear where the timing is a bit weird, that's where I am seemingly accounting for it while in the recording itself. I had used this fix for a few other songs recently, I don't remember which. Any of the newer ones from this fall that I did on my iPad I think I did this offset fix)

So while I could span this out into the start of another album, I am too excited to have this one be complete to wait for the rest of the project to define itself. So, this shall be a single! Maybe I could release this one on it's own too? That could be something surely. Hmm. Thought of this right as I am typing this.

Oh yeah, and to mention GarageBand drums and the bass amp sim, really the sound in the recording was rendered with the Logic Pro equivalents, as that's what I edited and bounced it with. They are the same instruments, yet they tend to sound different between each program, as the Logic Pro ones tend to be higher quality too. For a while, I have enjoyed the novelty of the kind of finicky GarageBand instrument sounds, I kind of like how it plays into the DIY sound of my music. So I have missed that with Logic Pro. But I think I am okay with it actually sounding a little better now. I might have just been getting used to how it sounded, rather than necessarily liking it.

Went crazy on the artwork for this one. This is the second attempt at it. The first one was with a picture I took of some cool clouds and some powerlines. Wasn't feeling inspired. This final one was made from a bunch of post-processing and images from random internet searches. Very similarly composed to how Corruption Junction came out. I like how it conveys the music too. My new technique for making artwork is to listen to the songs the artwork is for while making it. Usually the vibe seems to come across visually more than you realize.

name: Ferret Train
description:
As of the early morning of Dec 15 (12:58 AM lol), this is the current workings.

Not mastered yet, not crossfaded.

And yeah, this project is not done, I merely am making it as you see songs added. Will update this info with when the mastering is done and the track list is finished.

Status update: Learning how to compensate for (no not that) headphone EQ! Realized it's been affecting my mixes and masters for about 3 years now. It's and understatement actually, as everything new in terms of music I've been listening to since 2022, has been with these Sony MDR-7506s. They works great! I thought they were more transparent than they are though, and this has now come to bite me, which is okay, because I didn't even know how to discern that sort of thing itself. So it makes more sense now, I can hear it, and I can articulate (to myself, and others, I'd like to think) what is missing from the signal path, or what is too strong.

In Logic, I have a master bus plugin which adjusts the EQ to correct it while using my headphones. I disarm it when bouncing. For any other playback, there is an app I found called eqMac, highly recommend it! Works great so far. That fixes playback system-wide. I don't use it for Logic because it seems to apply a noticeable delay when tracking alongside the Focusrite Scarlett. I don't think there's much delay from eqMac in any other scenarios though, so it works great.

These are the first mixes of things. May make changes, just learning, just starting to get into open-ended experimenting and writing again. Not fully open-ended like Recreational Outrage, but we'll see. It's more that I want to try how I was writing when I was doing Catastriphic, where I would write for months on end, then (with so, many.. at least,) I would select the ones I felt fit the project the best. I want to get back into that. I think my headspace is a bit more kerfuffled at the moment though, I think just "getting out there" and playing a bit more, rather than always recording and or tracking/mixing, that may help. It's being close with the playing that makes you want to write, I think I tend to forget that. The idea and feeling is what leads you to want to sit down and write, not that you "want to make a song". The song wants to make you (what?). Yeah.

Thumpermonkey is awesome. Awesome I tell you, goddamn it!! Legion was inspired by them to some extent. Started listening sometime this week, it was in my wishlist for a few months I think, I found it somehow at some point. After the second listen (ever) today, I bought it right as I got home. Can't wait to get more familiar with this album.

The names are definitely off the wall this time around again, I don't know what this one is about, and I don't know what it is or isn't. I wanted to make and still want to make a heavy record, whether that's with vocals, thrashy parts, blast beats, that sort of thing. I don't seem to be able to access that right now though. I feel very much at peace internally at the moment, very balanced. So that's a very fair trade-off, haven't felt that in a long while now. Maybe that's why things are kind of coming full-circle with going back to doing things from a few years back. The feelings have settled. More work to be done, but the foundation is starting to cure! That's where all of the magic starts, my friends.

Chocolate sunshine! It's the cure to the farts within the fields. I don't know why I felt I needed to write that. urrhm yeah. Trucks? No, tennis rackets. ah, polyps! What an exclamation that is haha.

Edit a few minutes later:
Shrouded, Collosus, and Bleeper are from a folder in November. Otherwise, everything else from Pelagan onwards started on 12-10. Shrouded was on Nov 13, Colossus on the 20th, and Bleeper on the 23rd. So this isn't a cohesive project yet. If anything, maybe the expanse of this project had already started, and I didn't even realized it yet. We will see what this turns out to be. I think in concept, yeah, I had already started writing material for it, but I didn't know it was a "thing" until a few days ago. I mean like the motivation behind it. It still doesn't have a vision in terms of the soundscape yet. Looking forward to just being open to what it arrives at. I want to make more songs like Shrouded.

And yeah, Pelagan onwards was with the EQ fix, everything prior all the way back to Scary House was with the wrong monitoring EQ (not a flat curve), oof.

Edit:
As of 10:31 PM on the 16th (very much sleep deprived today, from having stayed up; unrelated but bought 4 more Keneally releases last night, from his store, as everything is 50% off for the holidays! Had to jump on that one! So that's like at least 8 or so Keneally additions this year, wow!), Planthers' has been recorded, mixed, then re-mixed in Logic with headphone correction. The concept with this project is seemingly growing into allowing any sounds to be present. I wanted to try just using Logic Pro and my Mac for recording, to leave my old GarageBand ways behind. But I had to try this time, to make a song exactly as I would, with my OG amp, pedals, GB drums, bass guitar, all of that special combination. It's amazing how much it really makes it sound like it's from a specific era in my catalog. The sound of music I make really equates to time in my life for me. Recording like that again felt totally natural, and the whole song slipped out. The full release of just pure playing is so much easier with GB and iPad for me, seemingly. It must be a lack of DAW distraction configurations or something, I still very much enjoy it more than just recording with the Mac. The touch interface really is awesome, and not having a bunch of info in your face at once really helps keep your mind at ease when writing.

My magic connection to writing very much still seems to be rooted in improvising, active listening, and incremental writing, where repeating riffs are okay across songs, because each time you play it or arrange it, it gets better and better, hopefully more unique each time too.

So for this new song, it hopefully is the most clear audible mix of this writing style of mine. While the song itself feels like I didn't write really anything new at all, going back to the "basics" really does feel refreshing. I can't worry about what I am writing right now, I merely need to just write it, and move on. That's been my mantra for the last while as well, just to feel your feelings then move beyond that frame of mind, in due time. Writing seems to be the same for me too. Maybe it's because my brain is all frazzled from those remixes, and now I am kind of going back in time in writing frame of mind reference, so now I am kind of pulling from all of those parts of my catalog again. That would make a lot of sense. But what I now have come to try to follow, is that I don't need to worry about whether that is true, but to merely act as I believe things to be. If I am to choose my next set of events with that being the premise, then so be it. Whether I am wrong or right, the goal is to make up your mind, and then get to the next thing.

Edit Dec 19 '25:

Okay, I felt this project was going to last longer than it did. It also got more in-depth than I thought it would. It is also much more raw that I was expecting. I feel very lost as a person at the moment, and I think something is a bit off, which I mentioned before.

I think I do feel a bit wary of letting this project getting too big, as I seem to be worried about that. I think I am a bit preoccupied still though, and maybe it just isn't quite the right time for music stuff. Idk. This project feels very much uninspired like duds or orange paradox. Funny that both of them were lower-cased. It kind of explains the mood I think. It's like passively wanting to be working on something, but you don't have the thing that it's rooted in. I'm glad that I made what I have so far for this, and I am glad that I am okay to share it and write about it. I do think that pushing it past what it actually is feels a bit unhealthy though. Wannafaratakow really seems to explain the feeling at the moment, and much like Carpincho, I feel like something isn't right.

Right now, I feel very disconnected from everyone, and I don't know why. It's like I feel out of place with everything. I don't necessarily feel sad, I don't think. I can't tell. I just feel like nothing is mutual anymore, and it's exhausting. Things are never what they were let on to be, what you believed them to be, and the things you've relied on start to fall away. Whether it's things you connect with, things you understand. Everything just feels much more lost.

The word of the last few days/week has been "vacuous". Being out of people's way seems not to please them, nor yourself. Then when you stand up for yourself and do your own thing, people don't like that either. So the only reliable one seems to be the love you can have for yourself. Fostering that seems to be what helps in the long run.

I am and have been wondering, and other people have mentioned to me now, that maybe I have things to look into. I thought the way I am was just "me", or things that I like. But maybe something is wrong. Again, it's nothing to be ashamed of, I am glad that I can do the things I can do, and maybe now I just want to understand more of why I do do the things I do. I mean, like weird stuff like all of this music seems to only make sense to me, and I don't understand why. Like the not being able to understand things, that is exactly what this music is trying to explain. And when looking at it like that, maybe there is an underlying thing in that. I have no expert knowledge in anything, but it seems to be lining up with things like ADHD, or Autism. These seem to be very big words in terms of things to describe one with, and I don't know how I've felt about that. It hadn't even really crossed my mind at all, and I haven't really related to people with those yet. But I also haven't had much exposure to understanding them yet either. But why does everyone else seem so "normal"? And why do I have so much disconnect with everyone else, and why do I do things differently in so many different aspects? I didn't ask for this, and it took a long time to think of it as a good thing. I don't necessarily think I thought it was a bad thing, but it always seemed like I was doing something wrong, or it was made to appear as if I was doing it on purpose or something. If I didn't have to behave in these ways, I probably wouldn't. But, I seem to not be. So, why is that? Struggles with embodying emotions, social queues with people, friends, significant others, you name it. Social anxiety is much better now, that has made significant progress. However, it seems that at the expense of that, with the confidence I do have in not feeling worried about interactions with people, now it seems from my perception that people don't get what I am putting down, if that makes sense. It's like the techniques I did discern seem to not be what other people understand, even if it does make me less anxious. For some people, it does work though.

Say like asking questions from people to learn more about them. Until 2025, I did not think to do this, nor did I do it. That seems heavily significant to me. Now it seems like the obvious thing to do. Now when I don't do that, I feel rude. But I had no perception of this before. I thought people would talk about their interests until each found a place to express a commonality. So it's much less of a push-push kind of conversation stack, and more like a pull-push kind of one. This was also new to me. It explains why a lot of conversations (so many) seem to end cold back before I had realized this.

I have been working on the concept of "I" for the last month of two as well. I seemed to have trouble accessing that, for whatever reason. Now instead of helping myself with advice in the "you" perspective, I work to reframe it to provide myself grounding instead. From "Don't worry, you got this" to "Don't worry, I can do this". Or "You're fine" to "I'm fine".

I am also taking more internal notes about when I seem to be "emotionally disregulated". This has helped so much. I don't know if it's that state exactly. But when I feel "off", or just not in sync with myself, now I make note of that, and resolving that becomes the priority before anything else. Even if that other thing falls behind. It's okay, because it will only compound if I don't fix that. So that has been priceless for me. I seem to have to take multiple days to do this, and it involves heavy music as well. I don't want to listen to music loud because I know it's not good for your ears. But I don't know how else to let that bad energy out. It seems to give me nervous sweats too. But then I feel much more grounded. This is why I used to love my drive to work before. Now I have less time for it. But at least it's less loudness exposure.

Writing like this has helped a lot as well. Whether it's just in my notebook, or in bios like this, whether public or private, whatever. And to be honest, this probably is a bit much on the info side of things, but it is how I feel, so I don't see why it's bad to make it accessible. Like, I am trying to be more vulnerable in the first place.

I had the realization the other day that maybe I wasn't bullied like everyone else because I hid so much of myself from everyone. So since I did that, I didn't have anything anyone would pick on me for. This now makes me sad. I now see how not sharing more of myself to others has held me back. I now am just (and maybe it's always been the case, and I am just aware of it) sad that now there's nobody here to listen and talk with about this. I don't want solutions, I want to feel like I am understood.

I don't understand myself either, and maybe that's the issue as well. The more I feel I am honing my strengths, the more that other people point out my weaknesses. I don't fucking get it. I'm fucking sick of it.

I don't hold it against them either, because I understand where that's coming from. They want the best for me, and they want to make it known of things that I could work on. But man, it just is relentless.

I feel disconnected from culture too, what is culture nowadays? Is there any? Where are all of the people my age at nowadays? Everyone I see is older, and does everyone else understand themselves? This is perplexing to me. Do other people believe they can accomplish the things they put their mind to? I just have to brute force my mind into doing it, whether I believe or don't believe in myself. That's the hard part.

And when I trust my instincts, it seems like nobody believes in it. But I am told I am too mathematical and logical. But what if I base my instincts in logic and mathematical reasoning?

Why does it feel like I don't have a purpose anymore? I have purpose in the things that I have interest in, and what I care about, but why does nobody put their hand out to me? And what does it look like if I were to do that as well? Is that the issue? Am I not being open to being there for others?

And I am not saying that everything is bad, I promise. I very much have a lot of hope. It may not seem like that (I am feeling lighthearted now ðŸ™‚), but I promise I do. Maybe that's it. I have much more perspective, it seems like there's a lot of work to be done, and I can't wait to start it. I already have! But it feels like other people are uncomfortable hearing the truth at times, as well as acknowledging it for what it is. An "I don't know" answer is okay, when it's true. That's how I feel. If you are using that as a crutch for being lazy and not finding it out, that's different. But using it as a descriptor for where you currently stand with your understanding, I think that's okay. It's a statement, not a foresight. Acknowledging that you don't know allows you to categorize what you need to look into next. I think that's invaluable.

I think I am making this project right now because I don't have the voice to speak the strife I feel, otherwise. I am uncomfortable with that raw vulnerability, because when I explain it, it comes with critique. 'I am the issue that is causing my problems.'

I don't have and never have had a life trajectory. I don't know why, and I don't like it either. I can't see the future, or rather, my future. I am at least becoming more and more aware about what I want and don't want. But I seem to be lost in the now, to where I can't be focusing on the future, because then I fall behind in the now. And I am already behind in the now.

I do also acknowledge that that is just an outlook as well, and that I do have a lot of things under my belt that do put me ahead, both for my own interests and for others. I do have a lot of things to help me out of situations, much like this one, and I feel and have had a lot to teach others about hard situations as well. So I do see "my value in the world". It is just hard to come by consistently. I seem to always be a surprise to people in when I can be of help to them. "You are so wise for your age", or "wise beyond your years".

And maybe this strife is just a phase again, as I have come to learn it always is. This is a hard time. I am struggling. I will get through it. I am actively getting through it. I will, and am, finding answers to get out of it. There will be more struggles, questions, and answers.

I *will* continue to strive for what makes me happy, as that is the only thing that seems to keep me sane, whatever that means. I also will continue fostering an open mind. I will continue living my feelings, to the extent that I do.

I love you, take care of yourself. (this is to me, and the reader)

Edit Dec 20, the morning:

I don't want to discount the people and times that have been there for me, as this was definitely present too. I think right now I just have been lacking in it. I think I am concerned with my ability/access to foster new relationships with people where this is present, this is my fear I think. The people I am close with, it is getting better and better in the relationship. I am very thankful for that, and we are growing together because of it. There are still hiccups of course, and that's okay. I think I just am feeling low at the moment. And again, it's okay. I think the next step is to continue connecting with people, as I very much want to connect with people on a personal level.

Edit 1:32 AM, Dec 21:

Second night working on mastering. Last night I also made the track ordering, as the listing of songs is now different than I wrote them in. Some of the demo songs were omitted as well, in hopes of making this at least an interesting listen. While totally weird and unexplainable, at least it seems like you don't get bored. At least the songs that I was bored with, I omitted those. This album is very much inspired by the experimental side of things, and I don't think it was necessarily intentional. Just been listening to Captain Beefheart, Zappa, and Keneally over the last few months, so that's probably why this resulted in the way it sounds. Of course caused by all of the other life events too. So lots of factors at play. Now I am happy with this release, now that I can look at it as a "thing". May even make some Kunaki CDs with it. Oh, and forgot to mention Mr. Bungle and Maggot Twat as influences one way or another as well. Can't leave out Time of Orchids either. Or the "debut" Porcupine Tree album. Love me some Linton Samuel Dawson (the song, not the drogas). Nor can I leave out the classic references like Marco Minnemann's epic catalog. Sandwich!

This is essentially the first release with seemingly "proper" headphone EQ correction too, let me know if things are much of an improvement. It seems much more clear to me. I haven't listened to the masters in the car yet, usually that's a good tell right off the bat, if things are consistent or not. The mixes for some songs were pre-EQ correction, but all of the masters were at least with correction. It was just because I had mixed them before I fixed and learned about the EQ correction, and it felt disingenuous to go back and try to fix what was already there. As you can tell with this album, I would rather keep moving forward and make a new song(s) than try to fix older ones. Been doing that plenty as of recently. Needed to let the creative reins take over again!

This project turned out much more like I was hoping it would, than I thought it could have. The goal was to merely go back to the free-minded, open-ended attempts at just writing whatever. The challenge this time, was being able to somehow make it into a single cohesive thing. While the statements are all over the board, I think in some unexplainable way, it very much works awesome together. The songs compliment each other very well I think, and trying to do that when writing them would have not been possible. Having new ears to pick and sort what you like, and to rearrange into what is a telling dynamic, I think that can hold a lot of power. So the songs were very much open-ended in the creative moment of them, and I was thankfully able to let go of songs that I felt were part of the process, but weren't "listenable", or "didn't have a certain statement". Sometimes there are songs I like, but in concept, not in listening. I am happy with the threshold I set for this one. It seemed to filter just as needed.

The writing for some of these started in mid-early November, and is now concluding mid-late December. I only knew I was making this about a week or so ago. So it is in practice, a collection of demos that didn't have a cohesive thing. But yes, this is how I used to write, and now for the "first time", it is trimmed down to the essentials. The statements. The landscapes, the observations. The vegetables. It probably could have used more vegetables, but that's okay, haha.

name: Elkosaurus Tex (2025 Mix)
description:
Nov. 20 '25

You betcha, that's right! Elkosaurus Tex is soon to be rereleased in full lossless quality! This is a great step up from the original, as I really didn't know what I was doing while I was making it. I still don't know what I'm doing, but that's besides the point. All of the projects were re-bounced in Logic Pro instead of GarageBand, and all of the gain staging issues are to be fixed. Everything is going to be mastered as well, so nicer volume consistency, and no ear-rattling 3khz tones that could kill. They're the death of me at least. No more, no more! Okay; oh and yeah! Possibly possibly expect a full CD release as well. Just heard about Kunaki, and having this on a proper physical release (alongside Recreational Outrage) would complete a huge life goal for me. Not even complete, but moreso just that having that is something that I am and will be very proud and happy to have. It's representative of how far the work has come, and how much I have learned over the last few years. Music has really helped me learn more about myself, more than you could ever know. It's awesome. Can't wait to see what you think of this, now that it is in a way, closer to how it actually sounded when I made it, compared to how it turned out when I had released it. And yes, the artwork is now 3x more resolution. Just, because. This project is even more over the top than it was to start with. And because of this, it's probably not too far-fetched to eventually release it on all platforms too. I think I didn't start with this one because I knew I was going to want to rehash it to make the quality clearer than how it was firstly.

Happy Holidays! Remember to be with family, great memories find their way into your life, and you will remember them forever and ever â¤ï¸

P.S.
Oh yeah, and I have already started work on the HARRY remaster/remix project. That one is going to be a faithful remix to the original, unlike the remix for 'so, many, bad, decisions'. I have most of it done, did most of the setup and EQ fixes probably about 3 weeks ago. Haven't felt the connection to it for a bit though, so I didn't want to force myself to work on it just because it needs to get done. I very much love that project, and I want to work on it when I have open ears for it. That's more the thing. And when you listen to something a lot, you kind of lose your precision with it. Not that Elkosaurus isn't something I care about, far from opposite. I just felt that 'drive' to work on it, and I had the feeling it was going to be less intensive to work on, as this one is kind of meant to sound bad. I mean, there are parts that I did want to clean up, like the fact that the original bounces weren't even lossless, and in general, just apply some EQ and maybe maybe, compression on the master bus. The limiting and gain staging issues, along with lossless, were the main things I wanted to bring to this project. It is also seeming like the quality of instrument rendering in Logic is much better than GarageBand iOS too, which I can't tell if it's the Mandela effect, but comparing the two, they sound much much better. Not sure what that's about. So yes, some synths will sound less "low-budget" than on the original. Again, I can't quite tell if that was just the original bounce, or if it's the synths themselves, but something sounds much clearer. I haven't even done the mastering parts yet either. That will only help even moreso.

I also am working out how I will make this work for CD, in the proper form. I have one CD I made from the original version that had to cut 5 or 7 minutes off because the album is 1:24 in length. I will have to do that somehow here too. Will decide if there are songs I can cut, or merely creatively merge together or something? The lineup for these songs is much clearer for me too, I am less swayed by the "complete" picture of all of these now, albeit back then I still totally see why I did that. If I do end up dramatically changing the list of songs, I think it will be a separate release, intentionally a different "view" at this time period. It would be a companion release, merely just a change of song order or something, and likely to include "Infinitrack". That is really the only one that might make sense on this album. And it's already too long, and some songs are a bit lackluster. So, separate to this remaster, yeah, I might entertain the idea of making that. It might include some of the demo artwork that didn't get used for this final project too, as there are two or three other variations I didn't go with. One has a flag overlay (Texas), and one is at night. There were some demo fonts I didn't use too, both for the title and artist name. I did like all of them, I ended up with this artwork because I felt it matched the feeling of the album. A fine line of confusing, streamlined, and aesthetic. The other two variations were just more wild. I felt this album had more nuance than just pure chaos. That mightbewhy Corruption Junction iswild.

Nov 30 '25

Wow, finished up the final few adjustments for mastering the last maybe 9 tracks. Listening back, as I add these files to the listing here on Bandcamp, I am blown away. I loved this album because it was something that amused me. I thought it was purely just silly. But now I can hear it in full quality (ah hah, aaahh), I mean in the metaphorical sense. Because the project was littered with gain staging and lack of EQ and mastering, the original outcome of the project was hidden under layers of cruft, and hearing it as clear as it's ever been, it's never been any more obvious what was going on with it. I am taken aback. It's not as ridiculous as I ended up making it out to be. If anything, Recreational is miles into space compared to Elkosaurus. Elkosaurus is very much an across the board release. There are a lot more styles and references in here than I originally remembered. It seems like this was essentially the crossroads of so much that came before, whether it be musical inspirations, or my own interests in general. It ended up foreshadowing some other ones as well. This is very Zappa and or Keneally sounding as well. I think I had just started listening to Keneally at that point, I can't totally recall I know it was around the same time period for sure, but I am trying to recall what parts of the album were during when I had gotten into his work. I think Sluggo absolutely makes an appearance as an inspiration, whether intentional or not.

Bus Blues is a Marco/Aristocrats funny thing. Cry on Weastward Sun has a bunch of Marco references I think. The cattle duo, at least that I can recall, had nothing to do with the songs on hat. I hadn't listened to that album yet. So it was seemingly by coincidence. Amusing. Cheesecake has Marco drumming references as well. I absolutely love Gunk. I forget about that that song isn't just goofiness, it's actually pretty proggy, I think? Solo-ish? Cliff's Edge View foreshadows my interest in Devin and reverb kind of things; I hadn't crossed paths with him yet. Liminal Spaces is (now in hindsight) obviously inspired by early Porcupine Tree. I think around this time was Up the Downstair if I remember right. Bacon is a Guthrie-inspired song. I think this was inspired by the live version of Erotic Cakes, in San Pedro. Hornets is seemingly related to 'Party with the Termites' on Marco's album Symbolic Fox. Huge inspiration for me, that album got me into his catalog. That was back in fall of 2019. So that was kind of the initial start to the intro to prog in my own vein. I think Donuts was Aristocratic as well. DJFLUTES was a djent take at flutes, apparently lol. Laundromat was seemingly maybe inspired by 'Looking for Nina' from Sluggo!, not totally sure. Do and did dig that song a ton, and it was probably spinning in my head at the time of making this part of the album. Cab Crossing was seemingly a one-off Steely Dan kind of song. Didn't know I was going to make it, didn't know I even could make it. Have always been very happy with the result of that one. Sunset was in part inspired by Marco's writing. I think it was something like on My Sister maybe, another 2019 obsession of mine. It is probably a bunch of different Marcoisms to be honest, not sure quite which album it was. The big part of influence for this album was trying to write around the drums, as I really liked the idea of how Marco did that. Might have to start doing that again nowadays, kind of got into a rut with it, and ended up trying so many other different things, didn't come back to it as much yet.

I didn't necessarily want to change the track list, but I want to release this on CD, so I will have to trim and or omit some songs. My current CD for the old version omitted 24 and 25, as they felt a bit slow in that part of the album. Now I think they really make a lot of sense in the running order. I think this time I will make the first few songs into digital-only bonus tracks, as they are crucial to the completeness of this project, yet I do think they kind of make the start of the album go off to a rocky start. I know it was meant to be the "worst" album ever, but I actually think it didn't end up being that at all. And again, as I have mentioned elsewhere, I don't think that is even possible, I now understand. It's just as impossible to make the worst album ever as it is to make the best album ever. Life is a beauty aint it??

Listening to Chungus at the moment. Should that be the start to the album afterall? Hmm, we shall see. I'm actually not totally sure. I kind of like that it makes the end of the album into a seemingly silly and happy statement too though, so it may stay it's home there. Might remove the Overture part? That was because I wanted it to start the album, yet it didn't feel like it should start the album, lol. And naming it overture and placing it at the end felt like a nice way to aid in making this the worst album ever lol.

This version sounds much better than it needs to, to be honest. Again, I am kind of shocked. Gain staging, EQ, light compression, that's it. Oh, and lossless bounces. And, but not intentionally, rendered with Logic Pro instruments rather than GarageBand iOS (in most spots), merely just because of the merit of using Logic. If I could have used 1:1 synths, I probably would have. I think it does sound "better" now though, not totally sure if it's actually better samples, or if it's just because it's lossless now. Interesting things. The rendering definitely has changed over time for some synths though, that's for certain. Not much of Elkosaurus seemed effected thankfully though, maybe only a few here and there. Some of my other projects though? Whooh boy, those aren't coming back in lossless, it's sadly not possible (Septem Numero ðŸ˜¢).

Let me know if you would like a physical copy ðŸ˜œ

Brandon Bennett

Edit: the phrase "Elkosaurus Tex, it has no business sounding as good as it does" ðŸ˜‚

Dec 4 '25

Okay, as of 12:39 AM, this remix is now public!

Coming back a few days since doing the mastering and such, I found out about and or remembered that I need to look into EQ for system output with my headphones. It seems like my mixes are definitely running a bit hot with bass and treble, because it's what counteracts the output of my Sony MDR-7506's. I don't want to worry about this remix more, again, though, so I am going to leave it as-is. This is once again, a large improvement overall, so that's at least somewhere to start. Who knows, maybe I will remix this again, and do a proper mastering job lol. The fact that this is now no longer lossy, and improperly gain-staged, that's great. That's the biggest part of why this was done again.

Note that while it's called a remix, I didn't actually do any remixing this time around. Merely because of how the projects were saved though, I had to re-render them with Logic Pro, and that seemed to produce some different synth patch sounds to some extent, be it just higher-quality samples, or updates to the Sound Library in GB/LP over the last four years. So I do hypothetically want to do a proper mix for this project, as it hasn't actually ever received one, literally speaking. I didn't even "mix" in the proper sense on the first go-around. I just recorded, and bounced (literally, and literally, lol). So a lot of the production for this was merely during mastering. In the last 48 hours I started brushing up on the need to use EQ fixes for my headphones, as well as multiband compression. Both of which seem to be what I am looking for in terms of various struggles I've run into for production, I just didn't know of or how to use such tools to fix such issues. You also have to know about the issues before you are able to solve them. That's the hardest part, in my opinion! How many things go under the radar merely because of your lack of awareness of them, it's very interesting.

Okay, about the track listing. I didn't want to break up this album in terms of song ordering. But I do want to release this on CD, with Kunaki. Elkosaurus was running up to 1 hour and 24 minutes. So I had to find at least 4 minutes to trim off of the running length to make it fit. I flirted with the concept of speeding up certain songs to make them fit in the duration, even if it was just done with the tongue in cheek literal silliness of that. But I am "too lazy" for that, and the album is a bit more congruent with these songs left as bonus tracks as well. I still love them, and this is probably counter to the idea of how obtuse Elkosaurus was intended to be. But, in being open to just being okay with what decisions I make, I think this is actually an okay choice. I wouldn't want to edit Elkosaurus to make it into something it's not, anyways. The foresight to change the album these many years later, I don't like that. But it has to be done because of these new constraints. So in trying to keep the most amount of Elkosaurus as accurate as possible to the original, I think not editing it is the way to go. Trimming it with exclusive titles, that seems a little more straightforward to me. It's less of a creative decision for why I am doing it anyways, so I don't think a "creative" solution is necessarily the applicable choice in this case. The songs are very much still intentional with the lineup, I just won't be able to include them on the CD. Think of them as like the secret stories between the folds of the book. It's in there, you just need special access to get to them (what?). I don't have a good analogy for this. But yeah, I didn't want to trim the album. But I have to, and I am letting myself be okay with trimming it. Having it on CD is too cool.

And yes, eventually, just maybe, there could be a vinyl release of this. It likely would be a very much trimmed track list as well, merely the "essential" or "best of" setlist of the project. I don't like compilation albums, don't worry it's not that. It would just be "the essence of Elkosaurus". Whatever logic works to explain why Elkosaurus could be on vinyl, and it not spend a fortune, then I'm sold. The meme is too strong with this one. I have to see it through whether I like it or not. THIS TOO SHALL PASS!!!

Going to start working on the remix for Carpincho soon too. I still need to finish up the mastering for the new HARRY remix as well. That one is nearly done. Along with those on the horizon, I will add a digital booklet here for the soon to be created artwork for the CD release. And in the event vinyl is released, the artwork for that will probably be added here too.

Cheers, and farts to space, hope you stink up the place!

Just made that up. Maybe I can start scatting lyrics now.
Brandon :)

And yeah, again, this is not a real re'mix', merely a rerender, and a remaster. And since it's not coming from the original mixdown sources, I felt disingenuous to call it a remaster. Same with going from lossy to lossless, that would have to imply a new bounce, as it is in the first place.

Edit, 1:33 AM

Decided to actually mix things up. The original artwork upscaled, it looks great. I do think I did kind of step back a bit from the original concept I had drafted when making it (I think that was in 2022?). I think the craziness of the artwork was seemingly a bit too big of a statement for me at the time. It looked *too* out there for what I was comfortable with at the time. Now I actually really like it, and it's not even that weird, compared to things I've released since then. So I will make the "original" unforeseen artwork the proper one for this release. It will also come with the benefit of more easily distinguishing against the original too. I will include both in the download. There is a night-themed color scheme one too, I might use that for the back of the CD or something, maybe. We'll see (as I always seem to say). But yeah, this is really the first draft of the original artwork, before I nerfed it a bit. It looks great in full resolution. I had to vectorize the Texas flag, it was relatively pixelated otherwise. Note the interesting font similarity to Carpincho. This actually went the other way, than you might think. Since this was the OG artwork, I liked the Carpincho font because of this unused version of Elkosaurus. So it was kind of a nod to that, even with it not having been made readily available from this project. So it was like a secret back-reference to this. I also just plain like the font, and think it describes the aesthetic very nicely. Can't wait to see this on CD and or vinyl. Part of me wants to see both versions on both physical copies. So maybe I will merely just make the back of the CD into the OG artwork. The inside liner notes/track list could use the night theme one I mentioned. Not sure how I'd handle the vinyl cover.

I think I didn't use this artwork because it also felt kind of distracting and busy. But that kind of describes the album too though, lol. So now I think it's very fitting, and always has been. I think the sound of the album now matches the chaos of the artwork. But yeah, again, to clarify, I didn't choose the font because it was on Carpincho, I chose this font when I made this artwork in 2022, and Carpincho used it in result of that, and because I just like the font and how it communicates the album(s).

Edit 2:06 AM

Reverted the Digital Bonus track concept. This album is too cohesive to what it has been. I can't remove them. The CD will have to be the outlier. The digital copy is the exact same, I can't omit them just for the CD. Maybe if I release this to all of the services and platforms, I will keep everything, and for CD and vinyl, I will have a smaller track list. Maybe? I'm not totally sure. I don't know how I will be able to trim down this project and keep all of it's nuance intact. It may have to stay digital-only or something. I don't know. I want to make physical copies, but the album is too gosh darned long!! lol

name: Critically Wired
description:
A very confusing album, representative of a very confusing and turbulent time.

The following rant was from when I published some of the first songs of this, on Nov 7th. This little preface is from when I finished bouncing the final files on the evening of the 9th. This album took all of about, well, say, two or three days of work. Maybe four. Some songs were just trying to do some sort of recording again, last week. Then with everything being in flux, I ended up feeling this should be a collection of statements. I will further elaborate with time. As you were:

I keep wanting to make a better album, I feel like I know more and more about what makes a great album. But I know less and less about how to play instruments, and to actually make the album itself. The more I learn, the more out of touch with my own abilities I feel. I keep trying to make a better set of songs, and I keep coming back to the same shit. I want to play with other musicians, but nobody seems interested or receptive to my work. I also don't seem to have the guts to want to share my work to get real criticism. I am mad that I don't know what I really want, and I am mad that I can't even be good at being bad, anymore. I know it's the time period of things in the pipeline, but goddamn. Right now fricking sucks. I want to write lyrics to describe how I feel, but I am to afraid to speak, and I don't know if I really know how to. Why do I have to be so analytical all of the time? Do people really care what I think? Why does everything I have to do have to be because of my own interests? Why does nobody care about anyone else? It's not even about waiting for other people to ask me to jam with them. It's people ghosting me for meeting up to make things. How many people out there are also sick of their own personal bullshit? What do you do to handle that?

Why is everyone so self-absorbed into their phones all of the time? Doesn't anyone else strive to want to learn about others? What the fuck? I mean, what's so important about what is on the next flick of your finger when scrolling the endless web of AI crap that is now the Internet? Why is everything so fucked? Everyone has stickers about people they hate. What music do you like? What's your favorite color? I don't care that you hate everyone else. So does everyone else, that's not unique to you. Fuck off. I hate hating this about others, because that's exactly what I am hating about what they are doing. I hate that I am hating. Please, please, can we just be real?

I don't know what this album is, and I also can't make it into something it's not. I am confused, frustrated, alone, sad, grieving, lost, grateful, thankful, uninspired, hopeful, insecure, and driven. I don't know where this is going, but I can't keep feeling this ugly. I don't want to keep feeling this ugly.

Edit Nov. 10 '25: When printing the original artwork for my personal copy of the project (I make jewel cases with CD-Rs inside of my catalog, as I make it), the printer seemingly ran out of ink, because of just how much red the artwork needed. I was bummed about this, but also, I was kind of fine with it. It's like it represented that the intensity of what this record came from, it's like it was "melting the printer" in that it was too intense to print the artwork, because of what it was rooted in. I know it's just the printer running out of ink, that's the logical answer. It also however represented a reflection of how I am and have been feeling because of everything going on, and how I internally feel like I am falling apart. So it was an accurate reflection of that as well. I think I took it as more of a happy accident than an intentional thing. I was indeed curious about whether there was enough ink when printing it, and I never would have thought it to look like how it turned out. The whole image is supposed to be red essentially. So you'd think there would be no red if the ink was totally out. But there was just enough to try, and then it gave in. It couldn't let the intensity take over. That's a sign of strength. I printed the artwork on cardstock, because I thought I might make a booklet out of it. But since I didn't want to waste the extra think paper, I printed the artwork sideways, so I could fold the rest of the paper into the two-fold thing. There's only two parts to it. So that's why I wrote on it as well, and why the lines of the ink go that direction. Had I printed it normal, vertically, the red would have printed from the top of the artwork, not the right. Very intriguing, and also, very fascinating.

Edit about probably an hour later:
Thought that an inverted color version of the new artwork would look cool. Tried it, super cool. Then I had the inclination, to combine the two in some aspect. That turned out even even cooler, awesome. It is very much more unhinged now. So many layers went into the artwork, I couldn't have done it intentionally, if I tried. It's just inclination after inclination, after mishap, after inclination, and so on. Very happy with how it turned out, and how accurate it represents the void feeling of the work, and inherently the time period that it originated from.

name: Septem Numero (2025 Remaster)
description:
Heya! This is on Nov. 15, '25. Coming back to write up about this project. Had some thoughts and things to describe about this update to it, and maybe the reconnection to the musings of the original heart that it came from.

This project was very much, at least in feeling for myself, "my first album". I had made plenty of original songs up to this point, but I didn't internally feel like they were part of a cohesive vision (most of the songs on the 'Classic Projects' compilation album are what I am referencing). I also wasn't necessarily making what I had been wanting to make. I mean, I found out how to make songs, but I didn't have that feeling of "yes". To some extent, I guess that's always the case with my projects, and it just ends up being what I am capable of making at that time period. I am okay with that, and now I think that is actually the visible goal for myself, as of today, right now, and what I perceive to be going forwards into the future. I am to be as clear to make what I feel I need to make at that moment, and I am to do it as good as I can do it. I am to learn what I need to work on to make that vision clearer if I wasn't able to do what I wanted to do in my head.

Okay, that is laid out now. In learning how much a mix or master can affect a creative work, I was very curious about this as a concept. Lots of my work felt like it was completely there creatively, but it's coat of paint or foundation was merely just incomplete, or I wasn't able to articulate it effectively, or just didn't know how to for what I was hoping to achieve. This makes a lot of sense now. So now with that concept, I recently have been going into my back catalog to assess what I felt didn't work with it, from that time. I started with remixing 'so, many, bad, decisions', as I felt that I maybe could have a new set of ears at hearing it different than it was to start with. It originally was going to try to be a faithful remix to the original, but then I let the rains down a bit, and let it be what it was going to be, whether that was a creative new take a the original one, or if it was simply just a hope to adjust the "paint" of it to bring it's light through a bit better. I am happy with what I was able to do for that. I do find now though that I do think it did change the feeling of the album a bit, and I don't necessarily like that. I am happy with the result of the new feeling though, so I am utilizing that as being a success. I tried something new, learned from it, and I got a new way to hear a project I am close to and already love. It did clean up some loose ends of things I didn't like about the first, so it was still a success in a list of hopes of what I wanted to achieve with the remix.

Come to this remaster. This was a very open project (the original I mean, in terms of writing, composition, creation, learning), and I always loved how it turned out. Looking back now though, it was littered with the issues of my lack of knowledge in making it. Again, I wouldn't have known any better, and it's not a bad thing. I am where I am now because of the mistakes I've made along the way. That's how the learning happened.

So. The album came out in 2016. I had bounced the songs straight to M4A for use in iTunes, as that was essentially the only "target" I was worried about. I was making an album for myself, and to "maybe" play for my friends over a speaker or something. It was to see what was possible. I thought it was just crazy at all that I could create a song in GarageBand, export it, save it to my computer, add my name to it, and add it to my phone. I felt like a "professional". Not that I actually believed that, but I think I had assumed there was more music to it than just that, and that was very intriguing to me. This idea started with back in 'Made in merica' essentially. That was the first proper album, for real. I was curious not just about making cool songs (the 'Classic Projects' demos), but the idea of a "thing" that had a whole world in it, and it was "mine" (huh?), that seemed amazing. Like I could just make any sounds I wanted to, and if I liked it, then just put a cool picture on it, make some cool names to describe what I thought that song sounded like, and call it a day. The experimenting essentially started with this album, in the literal sense. The first two projects were in all reality, me learning how to use GarageBand, and getting used to the production process. The "album" part was the cool part, and that it was all one long story. I tried to do song transitions, but I didn't know how to do that, so I didn't do it very well. That aside, having one long group of "sonic stories" and ways to describe whatever "atmosphere" this was, I loved that. It seemed very personal. I wasn't conscious of all this stuff, but this is how I am remembering it feeling now, looking back on it, with the words I understand from it now.

So yeah. For this project, I have no idea about the (im)proper use of gain staging. I didn't know about EQ, compression, "mixing" in the proper sense. I just could make sounds that I enjoyed or seemed new to my ears, combine them, and give names to their tone. I wasn't even necessarily happy with the "imperfections" of things like the weird time signatures or "happy mistakes". I just didn't know how to fix them, and dealing with all of that in GarageBand is heinous (looking back now) anyways, so I kind of just learned to love the songs as they were.

Then you come back to the things like quirks with GarageBand audio rendering, and plain things like updates that change synth sounds over time. So now if I open the songs today in GarageBand iOS, they likely sound totally different, because the songs were rendered with buggy (probably?) synths, and now they don't sound like the original takes anymore. And because I didn't see the need for Bounce in Place, nor is it trivial in GarageBand iOS, the real stems don't actually exist anywhere; other than the audio samples I made myself of course.

And to make matters even more complicated. Since I was heavily trying to essentially push the limits of what I seemed to be an endless playground of things to build and create with, a lot of the things I would play with these synths and samples seemingly didn't play nicely with, what I now see, was GarageBand's Offline rendering mode. So I would make a song like "1eve1 I", and the way it sounds now in the bounce, it didn't sound anything like that when I had recorded it. It was without that weird note that spans the whole length of the track. It was much more open in that part of the song, in that you could actually hear the parts where that part obscures. The vocal part was meant to sound all chopped up and DJ-like in a way, or something like that. "glitchy", in sound.

I got so frustrated and confused as to why the song wasn't exporting the same as it had intended to sound, that I ended up deleting the `.band` file for it, and now only that messed up M4A one is what remains from it. This is the same thing for Gamma Rays as well.
