I actually don't totally remember what the intended one of that was supposed to sound like, I think the ending craziness on the copy that remains was much more fuzzy and louder than the playback sound of the original.

Had I somehow had the ability to export these with Realtime bouncing back then, maybe this wouldn't have been an issue. But I didn't know this was a facet to the issue at play, nor was it available to me in GarageBand iOS, which was all I had or understood how to use. We didn't have any Macs, nor Logic Pro X (nice), so there were a lot of factors at play at being able to actually fix the songs to be what I made them sound like originally. And now I definitely can't fix it, because of my frustration which led me to delete the `.band` files. And they probably wouldn't playback or render the same as back then anyways, hence because of all the things I mentioned earlier.

So, that's where we stand with things. Then you have small little things that bugged me, which again, weren't intentional. After having "finished" the album sometime during the summer (I think?), I ended up making another song, "Conspiracy". I felt like the album had a proper end with the end of Cascade. I really did want the album to end there. But then Conspiracy was such a great track, I thought I may add it on to the end. Looking at it now, I could have done just that, but I still don't want it to end on *such* a dark note. I 100% love the darkness of that song though, so it was definitely needed for inclusion in the project. It was almost going to be added to Spectrum, like a cool seamless transition between albums. I forgot about that, maybe I will look into doing that again, I don't think I actually have tried that yet before, other than having to want to do it maybe with this song. But Spectrum didn't end up including this song, and it was just a bonus track here instead. 

Why is all of this significant? Okay. Remember how we had only bounced the tracks with M4A? yeah. How are we to do song transitions now then? So, I had (badly) attempted to cut off part of the end of Cascade, and paste it into the start of Conspiracy. That involved trimming the already-bounced Cascade with the now shorter ending, now once again, back to M4A. This was getting ugly. I thought that I wouldn't need to do this, so that's why I didn't account for it really when bouncing to M4A, from the beginning. Now it is trivial when bouncing to lossless, because you don't worry about lossy encodes each time. And all of the other implications I mentioned prior to now. And because I had bounced Conspiracy with the start including the end of Cascade, now there was no going back, because seemingly that one seemed to bounce differently with each export as well, so I couldn't go back and remove that extra clip I had added. I just gave up on including Conspiracy at that point, so for the time until this was uploaded to Bandcamp the first time, it didn't actually have any bonus tracks in my own library. It was some time after I had uploaded it to Bandcamp that I added the three tracks just as they were, even with their brokenness, to the original Bandcamp version.

Okay, now where are we? In seeing that this project had no viable way to "fix" the project using it's stems or a rebounce to proper lossless (sad face emoji), the only possible way I could do "anything" to "help" this project was to attempt a remaster of it. How bad could that be? I think it very much turned out very nicely for it. Lots of the rough edges of simple things like EQ and volume consistency between tracks, that's much simpler to handle in a more accessible interface like Logic. So the production was mainly the only thing I could fix. The sources are ugly, so be it. I am happy now with the story that they hold, too. So I don't mind embracing them for what they are and were, essentially. So I think it wraps around nicely here.

And I simply used ffmpeg to convert the "source M4A files" (ugh, I'm sorry!) into WAV files (travesty!), and remaster those. I did a lot of things like cutting certain frequencies which hurt to listen to, as I didn't know about the know how about that before, nor did I really understand any of that stuff. I just knew it "sounded bad", "unfinished", "uneven", "hurt", or was "too loud". So I knew it needed work, but I didn't know what was wrong with it in the technical sense, nor did I know how to fix it. And inherently, I didn't know any better to leave room for my future self to fix it, because for whatever reason.

Okay. And big takeaways from all of that? I never delete any songs I make anymore. Any. Not that it's a strict rule, as I mean, I do delete random things if I didn't like them or something, but that would have to be very very early on. Even if something doesn't make the cut for an album now, I still don't delete it. It just goes in an "Extras" folder inside of that project. The information of holding on to the knowledge of something I made that I don't like, that's just as useful as something I did like, or was happy with. It just doesn't warrant being part of the complete project, on a visible level. The creativity in it still left it's mark though, so I shall keep the demo. That's the thing.

And starting with Flatlands, I always bounce in lossless. Yes, that's right. Elkosaurus is sourced from M4A files. I am bummed about that too. I may, and just maybe, try to go back and do a proper remix from the original `.band` files, as I love that project for what it is. And I am curious about the gain staging, EQ, and compression issues that might have been at play. I haven't even gone back and listened to that project with those things in mind though, so I am very curious what my takeaways will be in terms of this "new ear" of mine, per se. Yes it was meant to be an ugly album, purely bad. But one part of the equation I never did complete, was the concept that it would be *even more hilarious* if I were to bounce the whole thing as lossless (as back then I wasn't actually able to hear lossless being any different, I just saw it as "unnecessary". Oh how I was wrong), and mix and master it to be very well done. So like a nice and shiny turd, for lack of better words. Best way to meme, ever. So yeah. Maybe remastering (or remixing!!! ðŸ¤“) a turd into a better turd, that's pretty hilarious as well. I have never thought about that in the terms of Elkosaurus ambiguity. That's funny. Making a mental note of that. You may see a rehashed version of Elkosaurus in the near future. Will keep you up to date. Ha.

Beyond Transverse was an in-between song between this and Ultimate Chaos, if I remember right. Might be wrong on the timing, but it was at some point in between something. It never felt "done", and it was actually one of the few times that I worked on a song over and over and over and over, to try and "perfect" it. Or in what I felt at the time, to "fix it". The bounce sounds nothing like what the `.band` file currently does. I didn't make backups as I edited it, so I ended up changing things like loop patterns, and a bunch of stuff. So the original project in it's state of the bounce, I am understood to believe doesn't exist anywhere. The weird time signature offset things with the loops, I don't think that was intended? It sounded cool, but I knew it was broken somehow. Looking back now, I wouldn't have it any other way. But I think I just didn't know what that song was supposed to be, and that was the issue. It got lost in trying to be something it wasn't, and it got confused along the way. And the ending part of it sounded different to the project file too, if I remember right. Again, same issues with the FX plugin thing, the "DJ tool" from GB iOS. So it probably had to do with Offline rendering as well.

Okay to cover one more time, for my own sanity, since I went on a lot of tangents. This project was incomplete from original sources, and the mix files weren't inherently clear, nor are they lossless. So I did what I could to remaster them, after having converted them from M4A to WAV. I then fixed up things like zero-crossings at the start and ends of tracks, EQ pain points and clarity (bringing out certain frequencies that fell back into the mix, because of the lack of EQ in the actual mix), fixing volume consistency throughout the playback of the album (some parts were too loud, some too quiet, some were louder of quieter than they were intended from the beginning), and proper song transitions for where required. Lots of positives.

I do feel like some of the heart of this record was in the imperfections too though, so I do think while this was a positive addition to the way this was conveyed as a project, fixing it kind of inherently removes some of it's honesty. I think both renditions are keen to keep for the entire explanation of what was learned from this. This one is the better "listen", in terms of the audio, and the original was a better "learn", and more honest to the source material itself.

I did use some compression throughout the songs too, as it wasn't present before. I think sometimes the original was a bit jarring when it goes up and down so much. Part of that dizzying experience was, again though, part of what made it what it was. So it's up to you to decide which you like more. Again, to me, both are crucial in expressing the goals for different things. The original was an open-ended creative expression, with all of the raw parts embedded. This version is trying to re-mold that original dough into something that's at least a little bit more square.

Food for thought ðŸ™‚

The original was purely done on an iPhone SE 1, with probably Skullcandy earbuds. That's it. So yeah, that's probably why it sounds like that.

Another aspect to the reason for deleting project files, and or not exporting as lossless. I did not have a computer of my own. My first phone was 8 GB (yes), an iPhone 5C. I did not have much space to store huge working projects. I had to have space for things like SimCity BuildIt, Clash of Clans, Vine, *and* GarageBand itself. Space was limited. Moving to the iPhone SE at 64 GB was like a breath of fresh air. So say for like Made in merica, the song Googolplex is totally missing it's `.band` file, merely because I could only export the song had I moved over all other songs for the project to the computer, and vice versa. So I actually had to get rid of parts of the project to finish it. Very ugly, but it "workedâ„¢". I am just glad that I even still have as many projects as I do from this time, because there are a few I just deleted because I got bored of them. That was from the Classic Projects era, so not any of these album ones. I think I only moved the actual `.band` projects over to my computer once I had my own. So they were on our other iPad for years, because I AirDropped them to there for "storage". Such a crazy thing. Now all of it is either on my Mac or on my external drive. I absolutely am living in luxury now, in terms of data management and storage. I am glad I started learning about that stuff. It helps immensely. Just safe practices in general are a good thing. I probably didn't really have any of those back then, other than just backing up my phone to the computer. I am happy I did that though, have to start somewhere, and I think it was just lack of knowing to save data safely, in that kind of concern of losing it.

But about this project, hypothetically I could have bounced it as lossless because I then had the storage with my new phone, but I didn't know the benefits of lossless, and I didn't have any playback places to know that it actually was better, or why I would think it was better. It wasn't until probably about a year ago as to when I discovered the audible difference between lossy and lossless. Groundbreaking, and kind of a bummer. Bought so much of my music on iTunes, and now I can hear (at least for releases 2008 and lower, essentially) that it's not as clear. I am currently concluding that most likely Apple encodes the lossless sources to M4A when the song is distributed from the artist, then the encoded file stays the same all these years later. But this means that music I buy from 1995, uploaded in 2002, it still sounds like a 2002-encoded AAC file. Bummer. But yeah. I didn't have the stereo, headphones, nor ear to hear the difference between lossy and lossless, so I had no inclinations to "needing it". Make sense?

Oh yeah, and the piano part in Gamma Rays wasn't meant to sound that bad, I just didn't have good timing tapping out the notes, and I was to consumed with going to fix it, as I think the quanitzation didn't work well for it, and I didn't have the patience to go back and fix the notes manually. I still don't have that patience lol. Listen to any of my tracks since 2020 with drum parts in them. Lol. My "reasoning" is that I'd rather focus on playing it better than to fix the ones I recorded badly. I could be working on another song rather than trying to fix the current song. Good mantra, bad mantra? I don't know. I also am too impatient to find the answer to that. Maybe that's why there's so many albums ðŸ˜‚

This remaster wasn't perfect either though, and I am also okay with that. Some songs inherently were hard to fix, namely Warp Velocity. The EQ cuts made definitely sound weird. I plainly didn't want this album to hurt to listen to though, so while it doesn't necessarily "sound good" in some parts, I have to either learn about things like automating EQ, or other complex concepts. So rather than trying to make it perfect now, again, the best I can currently do is the main goal. It is "better" than the original now, using these additional metrics, with clarity in mind. It is a more consistent listen now. I also needed to exercise getting over worrying about doing remasters. I had to start somewhere, and this album's original production definitely needed it. So again, net positive here. It was an inconsistent listen to start with, and I didn't want that to be present, that was the goal. It might not sound like the original, and that's okay. Just a second take on it. Some of the dynamics might have been nice to keep though, looking back at this remaster. Cascade isn't as clear in sound, Conspiracy isn't as scary (maybe it's the mid bass parts I removed too much, the high end isn't as clear), and the weirdness of Warp Velocity with the EQ cuts feeling a bit jarring in the ear (the song was painful, and now it's jarring; at least it doesn't hurt).

name: The Post Apocalyptic Entertainment World
description:
"a compilation album"!

In making a representative collection of songs for a friend of mine, I realized that the contents on the CD itself would be nice to have as a sort of starting ground for my releases which I am fond of myself (these are all songs I've released previous to this; the only outlier is "Underwater Artillery", which hasn't been made available until now; just a timing thing). These currently also seem to be in my own opinion some of my most fully-fleshed work too, whether it be compositionally, creatively, sonically, things like that. This one has funny moments, but it should be all of the ones that are memorable.

If you'd like your own CD copy, feel free to ask me to make one for you, or to burn a copy yourself, if you so please. Enjoy!

I have and still do have a less keen feeling towards compilation releases, as I very much value the album experience and also the context that songs are placed together, and how they came about. That inherently seems to be how I structure my own albums in general, too. Like I seem to feel like an album is "done" when the ideas start to change creatively, or when I feel burnt out on a certain style. It seems to line up with life events too, whether it's change in schedules, seasons, end of the year, going to a new place, meeting new people, things like that. When your sphere of influence changes, that seems to be my internal marker for "okay, this is no longer that original thing that it started as". This has gotten more apparent with time I feel, because of practicing this. It could also just be part of letting go and being in the now, and trusting my instinct of "okay this is complete now". It used to be hard to do that. It still is, but now it's not as hard (that's what she said?).

But yeah, for the compilation album part of this, I think that's another thing I ~~have to~~ *want to* get over, it has it's utility, and it makes it easier to explain the kinds of music I do to other people, and that's always a good thing. Having a nice place for them to start is good. It might not be what I want from a release in the creative sense, but it is worth it to do that for people new to your work. It seems to also be a neat way for me to also internally catalog how things have gone over time, by listening to how each of the sounds of each song has changed over time.

I intentionally didn't remix or remaster specifically for this release, as I wanted it to be a raw gathering of things over time. Note that there are remixes on here, those were done for their own benefit, not for this release specifically. I guess I could have included both versions of the ones that were remixed, but that seemed a bit counterintuitive to me. Maybe could have been cool though. I think the progression of mixing and mastering is apparent enough between the songs, having two versions of some songs seems a bit much, for on this release.

This was going to be called "Sampler '25", but that felt too generic. Another one was "To Whom It May Concern", but it also felt like it had been used previously.

The name for this came from when I had a realization on how I feel we are at in terms of the "entertainment ""industry"" ", if you were to call it that. I don't mean in terms of the business side of things, but the personal enjoyment of entertainment itself. I realized that it seems like it is heavily rooted in business rather than plain old entertainment. If it was just entertainment, you can do that all by yourself. So what exactly are you paying people to do? I mean for big consumer content, be it reels, feeds, algorithms, big labels. Not an anti-business thing necessarily, but morseso, why is it that that is the only route that seems to be popular nowadays? "Did you see that new show on Netflix?" "Do you stream with Spotify?" "No that's not on Paramount Plus yet.". It's all around a big overarching brand. I know back in the day it was based around fame, celebrities, "drama" per se, and things like that (staying in the know with people you put on a pedestal), so it's not all sunshine and rainbows. It's just that now we don't have that, and in it's place, it's not even partially personable. It's all about ego. Maybe it always has been, but yeah. Wanna drive a cool car? It's because you want to look cool to your friends. Wanna go to the gym? It's because you want to impress a girl. Wanna dress up nice? It's to post on your social media, to which then other people compare themselves to you and put you on that pedestal. Or unintentionally making people jealous of your good looks. It seems like everything has strings attached for everything, again, to me it does. [this outlook] it's sickening. That's why I am doing things that are fun for me, and that make me happy. It's not to look cool, it's because I use it to push my comfort zone into places I haven't been before. I am typing my honest thoughts on the Internet. That's new! Rather than being like "I wish people could be more open", I am being more open. Again, not taking that as an "I am better than you because I can be open", simply just the observation. Instead, I lend you my hand to do the same. It is gratifying to let go in that way. Best time of my life [thus far]. The future has never felt brighter, because I am now always living in the now. You can't pay money for how good that feels. I hope others can feel the same essence of that. Only you can do that for yourself.

Okay yeah. So uh. A new album. CDs are awesome, you have control over the content, they are lossless PCM, what else could one ask for? Oh yeah, and they have amazing backwards compatibility, they've been around for 40 years. It's awesome. Scratches are a bitch though ðŸ˜ƒ

Was watching this just before I did the uploads here, very great timing.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jOmpyJUPHpg

Really been in a music kick lately, not in an obsessive way, it just keeps finding natural ways back into plans lately. Very thankful for that. If you "try to make it work", that's when things get frustrated. This link found it's way into my eyes earlier this evening too, also very thankful to have found it. Your heroes are normal people just like us too (lol).
https://www.reddit.com/r/Guitar/comments/26drgn/this_is_mike_keneally_from_zappa_satriani/

Okay, another realization after googling the name of this album. [generalizations incoming] People have become so disconnected from their ability to be in the now, that they are looking for abstractions to problems that don't need solving. It's the "XY problem" that is commonly mentioned in programming. Someone didn't get the input they needed when growing up, and or they got negative feedback. That gets internalized. They look for confirmation from outside sources to try to fill that void, which they were not taught to fill in their own fruition. They are now looking to get popular and get a lot of money, because they get validated by other people's opinions of them. So they want to become a guitarist. Guitarists get popular. They don't want to actually play guitar, they want the side effects of what it technically encompasses for people who are "successful" in the pop culture aspect of things (monetarily, "perceived" status [ego; how they *think* they will feel when they reach that place]). But that doesn't fix the root problem. So when they are looking to play guitar, they go to AI tools to write guitar parts for them, because it's not the music they are interested in. (a food for thought question, meant to be open-ended) Why else would anyone that is interested in music want to leave their space for interpretive input to some outside entity? They must be in it for different reasons than what I personally understand. Again, this is my perception. Why would I want a part of a song to be generated for me, when I can just learn how to make something that I enjoy more myself? For a learning tool, I could see it being used. It's not advertised as that though. That's what makes it ugly too. People are led to believe that these magical AI tools will get them the step forward that they need to "get their foot in the door". It's not about using the AI in their own fruition. It's just a "cheat code" at that point. We have all of this "big data" driving AI nowadays, plenty of it could be useful to people if we had realized what we could learn from it. Rather than have AI catch a fish for you, why not have it teach you to fish? If what it taught you was wrong, then just figure out the right answer. That's always an option. Say AI is like 3 wishes. If you could have it answer 3 of your own biggest questions, or teach you 3 different ways to answer your own biggest questions, which would you take? (hypothetical, that sounded cool, and the point comes across; I think AI is great for learning from, much like Wikipedia is; it could be wrong, and we realized why we don't cite Wikipedia anymore. Why is AI any different than Wikipedia?)

Listening to Synergy while writing this. Kind of went on a rant. Just gonna roll with it.

returning a few minutes later after a few other realizations...

I'm also of the thought that I don't blame people and or industries for why they are the way they are. If they weren't to be like that, then they wouldn't have been. But they are. So rather than getting mad about what has happened thus far, what are we going to do about it *now*? It makes sense for companies to cater to what people want. It makes sense for people to buy what they want from companies. What doesn't make sense is why we as people look for certain things from companies, celebrity figures, what have you. We have the access to do that for ourselves. That's what I hope to see change, or rather, to gain awareness of. Maybe this is already a thing. Maybe I just don't know of it. I just know that this has been my observation and I just hope others can see their reliance on things that don't actually help them as well.

Say one has a drinking problem. Drinking itself isn't the problem, it's the byproduct of another problem. WHY you drink is the problem. Or rather, what is causing you to need to want to drink, that's the problem. It is in our domain to learn why we do what we do. It doesn't have to be observed as "good" or "bad". That is a concern for another time. What will benefit you right now, in this moment? What positive steps can you take that will *lead* you towards where you want to be? Worrying about not being there yet isn't beneficial. Small steps are okay.

Another edit, later the next morning. It's the lack of knowhow of self-acknowledgement that stems the issue. That is [possibly] what causes those dangerous "fixes" to come about, whether it's drugs, alcohol. It "solves" the feeling, but it doesn't solve the cause of it. And when there are a lack of tools available to someone, they are going to do what they know how to do to try to solve that. Nobody is to blame for that. It's like if you told someone to build a spaceship or they are fired. This is McDonalds. Why would they know how to build a spaceship? So the goal is to make building a spaceship public knowledge, and not taboo to talk about. It's not wimpy to know how to build a spaceship, and it's something to be proud of. So it's in the interest and concern of adults and parents to be the strongest most teachable they can be for their children. How it is gone about is something to be solved on a case by case basis, a parent has to know their own faults, and to work around them. Maybe they don't know their own faults, that is the very hard part. How do you become perceptive of your own limitations, which were placed onto you, because of some external factor? It's not your own fault that it's like that. It's just your duty to learn what they are, and to either counteract them in parenting, or to, in a pedestrian way, explain it to your young ones to where they can understand, and not internalize those struggles as being part of them as well.

So I think it is a big part around being self-aware on a personal level. That seems to be what is the missing key, from my opinion, perspective, what have you. I don't know if it's the truth, but right now, in making choices around that being the premise, it really seems to be helping me grow as a person. Finding your limitations, whether that's what you have created under your own fruition, or the ones that were implicitly handed down to you, because they weren't caught upstream. The tools may not have been available prior to you to catch them. That's going to happen, and it's not some magic bullet to solve all of your problems. You aren't going to be perfect. But as they say, you can sure try to be. And that's what counts. The worst is being aware of your problems and issues, and not doing anything about it. It turns into a downward spiral unbelievably swiftly.

I'm no magician though, nor a therapist. So I urge you to please do this work on your own, for you as well. I don't have the answers for you, as I also don't have the answers for me. This is just what I have been ruminating about. Hope all is well. Whether we like it or not, we got this ðŸ˜‚

name: progger
description:
Took a few days to ruminate on how I feel the results of the 2025 remix for "so, many, bad, decisions" turned out, and came back with some interesting thoughts.

Just realized that I have learned a lot about mixing and mastering, both in the things I have learned up until now, and what I also have done wrong thus far. Compression and dynamics have been mixed up in my mind, in terms of how you use them, like what you are trying to achieve. Same with EQ. The intentions were in the right place, but when and how I was utilizing each of them, I still have much more to learn in that regard.

So I fully do not regret doing the remix. It does not quite sound to the extent I hoped it would have though, and I'm not sure any remix will "fix" that album per se though. It might have just needed a simple remaster from the raw mixes again, rather than EQing everything and rebalancing it all again in terms of levels. So I think I knew what I was trying to do, but not quite how to do it.

The contrary to this realization, is that I think I have to let it be what it is. Realizing things like certain parts being not quite nice enough in the mix, there are small things like that. But going back and fixing it over and over, that isn't helping either. I tried something new, overall it was a net positive to the representation of that project, and I am proud of how it turned out. It is a nice counterpart in addition to the original. I still enjoy the punchiness of some songs and sections on the original, that seems to be what I felt was lacking with the remix in some respects. While it is less "flat" and "blurry", it is lacking in energy as well.

So the response to this scenario? I feel the drive again to try experimenting and just letting loose again, not maybe necessarily in terms of the "anything goes" approach that Recreational was, but more in that I feel it's time for creation again, rather than refinement.

Okay, so that's where we are today. I started feeling the drive of just "trying to make things" again, albeit even if it's messy, and or whatnot. I am still onboarding all of the critiques I learned from things like Recreational, DEBUG, and "so many remixes" (as I like to call it), and rather than trying to "perfect" those with the new things I learned, I'd rather put that new found knowledge and perspectives into new things to delve into. That feels really productive to me too. It's that you tried something, learned something, and moved on to the next thing.

Felt a nice tuning over the last week or so, again, so that's what this is spurred from. That was just the inclination of what was interesting again. It is some sort of open tuning, in some kind of semi-tone I think (doesn't line up to 440hz). So it's not in "tune", but the guitar is in tune with itself, so I think it works very nicely. Originally, this sound really felt inspired (in practice) by Daisy Rickman's album Howl. I wasn't specifically trying to sound like her, whether that's sound or genre, but the parts that it's rooted in, whether that's presence/musicality, or whatever "essence", I think that album came into the front of my mind again. The rawness of the tuning seems to be what I am looking for right now. It's a raw album, like just an honest, open kind of one.

As of writing this, I wrote these 3 songs today on the 9th, and they seem to be kind of ambient/etherial, and heavy as well. I think I like the lower/open tunings for both ambient and heavy too, it seems like those kind of songs tend to come out of me when I am in that tuning. Standard tuning seems to be more solos, and the half-down Drop D seems to be Primus and or Keneally-eque, to some extent. Standard tuning seems to lend itself to me writing more conventional song structures too. Regular Dropped D seems to be very ominous in writing, and the half-down Drop D seems to be also possibly Alice in Chains-ey, but with a heavy chuggy thing too, so possibly things like Strapping.

The artwork was from some pictures of myself that were taken at a haircut, for some reason when seeing that picture, my internal voice for describing myself from how I saw "me", was "progger". So something called to me in that way. Whatever that was, that seemed to tie it all together, and I went and made these three songs. Again, Fall Festival is the current one as of writing this.

Keneally interview is awesome, watched it last night:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g8EBiEVHAls

Gilmour interview is awesome as well, watched it tonight:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OT_KFCidz_s

Dan Worrall is a great guy, he has an awesome channel about mixing. Learned some new things from him which I used on Fall Festival. Check out the Voxengo Sound Delay. It very much helps with the uncanny valley which is hard panning. I don't know what I am doing yet, as expected, so it might sound a bit rough still. I think it worked nice though, so I went with what I had tried.
https://www.voxengo.com/product/sounddelay/

This project is not complete, to emphasize. This is another, find out what this thing is, as I go, kind of thing.

The artwork turned out insanely cool, wow. Made it fully all myself.

Edit next day: Okay, added two more songs, Sandwiches and Rains. I totally dig rains. Both are great, but Rains is perfect, for lack of better words.

Had some fun making a back cover, aka jacket for this project. This one definitely feels like a cohesive work, even if it is a bit out there. It seems to have a vision in terms of style, and what it is. Maybe even if a bit stringent in straightforward-ness, or whatever, I internally know what this thing is. The current artwork represents it so well. That's why I felt like making the jacket for it, for the first time. The style of it seems very visible in my mind, now.

It is giving me concepts of Devin Townsend Infinity. Whether or not the music is similar, and or the vision, or what have you, the idea that the work itself is itself a "thing", that's the part that this seems to relate to me with in the concept here. Maybe it is just because I like the artwork a lot. The concept of the music really could be anything at all. So maybe it is just that. I am not to worry about what it is though, simply just to make the work into what it feels like what it is.

Might be fun to order real CDs for this afterwards, since I made the artwork and jacket combo. It might be the paper CD sleeve which this could be in, rather than a jewel case. I mean, a jewel case would work too. Haven't tried a paper sleeve yet though, so maybe that's the intriguing part.

This seems to be a very effect-y project, just totally drenched in processing and custom sound fields. The artwork was a result of a similar temptation. They weren't inherently meant to be the same, but it seemed to come from the same kind of experimentation. So that worked nicely, because it wasn't intentional. The artwork was going to have a red background and just my regular picture. Then I started messing around with a bunch of different layers, color adjustment concepts, filters, and the final artwork showed itself to me, just like that. It looked so cool. Then I did some other tweaks, and the background ended up turning gray. That seemed to work a lot actually, so it wasn't dark red anymore. The filters made a nice effect of blending me into the background too, rather than being placed right on top of it. And as I have usually been doing, I reexported the final artwork as CMYK, as I really enjoy the print color aesthetic. For my own enjoyment of it, it feels like something much more tangible, like it has already been printed out, and I had scanned the artwork again, or something like that. It removes some of that "digital edge", per se. (If some of these phrases are on album names, this is because I wrote them right now, and they sound like great names, so I am archiving them for later. I didn't try to reference the work in this paragraph, I just found the phrases through writing and then it stuck in my brain as being cool) So it's kind of like how tape is to me, like giving that real world feel. It has a logical use too, since I print paper artwork for my own pressing of my projects, to CD jewel cases, and printers only use CMYK. So in finding out about catering artwork towards CMYK, I actually enjoyed the look of it, so I started using it artistically as well. I think some of the first times I realized I actually liked the look was for things like Up the Downstair. That seems to have some sort of blooming on the cover, even on the digital artwork. I think probably because it was printed, then scanned for digital release, afterwards. I'm not totally sure. But that essence of that, I personally enjoy.

name: so, many, bad, decisions (2025 Mix)
description:
(work in progress! released but not complete, keep tuned for more updates; songs are not mastered yet, so they are a bit quiet)

Really inspired by learning about mixing and mastering, as I have mentioned previously. With that new perspective, I had a gigantic awakening about how bad (relative to now) my previous mixes for releases really were. I think the most recent two projects especially brought that to light. It's that I saw that I was able to make really nice mixes for my work, even if the writing is still in my haywire style. It really does come down to just proper level management, like gain staging, and inherently, compression.

I recently started looking into what parts of a mix that are important to me personally. I very much value dynamic takes, as well as a nice low-end, and clear high end. Without being too mathematical like that (because it's hard to explain things clearly without real-world examples), right now my mix inspiration is somewhere in feeling between Mike Keneally & Beer for Dolphins Sluggo! and Sevendust Home. If the "sound" of those had a crossover in production styles, it possibly could be these. Whether my work actually sounds like either parts from those, I don't know. I'm not trying to worry about what my new concepts "sound like", in relation to other things. All I am focusing on is figuring out what things click for me when I listen to the albums I love, and now I am trying to trust my own process to figure out whether I sonically like the "sound" of my music, rather than just the creative influence of it.

I am going to release the progress for this second version of this album, as I go. So the songs are not mastered yet, I will do that with a final bounce at the end of the mixing stages (I mix each song independently, then I bounce them, and master them together into a seamless crossfaded project, then bounce each track from that session; this is what I did for Recreation and DEBUG. I very much am digging that new addition to the workflow).

Seeing how much you can collect the essence of the album with something like mastering, it's groundbreaking. I've always struggled with having songs properly flow into one another, as well as having them at the volume I thought they should be at in my head. Let alone dynamics preserved, but that's a whole other story.

Because I have used GarageBand iOS for my final bounces for such a long time, that's all I knew. Same with mixing capabilities. Now I see that there is a lack of clarity in terms of being able to see the mix in terms of EQ, leveling, and gain staging. My mixes tend to have been running too hot, because I didn't know about headroom, in regards to 0db. GarageBand iOS also applies auto-normalization on export. I did not know the application of what EQ was inherently used for. I know you were "supposed" to use it, but I now see that I really just didn't understand it because my ear hadn't practiced that kind of auditory listening before. It's a different mindset than listening to the song like you would a fan. It's more about the sonic experience itself, to figure out what works or doesn't work in the arrangement. I didn't have the personal context of driving that process, so inherently, the work reflects that. I had always felt my mixes felt very blurry, and or fuzzy, and flat. All of these parts to the puzzle explain that.

Learning from various people, there are also parts that gravitate towards whether the arrangement lends itself to working nicely to being mixed too, whether it's double tracking, panning, counterparts, melodies, instrument choices. Not saying those are all good or bad, but rather that the inherent result of those decisions, that's what determines how the project is to be mixed. And one of my newer goals in relation to that, is to try and think of that, even if just a little, from the beginning of the project. Not that you have to make it sound like that right when you record it, but that you write parts for each other, rather than throwing them all at the dartboard because you feel like it. If that's what the song dictates for you, then okay, so be it. Heck yeah. But if it's because you don't know any better, then there might be some learning to do there. I'm all for both. Intentional insanity? Heck yes. Unintentional muffling? That's when you get disappointed by the result of your work. It's simply because there's more to learn, and you're just not quite to that point. It's okay, and it has to happen that way.

That's another counterpart to this. It's that I absolutely do not regret my decisions before this point. Because the only reason I am here learning about all of this and how it works, it's because I found I was very much not pleased with the result of my work. I started noticing how I had room to grow. The things I would let slide before, just because I felt they didn't bother me (because really, they didn't, it was just for fun), they started to bug me. That's when I realized I had to make some changes. Just start asking questions, rather than getting mad at the result and giving up. "Why do I dislike this new song I made? Even though it was fun to write?" "Why does it sound like that?" "Why doesn't it sound like <another reference project>?" "What would I change to make it sound more like <another reference project>?" If you don't know the answer to something, then that's where you look into things next. If you aren't feeling up to it now, and it feels like you don't believe in the work because you feel bad about it, then give it a rest. Not all of the things have to be solved now. The fact that you got to this point at all is already great progress. You are helping yourself get better. It will be difficult, and seeing it with fresh eyes and ears is all the difference. Just give it time, new perspectives bring new light to things.

I used to take a long time to release my projects, I think because I have the tendency to hold on tight to things I work dearly on. I am proud of that. It also comes with it's hard parts, in that it might restrict the project from being all that it can be, because you don't trust the process. I now have been practicing trusting the process more, releasing things on the fly, finishing projects sooner, that kind of thing. The underlying part though, is that I am intentionally helping myself not be so close to it. It's about like letting the mistakes stay in the recording, embracing them. Just because a mix might not quite be perfect, if it's better than it sounded yesterday, then that's great. That's progress. If you know it needs work, and you don't know why, then I will let it go and release it as is. To some extent I have been good at this since working on music the last few years, as I really haven't been 100% fully pleased with the sound of things as I finished them. But that's the thing. You can't be fully pleased, so the thing to work on is to not worry about it when you've done everything in your current power to make it the best of what it can be *right now*. This project is an example of that. I was very happy with this release musically, and sonically, at the time. Looking back now though, I see what additionally could have come of it. I didn't have the perspective to see that back then. So I can't blame myself for not having done it like this back then. That's where you can lead yourself forward. Rather than toiling in the despair of what the project isn't, just do your absolute best of what you know you can do now, then when you run out of tools, leave the project, allow it to be complete, and stand behind your abilities as they are now. Rather than trying to perfect something to which you are lacking the tools to make, instead use that time to focus on learning what tools you are missing, and keep learning those and practicing them.

I was going to mention this probably two paragraphs ago. I was very much debating whether I should even make a remix or remaster for this project.

The debate: Do I let the project be what it was when I made it, and stand behind that, and all of the learning it encompassed up to now? Or do I breath the life into the project which I wasn't able to at the time, now that I am able to?

Also with that, but really a separate scope of questioning: Do I replace the original mix on the release with this new updated version, because it is "better" (loaded take, that's where the issue is), or do I release it as a counterpart to the original?

That question threw me for a loop, because it had a very inherently deep set of implications I had to unwind a bit to answer properly. "Better" is an opinion. Opinions are subjective. Yes, while more work has gone into this new version than the previous version, that doesn't mean that it is "better". "Better" defines whether someone likes something, based on the criteria that they define for it being good. That is on a personal level. This then opened my eyes to checking out other albums I have loved in the past and current, and realizing that me personally, I actually very much enjoyed the non-remastered versions more than the remastered. But again, this seemed to be on an album-by-album basis. So even for me, with albums I like, it depends on the album itself. It's not that remasters are always better, it's that if what you are looking for in an album isn't in it to begin with, and a remaster would provide that for you, then yes, the remaster is for you. If the latter is the case, then the original is for you. Say the Devin Townsend Infinity remaster, I realized it has less of the EQ curve that I enjoy from that album (as to how I heard it when I first heard it; the parts I liked weren't present there), as well as more compression. For me, the parts about the album that I liked, were how raw and strong it was. Yes, I agree, it sounds rough since it was recorded like that, but again, to my own personal opinion, that's what made the album what it was, FOR ME. I understand why cleaning it up in a few ways, yes it makes it more like music out nowadays. But that's the part that I don't connect with. I specifically like that it doesn't sound like anything else, that's why I connected with it. And another example, say Mike Keneally & Beer for Dolphins Sluggo!, I very much adore the new 2013 mix. It is much clearer in terms of EQ and dynamics, and I think the original had some tape artifacts if I remember reading correctly too. The underlying part to both cases though, which I am not saying will always be true across the board, but has been true for the albums I've looked into thus far, is that it seems like I tend to always pick the sound which I heard first, regardless of which it is. Like if I heard the remastered before the original, then I would likely pick the remastered. If I heard the original before I heard the remastered, I would probably pick the original. Again, this on paper seems to be *how I operate* thus far. I am curious about whether this will change with future listens, I am eager to see. I listened to Genesis Selling England by the Pound, and I heard the remaster first. I listened to parts of the original, and I still liked the remaster. Yet again, it ended up being that I liked the remaster.

To wrap back around, after realizing all of those parts about myself and my own associations to things, as well as my inclinations about "betterness", and how it is subjective, in correlation with realizing that I am only capable of doing right now what I am able to do, I am going to release this project remixed and mastered again, and keep the original intact as it's own. Personally, I intend to enjoy this remix/remaster more than the original, since I ended up not quite being pleased with the original. However, I can't make that choice for you, you have your own inclinations to things, and I want to embrace that. As well as, my goal with my work is to be as logically transparent about the growing process here, much like open source code. I am using this to learn about myself, and I am hopeful that my learnings can be of help to anyone who finds themself in a similar path to mine. And obscuring the less better version of the album only hinders that learning process. Instead, say like you wanted to know why certain EQ choices were made in this remix, and or compression and things like that. They might only make sense because you went and listened to the original. The last thing I want to do is to prevent that correlation from being accessible, to obscure it. Being able to simply diff the two tracks and discern the creative choices sonically between the two, that's priceless to be able to do. At least for me anyways, that's exactly how I learned from the releases I mentioned above. So, why wouldn't I also want to make that accessible of my work as well?

Event if I end up finding out I don't like doing remixes, I will learn that by doing this one.

Edit Sep 15: Doing tracks 8 through 11 today. Went back and adjusted a few levels for Philosophy, and removed the mix bus EQ for all previous tracks. Realized that I want to start with a clean slate when doing EQ and compression for mastering, since I might unintentionally just undo what I did during the mix anyways. Might as well allow it to breath closer to what it sounded like in the first place. Easier to inspect in terms of original frequencies intent.

pogcat wasn't much work, I very much have really liked the mix for that, just the clipping and compression from GarageBand was the main issue. I did widen the stereo panning for the guitars, that is a change I may revert though. Will listen back and decide whether that caters to the song or not.

I realized I think I mixed a lot of these using the stereo monitors, rather than headphones, and I am curious how much that influenced both the original mix, as well as my use of headphones now.

Actually, I forgot, I added some of the original grit back into WELUTT too, since that (unintentionally) was kind of the point of the sound, it was supposed to be ugly, in a way.

Okay, this is probably 5 minutes later. The mix for pogcat was perfect to begin with, even with it's ugliness. I did make the drums a fraction of a db more visible in the mix though, so I reverted the panning changes.

Edit Oct. 4 '25:

Just started the remix for Pineapple Parrot and Cheese Cat tonight. So they don't have much better of things in terms of EQ, if anything I removed some of the defaults which seemed to still be present on the main tracks, I didn't seem to have removed them at the time. It was much more hastily done than I had remembered doing. Pineapple Parrot already sounds multitudes better, it was so crushed and fuzzy before.

A lot of the edits I made this morning and tonight (well, right now it's 1:14 AM, so the 3rd really), I had started to take inspiration from the music I have loved lately. Namely, Mike Keneally and Beer for Dolphins Sluggo, The Who Tommy, Queen Jazz!, and a bunch of others. Maybe not in name specifically, in terms of like specific aspects I am borrowing from each of them, but that I had realized that I really enjoy stereo panning. I think when I had made this album now two years ago, I still was keen to not pan as wide when mixing with headphones, because it sounds much much wider than how wide it is(n't?) on the stereo. So now I think my mental model for stereo panning in mixing, it's much wider than it used to be. Multitudes of these tracks have much more breathing room than they did previously. I have to say, it is changing the chaotic nature of the project a bit, back to more lighthearted and silly. I am also kind of okay with however it sounds. I am curious whether the chaotic notion will kind of resurface when I go to properly mastering everything, or if this [album] will generally be less uncanny overall.

Some tracks really do breathe so much better than before, it's absolutely awesome. Some are having trouble finding their way though, namely because I don't quite know how to mix vocals naturally yet. I seem to have gotten a hang of my trio-stereo kind of thing, where you have maybe two guitars (well isn't that a quartet then?), then drums and bass in the middle. But vocals? Well, then that's a different story. Lots of other clashing frequencies I have yet to know how to cut, by muscle memory. The other ones I seem to get close enough on the first try now, practice sure works it's magic!

It's been about 3 weeks I've been working on this remix, and I am very proud of myself by how I came about at it. I am making multiple changes across multiple sessions, and I am not obsessing about getting it done all at once. I think it's because I started to see how taking breaks really does help you with hearing it with new ears. Listening in the car really does help bring things to fruition too, that's been helping a lot. I do keep having to remind myself that it's not mastered yet though, because I keep wanting to make certain things brighter. But now I see the point of mixing, and of mastering. Mixing is where you choose which parts of which sections should poke out from each instrument at a given time. Mastering simply makes these certain frequency ranges more apparent or not. So once something is hidden behind something else, mastering can't do a damn thing about it. This totally makes sense for how those stem splitter tools work too, because it's not like the whole sound is all there once it's mixed, that's the point of mixing. When one thing takes more presence, you lose what was behind it. Say like you flatten an image in Photopea, you can figure out what came from each layer, but you don't know what was in that layer underneath the obscuring part above. That's exactly how mixing works. So with that in mind, I have been pushing certain parts of each instrument to make those parts of that instrument more apparent, then I plan to lower the output of those master resulting frequencies back down to make it more streamlined. Say like you see the sun through the trees, that's what I'm doing. If the sun wasn't that bright, you could only see parts of it through the trees. But because it's so bright, it's really visible through the trees, it even makes rays of light on the ground. That's what I am trying to do with my mixes. Right now, it seems to be the kind of sound I want. It seems like you could call it "frequency bleeding" or something. Not sure if it's what other people do, or if it's good or bad, but it seems to be doing how I hope to accomplish with the sound. Same with the bass and treble, bass guitar and frequencies are intended to be a huge part of this, for some reason. I love when it feels super big, like this wide truck coming through your stereo. Wall of sound, but more like wall of waves, or something. Another note, turning down things from 1k to 6k just about, it helps immensely with listening fatigue, it's been awesome. Will also do this in mastering. 3k is also evil, by the way. Putting cuts for that inside of the mix for each track, before needing to do it in mastering, it helps so much. It just helps things that it might obscure from being more visible now. Say like a sound is loud and hurts because it's 3k. That peak now hides other frequencies which might be crucial to the full context as well. This mitigates that. It's like your cutting off the part of the branch of the tree that blocks the sun on your favorite bench.

Edit: Alright! As of Oct. 7, this is now the final mix and master for the whole project! Going to listen back a bunch to this, to see what I do and don't like about it. Debating whether I will make any changes if there's anything I find while listening back to it. This definitely has a different feel to it than the first one, regardless of that being a good or bad thing. I have yet to find out. I'm keeping in mind that I am glad that I tried doing this, rather than whether the goal itself was successful or not. Time will tell.

The original public date for this was Sept 12, and I finished it today on Oct 7, so it took just about a month for the whole remix, and last night/this morning for the mastering. I really worked this time on not trying to be too close to the work all at once, like getting "obsessed" with it. I did kind of get that way this weekend, but if anything because I felt I didn't want to have this drag on any longer in terms of edits. It seems just about as close to what I can get out of it, with my current skillset. So I kind of just pushed through and did the last few songs mixes this weekend(day), then did the mastering. I had already kind of demoed how I was going to master each song, in each song itself, I simply just didn't bounce the mix files with those, they were bypassed. Overall, I am very happy with how much flavor and life this brought back to these songs. I think I will need to take some time to appreciate the work I did for this, as right now I can ultimately sense I am too critical of it, too close to it. But that's also why I wanted to push through to the end too, because I knew it was getting to that "hyper-critical" point, where things get frustrating over moot things, which are inconsequential. This is a net positive, so I am going to let it be as such ðŸ™‚

RUSH IS TOURING AGAIN? ðŸ˜ƒðŸ˜ƒ

*edit: Oct 20 '25

Dammit, alright. I was going to try not to go back and make edits after having told myself that I wouldn't, but I did. This time I really am though. I think I am not totally happy with the accuracy of this remix/remaster. The main thing is just the "vibe" of the songs seems to be lost for me. I went and fixed it in some regards today, with a few things I made mental notes of when going back to listen to it. Mainly removing some compression, adding some, changing some master gain and compression for certain tracks, a whole bunch. So some sound really good I think, and some don't feel right and I don't know why. But I really need to move on from this one. As it currently stands, I am not one for remixing. Being close to the material is the only way I know how to make it work, and not obsess over it. I have to feel that it's right, in the moment, having just made it. And because the original sound was created by improper gain staging in GarageBand, and lots of limiting (on the master tracks; again, not intentional), a lot of the sound was achieved in ways I don't fully know how to replicate again, with the new clearer mixes. Ideally it would be more perceptive and EQ-ed to certain parts, that was the goal, and I would just fix the limiting issues. But maybe the point this whole time, is that yes, the ugly mix is the mix itself. I don't know. Once again, this is the case of where the more you know, the more perceptive you are to that you don't know a fucking thing (not to be pessimistic; lol). I don't think there is, right now at least, a way that I can make this mix into something I will be happy with. Maybe that will change, maybe another remix in the future will work better. Either way, I think I need to move on from this one. Maybe I could have stuck with the original mix more in the beginning and simply fixed the mastering issues. Aaagh. This is a mess. But I tried, and that's a good thing. I don't regret what I tried, I just am bummed that I am not happy with the result. I can't tell if it's "better" now, that's what's weird. I think logically, it does sound clearer, more intentional. I don't know if I like it more though. That may just be the uncertainty here. After all this work, I thought it would be a no brainer that this version is much better. And I am not feeling that. And I don't want to have version after version of the same album. I am trying to be okay with that being the case, but I don't know if I want to be okay with it either. Again, I'd rather be putting energy into trying it with a new sound, than the same trodden path I made a few years ago. That makes sense as well. If I am going to try new mixing and mastering styles, they might as well shape the aesthetic of a new concept or album style as well, rather than trying to pander one set of writing to another style. That feels to be the internal problem.

After having just written that, I feel amazing. That clears the air. I am not against remixes or remasters in their own right. I just am not happy with how it turned out here, and I don't think I want to do them quite yet. I don't have the "ear" for it, nor the practiced workflow to decipher keeping the original "intent" of the original compositions, while making it also sound better.

It is weird though, in that when I made this album the first time, I also wasn't totally happy with the mix/master. Maybe moreso the master, I don't know. I hadn't known the gain staging/limiting issues were there, so that was definitely part of it. But I remember feeling like I had to let go of the things I didn't like about it as well, be it the messy recordings, weird clicks at the end of songs, a bunch of stuff.

So maybe that's why I don't like this either, it's not the remix, it's not the master. It's that there are blisters throughout this album, and trying to shave them off and make it into something new, that's not helping either.

So, maybe, lesson learned. As they say, you can't make a turd into a faberge egg. I don't think anyone has said that, but I like the sentiment of it. I also don't think this album is a turd. It has a beam of light through the heart of it, and I think regardless of how it is mixed, mastered, recorded, it is still shrouded in the difficulties that made it come to it's fruition. And there's nothing I can do to change that about this. It is all there, like it or not. The strife of the difficulties around the time period I wrote it in, the personal struggles with others and myself at the time, that's all there. And maybe trying to work through this album again, it could be reconnecting with those again, and that is very difficult. Not that I specifically don't want to stay connected with that part of me, but that I find it hard to look at it through the same eyes as that time period again, being a different person now.

I feel like the same thing applies with say if I were to remix Elkosaurus Tex. I would love for that project to be more fully fleshed out like my projects now. But it would be a heck of a thing to delve into again, pull apart, rebuild, yack.

Now, something else to learn from this. I would love to have the ability to be able to reconnect with past times like that, and not have it bother your current state like it used to. That is also something I can work on, and would be very powerful to do. Not sure if that's self-acceptance, and or self-awareness. Definitely sounds like it. Maybe it just has to happen with more time, then. That also makes a lot of sense. Regardless of mixing and mastering skills (which would be great to have more of when redoing a project), I think having a larger perspective on that original time period, and where you were as a person back then, that is part of the thing. I can work on that, and I am very interested in that.

If you try to do it on a similar level to where you were then, it is too close. But with time, and perspective, you can honor that state of you, through your new caring eyes.

Okay, gonna go check if Beer for Dolphins Dancing is in the mail, then maybe do some new recordings today. See ya! â¤ï¸

edit ~20 minutes later. Fuck it. This sounds insanely awesome. Fuuck iiittt!!! I love how much better this sounds. Comparing the remix to itself, you get stuck in a loop. Comparing the remix to the original, oh my fucking god. It's fucking crazy. This sounds outstanding. I'm proud of what I made here, and I now don't want to change anything about it. Done. Time to let go. Part of this might be that I added a custom little descriptor to the artwork too, just a little "2025" thing at the top, to signify the difference. I love this. I need to burn a CD of it, right now. We'll see if I make the artwork or not for it though, been printing a lot recently, don't want to be too much of an ink hog. Wow though, I forgot just how much the original sucks in terms of mix. Or rather, I forgot how much of a long way I've come in mixing/mastering, fuck me! (again, not pessimistic, just shocked; british slang).

Okay, kudos. Been through hard shit, came out the other side (as mentioned in "Philosophy", reference unintended), and now I am happy. What else can I ask for. Fuck yeah.

[p.s. the working title in my head/on my computer, for this: "so many remixes"]

name: Izalea Afterglow
description:
This "project" started from the fallout of what the previous projects before this had turned into. It was me striving to rekindle the concept of making a lighthearted release, where the songs were simple because they were enjoyable.

Well, actually, I had thought of the idea of making projects of distinct genres under all new names. I loved and still love the concept of this, yet it didn't flesh out because I was trying to make genres of songs I didn't know how to make, nor was familiar in listening to myself, so I didn't even have a real reference of how to make it.

This essentially consists of three different folders of projects, which ended up being demos for what I concerned them to be. It was one of those things where the songs are neat, but they don't quite work or fit in the projects adjacent to when they were made. So maybe it was just a transitional time in general. The time period was after DEBUG INTERNAL ERROR, before starting to work on 'so many remixes', and then progger.

So it was in practice, August 26 through to September 24. I was essentially trying to start up whatever new project was next, but I was at that point where nothing was sticking. These songs are from three folders from that time. They are once again kind of random names. The title of this project was originally going to be the alter ego "personality" of music which would be very accessible, and pop-driven. Again, I found that it seemed to be more the novelty of making that happen and learning how to do it, than what ideas it was rooted in to make that happen. So I still love the idea, but I just didn't have any music that I wanted to utilize for that (whether ones I came up with, or existing songs). The 'trip' songs (unintentionally named similarly) were from Izalea, and Bounce House. There was a folder called "Jerk the terk'" (don't ask; I don't know either), none of the songs from that were used. It started on Sept 7. Just demos which didn't catch my brain onto anything. Lots of good names though. That's one thing that's a bummer about my demos, they all tend to have some of my favorite names. The third folder was called "Compressed to Fuck!". Again, related to mixing or something? lol. Space Cadet, Tangential, and Cardboard came from this folder. It started on Sept 14. If I don't have an overarching drive for a single album at hand, I seem to write demos every time I am free after or before work, and or when I am open on the weekends. So I think that's why the folders tend to start a week apart or so. It is because the interest of the past week finished, so the next week I move onto something new to try that. On the night of the 23rd, I made three songs, one of which was Bounce It Off Someone Else First. The other two were either contrived/rehashed/not enticing, so I only used that one.

Sensor Tripped (both parts) was one song, but I split in two while mastering it (today, Jan 4th '26; happy new year!). It felt like a neat little thing to show the EP-like nature of this album. It's like a bunch of excerpts of nice things that happened during the sessions, while maybe not necessarily an album in concept. They were attempts to start the next full-blown project, but didn't turn out to be that.

This is the first project to be mastered with my Beyerdynamic DT 990 Pro 250 Ohm's. I was originally going to "properly" mix these projects in Logic, as, another thing, these were all made on my iPad (I think I wanted to experiment with that open-ended kind of creating I do on there, like my classic songs). I was sorting through my iPad the last day or two to tidy things up, and remembered I hadn't actually finished or filed away these projects yet, and I almost was going to not release them, and just hold onto them as demos. But I thought I might as well put them into a nice little bundle, and try doing some mastering on them. Learned the other night that I've been using compression and limiters wrong thus far (you need to have enough gain to actually activate them, duh), so that was also something I wanted to try. So while these are simple demos which I just kind of like, they are in theory mastered much better than much other things I've done so far, funnily enough. Gotta start somewhere.

I used Linear Phase EQ for everything here too, as I learned that that works better for mastering, as Channel EQ is better for single stems. It does seem to be much more clear than with Channel EQ. Duly noted.

So maybe the mixes themselves aren't too nice (They were whatever I did in GarageBand back when I made these songs), and I bounced them with GarageBand too, so I don't know whether it was fully safe gain staging or not. But I think I remember keeping it from clipping. It's not as transparent as Logic's mixer shows you.

I also was thinking, before having finished Ferret Train, that Bleeper might have worked nice for this pop idea. I think I still don't know too much about song structures yet though, so while it sonically sounds like a pop song, the structures and concepts aren't there. So maybe I will do it sometime, but it just wasn't this time. That's okay!

Much like Recreational (if I remember right), I used LUFS to measure the loudness on this one too, rather than just full scale. This seems to work much much better for consistent volume, instead of just pushing them all to full scale. If one song is perceived louder, both being at full scale is very jarring, because it sounds much louder, but they are the same volume. So yeah.

Either way, all of the stuff I am learning, things are very much even more shaping up to making better projects in the future. I think it's just that I have to be aware whether I am in learning mode, experimenting mode, or creating mode. Right now I seem to be in learning mode, where I learn what I have been doing wrong, what I can do next, that sort of thing. It's not a negative light, don't worry. It's all in the best outlooks. Very happy to be able to see things in that way. It's just a list of things that you currently know how to do, and to decipher whether you actually know them, or think you know them. That's a big difference. I didn't fully know how to engage the compressor or limiter for example, that makes all the difference. And Linear Phase EQ causes less smearing from what I can understand. Yeah.

name: DEBUG INTERNAL ERROR
description:
Literally just started this right now, as of the early morning of the 15th (the album I mean, the song was from a few hours ago). Was writing a commit name, when I thought it made sense as an album name. Here we are, the start of the next project. Never even saw it coming.

Edit Sep 5: Okay, this project is "done"! At least music-wise. I intend to make some of my own artwork for it again, the current one with the MIC and cassette, it's just a placeholder I feel like. This one was an unexpected one, I really like it. Even more unexpected than the previous project. It seems like some of my best work is the remnant projects I work on after finishing a full-bore project, right when I think I'm out of ideas I make some cool stuff after. Then I relax and am burnt out for a bit. So it seems like this is the songs from when I started to feel burnt out.

Coming back some time later for the mixing of these, it really put things into perspective, the mix and masters for these are fire, very happy with how they turned out! Expanded similar learnings from the previous project, and made more improvements in general. Tried the concept I heard of mixing the whole song in full, as you hear all parts, rather than mixing each on their own. Totally new perspective, I am very happy with that idea.

The original concept for this project was to try not to use too much compression too. I still like the listening volume to be consistent though, so there are still a few limiters here and there, so I can increase the gain overall. I don't want it's brick-walled though, instead to simply remove those random painful spikes which shouldn't be there to begin with (I have yet to learn how to tame those effectively; maybe a limiter on the track bus that causes it? Seems like it's still EQ clashing issues, like bass drum with bass guitar, guitar with cymbals, snare being inconsistent in hit strength). So right now using limiters is a nice fix, albeit I know not perfect. Have only really listened to this with headphones, the only one being Dynamico I listened to in the car. Excited to see how this translates accordingly.

The EQing on invididual songs during mastering really does help a ton, I adjust the EQ for how it feels song to song, to ensure they don't sound TOO (much) different between songs, I like when they are unique, but they should kind of flow together in a way, like you don't want a bass heavy followed by a lack of bass, that kind of thing.

Used crossfades once again between songs. This time I used automation on the master bus for the mastering session, that seemingly (yay!) fixed the zero crossing issues from the previous project. That's one benefit to mastering all of the songs in the same project, it makes it trivial to have those fixed, and still have things like crossfades. So mastering in a separate step is now a likeable thing for me. It's less about mastering individual songs, and moreso for the album altogether. I am now trying to clean up less in the mixing process, and simply just make the mix good (as people have said, and now I understand). This is awesome!

This project sonically has a lot of similarities to my past work, and I am extremely happy about that. It's like I am giving proper light to that work, with a new pair of glasses if you will. How this project sounds, it's how my work from that time was *supposed* to sound. Again, I will probably say this later again about this project too, the point is that you are always growing and learning, figuring out what you can work on and improve upon.

I hear parts of Electro Capacitoritor/Scary House, Carpincho, duds, zein-zein (soon to be renamed, it's the post-Reaction Factor project I have yet to fully complete). Again, can't explain how rewarding it is to let go of the process, and just let the work speak back to you. I wasn't sure if the songs here were really much to work with, but then I let myself stop obsessing over it, and said "come back to them when you feel like you can". And that made the world of difference. Now I have a nice little album/EP thing which I didn't really plan for. Or rather, this is what I would have hoped to have made, after finishing Recreational Outrage, but thought I wasn't going to be able to, but then it turned out it actually was, *and better!!*; and I still got some rest in to listen to new music too, maybe that was part of it. It seems like you have to give things time to breathe to let them finalize themselves.

Note that these are not the extra demos from Recreational Outrage, I simply started writing things I kind of felt like writing again, after having started to make things like Griselda the Snitch. So it became it's own thing, as kind of a downhill slope of relaxation after the craziness that was the previous album.

I think the taking the time to observe and understand what worked and didn't work for the previous project, that also made this one click a little more when coming back to finish this one (last night, the 4th). So that could be a big part of it, too, that I had actively figured out what I needed to adjust had I known a few more things for the previous project. And when coming back to revisit this one, those things came to fruition. This was before I had thought of the new idea to make albums of different styles and genres too, this was a precursor to that.

So this project was like when you start to realize you are on the trend of going back into learning mode/creative recovery, but you still try to keep going. The end of this project, I realized I needed to take a break, and or try something new. I ended up trying the new songs from the genres concept, but that didn't seem to pan out because of a lack of complete inspiration and or abilities to complete them to how I would be happy with.

name: Recreational Outrage
description:
(This part was written when the album was started, July 20, '25)

Pure adulterated fun! (yes, not unadulterated). Oh yeah, and, unhinged. This is like if you see a door laying vertical (on the ground). That is a presteen example of unhinged. Or maybe a couple that are dating, they are both un-"Hinge"-ed, get it?? This description is a preface to the stupidity and unhingededness of this listening experience ahead. Whatever stupid joke you thought it would be too low to be, it's below that. Complete dog water humor.

NOTE: This album is not done yet. Songs will be added, reordered, and possibly removed at will.

This is one of my more progressive projects in a while. I started it on the "release date" for it (previously, as of writing this part, it was July 20, 2025), and it is going to be at least an hour long, maybe and hour and a half. It will go in any direction, and I have yet to see where it goes yet.

Yes, the artwork is AI-generated. It is a placeholder, not the final product! I explained how I wanted the scene to look, and it looks very close to what I pictured in my head. I am going to use either digital or physical drawings of my own for the final product.

Again, the only constraint for this album are that there are "no constraints". So far, it is borrowing parts of Mike Keneally' hat. and possibly some Zappa-infused concepts too. My next premonition is that it will have some very heavy metal too, with lots of weird sounds and such.

Again again, this doesn't have to be a certain way, it will turn out how it does. However, the initial point of it's source of truth seems to be stemming from a place like Elkosaurus did. I have been very much longing to make a record like that again, and now it seems to be time. I don't know if I was ready for that kind of project again, for some time. Now I am hyper-stoked to do it. I am also very much looking to not burn out while making it, I plan to only work on songs when the time is right, and not to just spin this thing out too fast.

This is also inspired from the Boil That Dust Speck DVD and album, some of the things I learned from that really brought me back to why I love doing this. I don't know if I could name it outright yet, but it really reconnected me with my mindset from a few years ago.
