This bio is on the day after these songs were made, and this is posted one day after they were made. I 'made' that artwork in May, and I think the goal for it was to be used for something like this. Seeing it again, it perfectly fits with this project and it's intent, someway or another.

This is going to be a very abrasive release. Reflecting on "Sooth" from Boil That Dust Speck, that was part of the start of the game for making this. It made things click again. The magic of how that song came together, that's how this initiated itself. "Suommi!" is kind of like an intentional reference to that song.

This is not intended to be a regular album. Don't listen to it as such. Even I don't understand it yet. So don't expect you will either. I don't know where it is grounded in, we have yet to figure it out, together. This is just as fresh to you as it is to me. I was going to wait to publish this once it was complete, but the contrary to that seemed to be the perfect thing to do. So hilariously ridiculous. I'll add the lyrics/backing notes for each of these songs to the notes for each one.

I think this project is also the more-intentional start to my own lyric writing. Albeit, not ready for regular consumption, as this album is intended for (ugliness is wanted!).

Another thing about the concept for this is that it is almost meant to be a CD you'd find out in the world, which makes no sense, yet seems cohesive to what it is. A solid mystery object.

Oh yeah, divisive is another word for this. It is meant to represent divisiveness. The work implicitly will be divisive since it is meant to represent that as well. No drugs were present in the making of this either, or drinking. I very much value being open to yourself and not getting influence from those bad kinds of things for your mind and body. So, yeah this is purely weird in the literal sense.

Edit 8/2/25: Interestingly enough, some of the songs on here are turning out to be fairly normal to some extent, didn't expect that. This is going to be a release which goes in a bunch of different directions, but both intentionally and unintentionally. So there's even another layer of 'meta' to that as well, which I didn't even intent to have, or to try, or have even thought of before. "Haunted" is just pure awesome. It's exactly the song I have been trying to make for some time now. I can still hear where parts can get tweaked and worked on. But the way the intent was conveyed this time, for that song, it's as spot on as it's been (some others have been the same, "Open Ears, Open Eyes"), this is a further progression of that progress. Just small adjustments and learning, practice, it really does get better over time. It's awesome.

Edit 8/4/25: Okay, I am reminded what this project is for me. I think it's something to keep me grounded, yet to also continue to push into grounds of what I am, and what I can be, with work, practice, learning, and experimenting. It also involves me being open to making that happen. As I mentioned when working on As the Leaves Blow, I had a feeling it was the end of this project. But then I remembered. The thing about this project. It is meant to be something that's just, there, if that makes sense. It doesn't know what it is. It is unrelenting. Not because it needs to be, but just because it is. And it's what it seems to be representing. This one isn't trying to be something, and that's why it has to go the way it does. I think me allowing it to be like that is part of the journey, and that is the hard part. It's difficult to keep going forward with it, it is vulnerable to do that. But that's exactly why I am doing this. To keep going, find the vulnerable thing, and work with it, through it, whatever that may be. Progress is to be done.

Didn't mean to get that deep. Okay, again, so this is interesting. I remembered part of why I am doing this. Over the last year or so I think, I realized something. It's that the things you are the most aversive to doing, those are the exact things you need to do. At least that's what I've been trying to see, trying to make choices around. Of course it doesn't translate literally to all scenarios, like "do drugs, don't do drugs? I don't want to". That one, that's different. You absolutely don't want to. My concept applies more to things you are less than thrilled to do. I think it's whether it's something rooted in fear or uncertainty. That's the thing that's meant to be chased.

So it's like one of those recursive things again. This album is partly meant to encompass that I think, and that idea itself is coming up in the creation of this, counteracting itself from happening. But I remembered the goal, it's to follow the things you are afraid of, and do those. So if I was afraid, apprehensive, or what have you, about making this, and or releasing it song by song, concept by concept, possibly unfinished idea by idea, than so be it. Me being afraid of doing that, it means that now that's the thing I need to delve into then. That's where the room to grow is located.

So it's not with the goal of becoming the "always follow your dreams", or "wake up at 5:30 every morning to have your protein shakes, yoga, and meditation", it's just the plain observation, in that the most growth and "quick learnings" come from the things you don't want to do.

It might be solely related to familiarity and that kind of thing, where you are meant to survive because of things you are familiar with. That would make sense. Either way, it is simply an emotional response you have, and you can learn to look around it, and see whether it is justified or not. Is the thing you want to do, what you want to do, and for the right reasons? If so, and it's not insanely outlandish (in the real world sense, don't be a bad person), then just go flurping do it!

I think this album is also about letting go, in a way. Or if anything, just letting things take their course. You learn to trust yourself to handle things accordingly when they arise, rather than having to plan for every contingency. Ooh, maybe that's it. You don't trust yourself enough in that you will be able to handle it, so in return, you try to over-plan as a pre-response. But then you use too much energy on planning, and you don't end up getting anything done. It doesn't have to be that way! You can do it, I believe it. If you thought of it, it can be done. You got this.

Not sure if it was to you or me, but I'm sure we both need it. Good luck out there chief.

Probably will be back here with another edit on figuring out what this album means to me.

Okay back one more time, still the same session, just 30 seconds later or so. The title is meant to represent something else too. Me being able to observe, reflect on, then state my feelings, observations, as well as allow them to fester out in the open. This album is the culmination of those. I have had my own takes on seeing how people in the world are (oh god not one of those generalizations??), and usually I try to ignore generalizations and just grouping things together, to use that as evidence for your own trajectory on things. But I now also see it as a tool for getting past your own self.

It doesn't matter whether I correctly prove or describe the world around me (kind of relates to the perfectionism thing from previous paragraphs above), the point is that I am able to speak my mind, and that I trust in what I am saying. The other counterpart to that is that one has to be open to criticism for that too. It seems like (realization in real-time while writing this), that I had not [fully?] developed neither the ability to trust my feelings, or the vocalization to speak them. I also had not been very nicely open to criticism in the past. I now see that both of these come hand in hand. I think maybe I have had trouble connecting with others, because I neither could show my internal feelings on things, nor would I allow others to change how I feel, if we did get to that point. So that's a hard way to get to know people.

It seems like some people have a certain ratio of these. The really strong people (my own analysis), seem to have both. They are open to their instincts, feelings, are able to speak them, while also being open to criticism to make things better, maybe their way was not the most ideal it could have been.

With this in mind (full circle now, the original statement I was going to make), is that I have noticed how people like "Karens" seem to get mad at a lot of things, and this seems interesting to me. It seems like a response, and or compensating for something, something in the equation must be missing for them to act like that. This is true for everyone, it just depends on what metric you are looking at. People that are shy, something is causing that. Maybe "Karens" are mad at everything because they aren't accepting things to be the way that they are, and that comes across as controlling anger.

There's even more aspects to this, I could type for a while. Will expand on this more later.

In short, the artwork feels to me like it conveys ones blindness to the beauty of the world, because they are absorbed by the things that keep them safe. Rather than letting go and just living, they need things which determine how they act. It's placing your happiness outside into things you can't control, because you are [currently] unable to gather them from yourself.

This was all driven by the term itself, "recreational outrage". I then took that, and put it through my "amusing lambda", and what came out was what I thought was amusing, the play on words of having a "Karen" outdoors getting angry at things for no reason. The careful pendulum between these two interesting ways to observe this, it seemed very neat to me. So that's how the artwork came about. And I think my own journey into seeing this in myself, that's why it made sense for this project. Getting used to doing things you are uncomfortable with, in the sense of getting used to doing uncomfortable things. No, you are never completely there. The point is that that is exactly what you want to get used to. You don't want to be stagnant.

Okay, okay, another edit. This was the original original original meaning I wanted to denote here. It's meant to be "detached". This is meant to be something out of my control, I am simply letting it be what it is, and that's it. So far this bot has the goal of being, and is turning out to be, the most detached album I've ever made. I am very proud of that. I now see that simply being a conduit to the work very much does allow it to be very pure. The work itself is the strongest to what it is, it has barely any interference to hearing it from the original source material (from my head, my heart? not sure, that's cheesy though, but that's okay lol). But while this to me does sound stylistically similar to a multitude of things I've done in the past, the heart of this record is truly all new to me. I think I had tried doing this in the past, but it had not been fully apparent to me yet what it was, and what the driving force is. I think "Catastrophic Failure as a Human Being", "Electro Capacitoritor", "Growing Into Your Potential Self", "Progscapes" (still called "zein-zein"; placeholder), and "RESERVED A", they all poise a very open, unaltered, and detached point of view. Including this project, they are open to what they are, and it simply comes as it does. They didn't end up trying to be something else, and they are simply what they are. Elkosaurus almost felt like that, but it was more driven in being a certain way from the start, not simply a conduit for "whatever might happen happens". Songs like "Cab Crossing" weren't the goal to be on there, and it was a case where the conduit output that, but it was not the vision for that to be present. It does fit the album nicely, I am not observing that. Elkosaurus is exactly how I wanted it to be. It's simply not a conduit record though. This current project, this is the most conduit-based one I have had.

edit next day:

Okay, I think I understated or maybe misunderstood how I remembered Elkosaurus coming about. It was absolutely true to what it was meant to be, and it was exactly what I wanted to make at the time. It was meant to be "the most outrageous album ever". Edit Aug 11: Another point I'd like to make, is that this album is like a fully subconscious one, there's intentionally barely any afterthought in terms of having anything be a certain way. It is merely, and intentionally purely reactive. There's an impulse, it is archived, then instinctually edited to have better sound quality. Those edits don't necessarily follow any specific guidelines that are meant to make things sound a certain way. If anything, I am still trying to actively use the things I have learned to make songs better, but not use them in name. Essentially, the processes I decided to use, I didn't use them because I was "supposed to" (like EQ, compression, mixing, what have you), but more because they all seemed to more positively effect the experience of listening to the project itself. So while basically this whole album's creation was very hands-off in concept, it is very intimate in that it's the most exact recreation of the real responses themselves. It's understandable why not much of this album is necessarily memorable or notable after the fact, of listening to it. I feel the same way too, mind you. For what this album "is" (what it's make up is, what it is meant to represent, what it is grounded from, what it is built upon), it is the best thing I have ever done, because it extremely accurate. But because of that, it is not really the best "experience", if that makes sense. I think part of the art of making things like art, depending on their objective, say if they are meant for the enjoyment of the experience of observing it, then this is certainly not that. This is more like a raw expelling of ideas, and being able to let go of them. Not that they are good or bad, but just a way to see yourself. For some reason, this project hasn't been as amusing to me, as Elkosaurus was. Not quite sure. Maybe because I am already able to connect to it in a way. It's not as mindblowing this time around.

Yeah, this album is very awesome to me, because it's like it's "accurately" representing what goes on in the inside of my head all of the time. Inherently, if you are trying to represent that, then it's going to be messy and unlistenable to some extent. That's also why this project is interesting, because you can see why it is also crucial for you to have the ability to, not necessarily limit, but be able to choose what you want to express. This album is the entire removal of that. It's entirely instinctual. Even the ending of the album. I kind of just started feeling like "okay, I feel like the album is over". I was trying to think how I could end the album, what to write next for it's conclusion. But then I remembered, that's exactly the point. That's the part of your brain that this project is meant to not include. So, in return, I saw that the album was done. I had already written the conclusion, that's why it felt like it was done, complete, finalized. So that was kind of eye-opening too. Using that instinctual side of things, it's a very powerful tool to use, because it gives you answers you didn't really realize you had.

Essentially, any ideas I had of what song should come next, I didn't end up using, because that would be planning it out, and that's not what this record is.

[Still today, 11th] Working on publishing this to YouTube at the moment, that was another instinct I felt, that this should indeed be posted there, I felt it. That's different than it being on there because it's "supposed to be". If anything, my logical thoughts were that I probably shouldn't post this, because it is too outlandish, and people might not understand it (they won't; or they might, in all honesty I don't know, so I can't be sure). But again, following my instinct, I would love to post this. So I am. Hell yeah.

Edit Aug 21: Listening to Portajohn, realizing that this album is meant to be entirely tongue in cheek. It knows exactly what it is, and it bathes in it. It's not being the way it is for being totally outlandish, if anything, it is making fun of itself for what it is. Or rather, it is being exactly what it is making fun of. Think of The New Black, in how it pokes fun at Strapping itself. To me, that album is very strong, let alone for the music and things like that. But I mean in that it takes the strength out of the weakness it was rooted in, and wears it on it's sleeve. This is what this album is doing. It isn't being outlandish for the fun of it (well, it is fun, songs like A.O.V. are meant to be just totally outlandish, that one is for fun). But something like Portajohn, it is meant to take the merit out of being worried about oneself perceives themself. It is the living artifact of setting aside how people perceive you. With this project, I am not worried about how this project it perceived. If anything, the reason I don't show it to people outright is because they won't understand this aspect of it. They can only see it for the silliness that it's perceived to be from the outside. So it is using the abstract intent silliness from something like Elkosaurus, and using it as a driving force to break down the worries of perception from others on the outside. For people who would understand this, and or find the silliness funny at face value, I am happy to share the whole thing with them.

The entire album front to back, sounds exactly how it is meant to sound. It is not random, every part is exactly how it is. I mean, it is "random" how I came up with it. But it's not like the goof-ups I made in the recording, I didn't just leave them there because I am lazy. I left them there because they represent me being okay with their existence, and moving past them. It is not for the sake of it being the most ridiculous thing ever, like Elkosaurus. This is meant to use that as a catalyst to explore being okay with oneself. Elkosaurus was the same thing, but before the acceptance part. It was testing the waters to see if I was capable of letting myself be what it was. It was a success back then. This is the manifestation of that, with progress and self work since that time.

This is the physical representation of me at the very beginning of trusting my instincts. That's why I love this project so much.

I can't remember if I already mentioned this above too, but another thing is that this album is aware of the things it references, whether that's artistic influence of bands I listen to, or even self-reference to styles and songs I've done over the last few years. This isn't trying to be an "intentional breaking of new ground". If anything, it tries to lean into the tropes itself, like the silliness, and past riffs. It is playing fun at those, and really being like "HEY, I see you in there!!". So if there is a little lick that sounds like work from before, if anything, if I happened to notice that I played something familiar again, I really tried to be like "ha, I saw you!". It reminds me of the Zappa-related thing where he says if you play a wrong note, just play it twice. I think Wooten mentioned that possibly too, where if you do something wrong, try it again (the "mistake"). Make it show itself again.

So if this project is breaking new ground for me (I think it is in multiple ways, but that's besides the point), then it is merely a bonus, which I am thankful for.

Another another another thing, a lot of this is also about letting go and trusting the process. Griselda the Snitch made me think that.

Edit Aug 24: Okay, another facet to this album, it is like an apocalyptic album in a way. I have had feelings like "oh well what's the point of 'x' thing, when 'x' [excuse]". Like, why make music when people are better at it than me, or AI is around the corner, or some other thing. There was an AI YouTube video that popped up today, and it was horrible just how enticing, yet disturbing it was. Very uncanny. That reminded me what this album is. It is grounding very heavily in reality, and or humanity. How real it is really helps bring you back from bad places, because that's exactly what it was itself, as well. When you've lost all hope, all you have is yourself, honest, human, tangible, it's really scary, but that's the beauty of it. When I have no reason to make this, that's exactly why I have a reason to make it. I am here, I am now. I don't worry about then, it's not now. I am in control of me and what I can do. I don't care if something else can replicate what people do, because it can't make me happy in what 'making' does for me. It simply creates the end result. It doesn't provide the experience along the way. That's exactly what this is, too. It's a staple to humanity, in that it's imperfect, honest, personable, and tangible.

I was just now noticing I was starting to get anxious and or preoccupied with what that video did to me, and how odd it was. I tried to think of what could set me back into reality, and this album was first that came to mind. It very much described how I was feeling [frantic?], as well as allowed me something to focus on to take my mind away from that odd set of thoughts and feelings. I am human. I am me. I am in control of what I observe, consume, and think about. That's a beautiful thing.

Okay, crisis averted.

So this album is also a response to the overbearing, complex, and hard to explain, modern experience of living in 2025. AI, wars, anxiety, living at home, wanting to move out (so feeling like you are doing well, but not meeting your own expectations). Rather than thralling yourself in your own despair, what are you going to do about it? Just let that shit go. It's going to be ugly, but it's worse to just hold onto it. Rather than just letting it take you out (metaphorically; or literally if you will), just let it be it's thing, and move on. So this album isn't necessarily the venting itself, or the healing. It is more an explanation of that process, a reflection of it. That's why this [album] is so open-ended in a way, because it is an honest outlook of how things felt, in the moment.

I could talk for ages about this, I love music, art in the creative sense (I haven't done much with picture-related art), it is priceless how much it helps you work through things you don't know how to explain.

Edit Nov 25th: I think it was last week or so (or two, can't remember exactly), I heard about Kunaki for the first time. Working on getting things setup to make some physical CD releases for this project. I worked on the inside image for the two-sided artwork part of the jewel case. I realized after the fact, that while making that artwork, I was being very particular about it. As I haven't been in the same headspace this project was in when I made it, I was trying to really make sure it looked nice. I didn't end up fully liking the artwork, as I felt it didn't match the album itself. I think what it might be though, is that the image has a picture of me on it, and I think seeing myself as a representation of what this album is, that might have been scary for me. There is definitely a new vulnerability in that. A lot of my work has been a separate thing from me from essentially the beginning of doing it. Being the cypher-related naming scheme 'rBnaodn' ("every two letters flipped"; it was part of the scheme for a 'language' I made up when I was in middle school. There was more to the language than that, but that facet was part of it. The language was Nofth. Maybe I need to bring it back into perspective again..), or just plainly not really sharing this or promoting any of it with anyone, this album is an outlier in that I made it fully available and shared it with people close to me. I don't think they looked much into it. I'm not sure what their initial impressions were of it, and I also don't need to know nor need to worry about knowing. I am interested in that I didn't get much feedback about it though, so that is interesting as well. The people that did listen to it, they did have positive things to say. I was surprised I didn't get any negative feedback on it yet. Regardless of good or bad, I still can't quite figure out whether the work is just uninteresting to other people, or if they just don't "get it". Of course I made it, but something like this is totally up my alley (lol, not to sound full of myself, I sincerely promise). It must be that I just haven't made it very widely known about to get *any* reception on a larger scale. Again, not for focus of sales, streams, or things like that. I am just very interested in how it's seemingly hard to get people's attention; like good energy or bad energy. I am wondering if I want to keep it that way though. I know it's more healthy to get input from others. Internally, I still absolutely want and am striving for that. But I also know from people that did turn on that lightswitch, that there's no replacing that fuse. The magic of that bubble will pop, whether you like it or not. Once you are found, there's no going back. So I do enjoy how I am essentially, somehow, making creative work in a void. I make it without input from others, and I still make it available to people who might find it, if they stumble across it. I do worry if the solo void concept is being a disservice to others as well though, because the things I learned with all of this is absolutely something that I would be happy to share with others, it just seems like people don't see it, or they don't think it really means anything. And maybe that's not my problem. Again, I can't worry about what other people want or don't want. Only they can do that for themselves.

What was I talking about again? Oh yeah, the artwork. So one of the pictures I saved from online was a pixelated image of a line of portapotties. I think I saved that to the project folder when I had recorded Portajohn. I felt that image would be an encapsulation of the spirit of the premise of that song. I don't know if I have words to describe the premise at the moment, will add those when I know how to articulate it. The image has a picture of me on the day I recorded More Answers Than Questions, Non-Sequiturs, and Loopage is My Friend (I am pretty sure they were all the same day? The sound of these, and the writing mindset I used were very similar to Elkosaurus as well, I think that's why they came about in the same manner as that, kind of a reference back to that by merit). I am in a fancy shirt because I had to go to jury duty, and I think I was in a good mood because I was going somewhere new, felt good at being productive, and kind of silly (again, similar parts to how Elkosaurus started; being in school felt similar). The contrast to this "properness" seemed amusing to me, because I was working on this seemingly absurdist album at the same time. These observations are after the fact, I wasn't specifically thinking this literally back then. And I think the guiding concept for using that picture of me on top of those "portajohns", alongside the low-quality of the image, it seemed like a nice gag to use that as the picture. I still like the "idea" of it. Something about the edited picture feels off though, kind of jarring. I can't put my finger on it. I still feel unsure about it. But back to the thing I realized the last few days, that this album was specifically to be about not critiquing the output, to simply follow it where it leads you. I think this may be another recurring lesson for that. I think I might have to include the picture, even if it feels cheeky, or jarring, or whatever other adjective that I am putting in my own way from making great CD artwork.

So, I think I am doing it. This is the artwork. That was the idea, and I made it. It does accurately reflect the album, because I made it instinctively, and I am releasing those ideas whether my inner critic agrees or not. I think I also feel like it should really be words about the album on the inside of the cover, but I also feel like I would do that because it's the "right" thing to do. But again, that's not what this album was for. So this is another tricky one to work through, even after having completed the album. I am going to work on understanding why it makes me uncomfortable, and try to be okay with it. It's just a silly picture. I already released the album. I am already myself, I already did all of this. Whether I put my face on the representation of it, that seems to be what I am uncomfortable with. Breaking down that barrier of separation.

Maybe that's the lesson to learn here. Again, about being open to being yourself. That's what I'm afraid of. It's vulnerable. It's something to practice. It's something I want to embrace. It's something I'm starting to embrace right now.

Doing things like writing my feelings through vocals, that starts here. I have to stand behind my work myself, before I feel I can use it to articulate myself truthfully. I also feel I need to learn about understanding what emotions I feel too, as I think I feel them, but don't know how to name them. I seem to be able to discern which ones they are, and help myself work through them when I sense which ones they are at the current moment, but I don't know how to articulate to myself or others what they are at the current moment. I just know (or don't know, in some cases) the remedies to help work through them, or lessen their power. I absolutely do not want to conceal my emotions, that is 100% not an option. Or rather, I don't see it as one, or don't give myself an option to do that. I know that not everyone does that, that's not my point. I know that for me that is not one of the things I am opening to do. Too much can snowball because of that.

I also thought about using an image of the paper notes for A.O.V. or DOOBERB for the inside artwork, but I think that may make more sense inside a booklet if the album were to ever get one. So I think I would save it for that. The jewel cases that I'd get from Kunaki would have black inserts anyways, so under the CD you wouldn't get to see DOOBERB if that were placed there. The left panel in that event would be A.O.V. or something.

Getting sleepy, and I felt kind of out of sorts tonight, mentally feel like things are up in the air. I think it's just the holidays and weird schedules. Same with routines being off too, lack of running because I am tired from working so much. Happy though, being present in the moment, and not letting other people's **** cross into my mental lane. That's their business, not mine. Empathy is great, being an empath can hold you back. I love my empath abilities, they do have a self-destruct button when used to often though, so that's what I am wary of now. Wow, the weight being lifted off by not keeping that door open ALL OF THE TIME, it's breathtaking (breathgiving?). If you struggle with that, I can't state how much of a difference it's made to remind myself that "hey, I can take up space, too".

Just wanting to continue to try new things, learn from them, and keep making my little mark on this blue dot into a cool thing to look back on.

Be nice to yourselves out there, love ya!

Edit Jan 15 '26:

Was reading a Reddit thread about Disco Volante by Mr. Bungle. Someone described how they tend to borrow music styles in a kitsch way. Kitsch seems to very much relate to the humor, ironic, meta, satirical nature my music and personal tastes tend to employ. So I think now I have a new adjective to describe what this album is. "Kitsch" has been added to the knowledge books. Just had the inclination while writing this that I should make an album called Kitsch. I think I will, how about that.

I don't remember if and when I have mentioned this, in this description, or of another project of mine, but my music feels like it is trying to be if Devin Townsend, Mike Keneally, Norm Macdonald, and Patrice O'Neal worked together to make a Mr. Bungle album. The original inclination was just Norm making a Bungle album, but there's a bunch more influences than that, for me.

I think my albums, now I can see at least, have a bunch of different metrics that occur throughout the playthrough. It varies in emotion, energy, kitsch-intensity, meta humor, and irony. Each of these variables can ebb and flow, and this to me is what tells the story. One of the newer aspects which I am working on fostering more, is the open/honest/reflective/hope metric. One example from this album is Pleasantries, that is the most open song on the project. Haunted is second, and As the Leaves Blow after that. Reveling in self-awareness and exhaustion is another aspect of it too, where I may want to try and stray away from recreating work I've already made similarly in the past. However, I end up using kitsch humor to ironically self-reference myself as a joke, because I am making light of the fact that I might be uninspired or running low on ideas. So repeating colors of the past are fully aware of themselves. Not because they are what I wanted, but because I have to be okay with being currently stuck. It's acknowledging that lack of inspiration, and bringing it to light, rather than trying to fake it. It is uncomfortable, yes. That's what I'm working on though. This is all telling a cohesive story, and it's documenting the struggles of things I'm working through.

An example of where this wasn't quite the case was Orange paradox. That was (off the top of my head) the last album that I have believed in the false-positive of that lack of inspiration. If I let the "I am uninspired" get to my head, I start to believe it, and it's ugly. Or rather it feels ugly. Say like you internally feel like you are out of ideas, so you lean into it and make an ugly album because of it. Gross. That's what that was. I think it was more the sentiment of it, more than the result. I mean the album isn't one to be very interested in, there's just not much going for it. I think the point is that I wasn't owning how I was feeling, I was pinning it up as something else, like I was trying to make this absurd album, when actually I was very much wanting to make something regular, and that contrast is what felt so bad. So the things I learned from it are that I can't make an album I want to make, I have to make an album I have to make. So instead of me deciding what I make, I have to let the album make itself. That's why I love this project so much. While it is very hectic and just kind of low-hanging fruit, it's honest to how I felt, rather than trying to pin it in that I wanted to make something like this. Does that make sense? Orange paradox was close-ended, this was hyper-open-ended.

edit a few minutes later:
Am reading more into it, and "camp" might be at play, can't decide which is which yet. My work most of the time at least is intentional in the way it sounds. The deciding factor if anything though is just that the way it sounds wasn't what I wanted to make to start with. That's when it's frustrating. That's what Orange paradox was.

name: Open Ears, Open Eyes
description:
Made this one on Sunday morning, the 13th. I really worked on mixing and mastering for this one, like, a lot. So much so that I wished the song was longer. But, it is what it is. This has to be my "best sounding" song to date, I feel at least. I was blown away when coming back to it again with fresh ears. It sounds great everywhere it's played too; headphones, the car stereo, and your phone speaker. The only issue might be the arrangement, it's a little cluttered, since it tries to fit so much into the short length of the song. The solo could have been a separate section, with the backing track looped instead. But I still liked it as is, so I am going to work on arrangement for future projects. This one is absolutely awesome, and I'm super happy with it! The solo was 8 takes if I remember right, and this was #7. They were all improvised. I think the entire thing took about 3 hours to make, it was all from scratch.

I actually made the artwork for this, on it's own a few months ago. Back in May I seemingly was having fun trying out a bunch of different styles with making artwork which looked "classic". Some of those styles have still carried through to other releases, like "Snake Oil", "Trashmouth", "The Guest Room", "Renaissance", and a few others. The concept is that it can still be digitally created, but it should look like a picture of an existing photo. Or even a combination of the two. This one kind of took that approach. Since the image was already pixelated, I had to be creative with that. Seeing this one, it actually makes perfect sense for the name of the song, and the tone it has. I didn't plan that, and I didn't plan to use the artwork for a specific thing either. They both just seem to make sense when I was looking for it, and rediscovered it. Awesome!

Been trying to think about various guitar techniques lately, and this one seems to have a lot of Guthrie Govan-styled things in the solo, and maybe even Mike Keneally to some extent. It definitely has a big Guthrie tone for sure though haha.

name: THE JUGGERNAUGHT RETURNS!!!!
description:
I think it must have something to do with why this song sounds the way it does. Last night I started properly adding all of my discography to my iPod so I can listen to it, and figure out things I like and don't like about how it sounds. The main things would be styles, how I pulled it off, and of course, mixing and mastering. Noticing a bunch of things, I think I am looking to go back and try some of my old styles again, now that I have mixing and mastering a bit better. This kind of calls back to a few different things I've tried in the past. Really fuckin sick, for lack of better words. This is meant to be tongue-in-cheek, like before. I miss that, going to embrace it again. This one probably is a little over-done, but that's kind of the point. Let's get back to that!!!!

I have been kind of getting into a funk again with how messed up the world is right now, and I think that's why I'm getting back into making angry music again. I want to make weird music again too, I think the next wave of things will be somewhat like this. Only time will tell. I need to let some creative steam out again. I am still going to be mindfullness driven though, I don't plan to have this being the only outlet, unlike before. I am still going to come at it with the intention of making things I like hearing. Just going to let it run it's course.

name: Dominos
description:
This description is borrowed from the corresponding YouTube video of when I made this song :)

Did a video of what my recording process looks like now. I am still a little anxious around live streaming, since all of it is shown in real-time. I don't want that anxiety to affect how the writing/recording itself turns out. So this one is just an OBS recording, uploaded a few minutes after.

Made my own camera the main focus now, rather than the DAW. This is a big move forward in showing my confidence too, or rather, embracing it. It's me here that's the cool part, not only the music. Before I felt I was only doing a service to the teaching/recording/writing part of things. But I am an important part of why it turns out the way it does too, so changed that up this time around.

Using my iPhone camera dramatically increases the quality, looks awesome. Continuity Camera works awesome.

Will update this with the Bandcamp link once I put it up there. Will have to work on some artwork for it to be a proper 'single' if you will. (yay, hello from the future! here we are!)

For this one I used a few various things, notably parallel compression, which is new to me, just read about it yesterday. I also have been using the SketchCassette plugin for 'classic' sounds, it really ties things together I feel. Adds a great atmosphere to it, much less sterile than a plain DAW recording. Using slight pitch changing is another one, this is to sound more like vinyl, where it's more 'warm'. The video doesn't have it because it introduces latency while tracking, but it is in the final master that will be on Bandcamp. It's only a few cents more, just a small hint of flavoring. And of course chorus is in here too, that's key to this 'classic' sound. Very 80s, Rush, Yuval Ron, a bunch of different people. Really have always loved this tone, only acknowledged that not too long ago. Isn't it weird when you love a style for so long, but you didn't realize you did? Huh, interesting. Same thing for me is with things like Cannibal Corpse. Haha, or rather just the crazy heavy chuggy thrash kind of thing. Definitely plan to expand on that in time too. Just really enjoying getting this tight classic tone worked out for the time being. It sounds so great I feel.

The one thing I didn't do this time around, is that I like to check my mix/master without headphones, that usually puts new perspective on certain levels, which aren't as noticeable when you have the same 'ears' on.

And just to explain how this works one more time:
I'm using BlackHole-2ch from Homebrew to get audio looping on macOS. I have it tied to my Scarlett interface as the input/output device. Both of those are active at the system level for my sound settings. In OBS, I am using Continuity Camera from my iPhone to get the clear webcam quality, and the audio is just the system audio present when monitoring directory from Logic. I didn't do any post-record editing for the video. There is a slight delay in the video from the audio, I want to fix that. It sounds like you can fix the chunk sizes in OBS to adjust that. We'll see. It's okay for now, it is just too dang simple now to worry about it. Not needing to do any video editing is mindblowingly cool. Super simple to set up. I am doing a Window Share of Logic from here, usually I do a Display Capture. Then you get that weird OBS infinity though, so this is better to counteract that. SketchCassette II is the plugin for cassette effects, and yes I knew my mic wasn't on during the video; that was intentional. My guitar tuning is one I kind of made up, just by ear. It is kind of a cool open chord, originally extrapolated from Open C, then I changed some things with it. It's C#, F#, B, F#, A#, D#. It's like if you smashed Alice in Chains tuning with Devin Townsend, and had hints of standard tuning in there too. I like having the 2nd string still allow for dissonant notes, that is part of my style seemingly now. And you get nice pedal tones on the lower strings. Open C is too Major for me, or rather the chords are too difficult to get dissonant notes with.

name: Wide Open
description:
Made this one tonight. It feels like a very favorable echo to previous themes I've visited before. This one is done much more faithful to how it sounds in my head though. Extremely happy with my 'new ear' for mixing and mastering. Having better tools to focus on that helps as well though.

The song thread that this is apart of is across a few different albums. I think they're either different versions of what this 'song' is, and I essentially make a new version every time I 'play' it, if that makes sense. I try not to worry about whether I am repeating myself. If something improved, then that's what I'm looking for. The quality and dynamics are excellent with this one. Very happy with it. Maybe my best work across the board. I have been feeling that frequently the last few (successful) songs, I think things have been really turning a corner, and I haven't even noticed. Going back to the original versions of this 'song' from a few years ago, this is completely better in quality.

Legendale, Landslide, The Land of the Dear, The T-Shirt Nobility. There might be a few others. I think it could just be a tuning thing or something.

I am heavily thinking about going back and remixing/remastering some of these older projects, now that I hear how good my new work has been progressing. I really want to make sure I am comparing the lossless versions though, as I can very much hear when something is lossy now, like when playing back with Bandcamp.

The biggest ouch is that I was exporting things while they were clipping, the last year or so, a bunch of those projects were heavily messed up by that. Just need to turn down the levels of things, rather than making the 'quiet parts' louder. Again, having better tools really helps with this. In Logic, I can much better see whether something is redlining, or needs compression/EQ. *edit: But then again, it's also probably a paradox in that I am now just able to notice it because I have been practicing that kind of work now. Also, this video is flipping outstanding. Would be great to burn to a DVD lol. Really would be great to archive. But I won't, because it's only relevant now, as the video itself states. Thank you for the outlook here! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vV00E9CwK3Q (these edits are on the 18th)

Edit: Jul 14 '25, adding the artwork, making this 'single' now public! Meant to do this a few weeks ago now, at this point. I don't necessarily like this artwork, but it's moreso just a placeholder and or demo artwork anyways. Not feeling into it today creatively, I think having lots of things in the air is getting me preoccupied. Yes, the graphic on the top is a reference to Sluggo! by Mike Keneally & Beer for Dolphins. Thought that was a neat nod to that, a big influence of mine, as of lately once again, especially.

name: Fleeting in Time (A Tribute to Shawn Lane)
Limerence
description:
I wasn't going to include any information with this track. However now I feel I am ready for it (I posted this 8 hours ago).

I discovered the term 'limerence' earlier in the day of writing this. It was mindblowingly shocking the kinds of things it encompasses.

I am trying to understand it. I don't think it lines up completely in all aspects, but I understand and can see similar points of view and crossover with the concept here. It adds up similar explanations with things I've been struggling with. I thought I would write a song about it, without trying to 'think' about it.

It [this song] was trying to be very much 'not intentional', and simply just a reflection of what I was feeling, being in the moment. I had all of the lights off, and I looped multiple delays and reverbs together. This very far away state sounded perfect for figuring things out.

Aah, instinctual. That's it. This was with the hopes of being purely instinctual, unfiltered. I mean that in that this is only the one take, and improvised. Also a very pure reflection of how things are internally, it seems. Somehow. And yes there is some other processing like compression and EQ. I am working to use those to make things sound much better to my ears. I now have to learn what is too much and too little of compression and EQ. I am starting to listen in on that and learn what kinds of mixes tend to have that kind of response for me, like which ones are too much and which are too little. As it currently stands, this mix sounded perfect right out the gate, no questions asked. Any thoughts I had up in the air would just be 'perfectionistic'. This is exactly how I felt it would sound, and honestly better than I thought it could. That's all I can ask for. That means it's okay to release.

I might have mentioned this before, I am looking to start releasing things as soon as they feel done. I think the goal is to be able to write songs which have the possibility of feeling complete sooner. That would be very awesome. To not need the year or more delay to finish albums, be on a backlog. If I could just finish my projects as I make them, that would be the biggest step up for me I feel. Both in terms of administratively working on them, and to their own benefit. The 'closer to the metal' they can be, the more honest to their original intent they can be. This will also make it easier for me to work on things, as I'm not looking back at the same time as I am going forward.

This doesn't have to be the end goal though, it's okay if things *need* to take time. Same with everything up to here, it is what it is. It needed to take time. If it didn't, I would have finished it sooner. Even if it's not (always) achievable, just having the goal of releasing things as they feel ready, that's the end goal. Maybe the goal is to only bring forward finished pieces which undoubtedly give that response for me. That could be a way to handle it too. There are plenty of my songs that I 'like', but they aren't what I necessarily always want to bring forth, or to listen to myself. Maybe I can use those metrics as to what I want to bring forward to the finalized projects.

Okay long story concluded.

This likely will be migrated to the album cycle I'm working on right now, called "Zoince!". That's the working title. Not sure what it means either. This, in a way, is like releasing it as a single for that album. More of a side-effect though, not intentionally a single. It's more that this felt done, complete, and very much in the moment. Exactly something I'd want to share right out of the gate. The rest of the album still has a bit more potential and configuration to do.

Very excited to show you all of what I've been working on next. Very happy with how I've been progressing. Proud of myself! Looking forward to future things to learn as well. Just got an SM57 today. Not quite sure how far back exactly, but I think since maybe Jan or Feb this year, I have had the concept of recording improvisations outside, or even in a live stream/video format. It would involve recording it like a studio project I do, but with video too. It would be out in the hills, very open and broad. Big and happy, hopeful. Grand. Not grandiose, but great. I did some demo improvisations with my electric outdoors in February (yeah maybe it was around there, that lines up about right), and I got some video too. Yet to combine those and make a proper multimedia project out of it. Working up the line of projects in the works before getting to that.

I don't as much mind releasing things out of order anymore. Since it's all digital at this point (for me, right now), I can define the dates on my own anyways, and I can always just do YouTube art tracks later way after the fact (if I still want to do them, anyways, and or manually). So I can just fix the dates after the fact, and the original Bandcamp publish dates still retain the real 'release' date of those, when they were made available. I still have an internal personal timer of when those projects are 'released'. I hope to combine these into one eventually, to where the public release date is the same for me as well. That's what I want to make use of in streamlining releasing things as they are done. I think it makes it easier to move on from projects when you don't have to worry about coming back later to them, to finish them.

Seeing Devy at The Wiltern tomorrow, very much looking forward to it! He deserves a well rested break. Works so hard.

Hope all is well, have a nice one!
Brandon

Edit*: Jul 16, 25. Coming back to this, I once again see why it's one of my best works yet. It echoes the past, of things like Septem Numero, but with hope and honesty as well. But still with a hint of unknown. That's what I get from it at least though.

This is meant to be "musicked" (as Adam Neely has called it) at night, in your room, in bed, with a great pair of headphones, no noise, no lights. Whatever the most safe and sound(less) place and time is for you, that's it. There should be no distractions, and you are just experiencing. That's what this kind of my writing is meant to be with. So I guess it's like a soundtrack to meditation. At least for me, this seems to be either what it sounds/feels like to me. I do like this kind of sound playing when I do what seems to be meditation. But if anything, the way this song makes me feel, that's what being present makes me feel like. And trying to explain that is such a hard thing. This does it so well, at least to what I am able to. There's only so much you can articulate which will come across.

Really looking forward to making these projects into a complete album. I absolutely love the way this is meant to be musicked. I think I kind of forgot how these were meant to be listened to, and now I remember why. Not everything has to be for the car stereo, or for others' enjoyment. If you enjoy this too, then I am happy for you. But if anything, I made this for me. It is a tool that allows me to let go of the things I hold so dear and tightly to my heart.

name: Classic Projects
description:
If I were only including songs I think are "good for an album" by my current standards, this album probably wouldn't be a thing.

This is meant more for a look back to ideas and concepts that weren't part of an album goal, and were moreso just one-offs in concept, and showed what was coming up next in my writing. It's also kind of just an archive of the past in a way too, crazy that's the case now. I'm old haha!

These were all done with GarageBand on my iPhone, and I am only properly exporting them now as of recently, after having gone back and archived the .band files themselves. It's from early 2015 through to the start of 2020. Each of the dates is listed under each song individually if you are curious.

You can tell from how the writing here goes, and from the styles in general, it really does foreshadow into how my writing usually goes, and it sonically points into distant horizons that I cover later on. "Odd Ambient" for example was a fair ways before Septem Numero started, and looking back it sounds kind of like it would fit on that project in a way. The Guitar Improv projects were one of those too, I still tend to write in that fashion now sometimes, I just have improved my ability to listen and improvise with multitracking. I'd like to think my playing and concepts are a bit better nowadays haha. Some parts aren't too far off from how this sounds still though, so I am still feeling like I have a lot to improve on going forwards. I've felt like this for a while now, but now I am starting to notice more and more how my concepts aren't as fleshed out as I picture them to be. Now I am starting to have a stronger feeling that I want to ensure the final result is better aligned with how it's supposed to sound, execution wise and editing wise as well. I'm okay and still interested with experimenting and improvising, I just want to see if I can better hold the listener interested in that end result. If I'm writing my songs myself, and I can keep my own attention at times, then I can only imagine what other people feel. It's not wanting to cater to other's feelings, it's my own feelings that I'm not content with anymore. I guess that is a big step forward! It all starts there at least. You have to first confront yourself with your goals before you are able to change your output.

Might come up with a better name for this "album"/"release", right now it's just called Classic Projects. That does seem like a simple name for this though, it just makes sense at the same time.

name: Building Your Mental Compass
description:
Okay. Posting this on Nov. 3, '25. Coming back to these. They are essential to where things are now. I am definitely struggling with seeing why I should post these. I think they are, once again, however, crucial to the entire picture of things. This was a categorically hard time for me. Lots of things to work through, finding what the next path was of things to come next, and discovering personal things to work through. It's the storm before the sunshine. I think having the storm visible is part of the thing here, that's the whole point. I don't know how to categorize this project really, it was just some learning how to do some new recording with Logic, and wanting to write without having a goal necessarily.

The names for most of the songs were from one of my lists of random ideas for titles. 5, 8, and 9 are the only original working names left, there were a few other tracks with names already, but as of right now I replaced them all with ones I liked more, from that list of random ideas. I think I tend to have certain periods of time where I have lots of song name ideas, and this seemed to be one of them. There's probably about 50 random little things that I had come up with. They can be thought-provoking, amusing, utter ridiculous, and or both, or all of those. Whatever makes me think twice of again, it's being written down. For these songs in particular, they didn't feel like they had names right off the bat, other than the ones I named, as this is one of those very open-ended albums. It's also very much in it's raw infancy in terms of production. Mostly just recorded it, and didn't do anything with them. Didn't listen back, just went on to the next thing. Some are like that. Coming back to them, it's really reminding me of this uncertain time period, where I was starting to see and feel a larger scope to things. That is the underlying current to a good deal of my things around this time period.

Some of the song titles have really nothing to do with the tracks, namely 4. I wanted to write a song with that drum track, but I never got around to it. I like the track though, and I like the song title. They don't really fit with each other, but on their own, they very much reflect this time period, and I want to finish up these "demos" and complete them in a way, so just like not much thought went into the intricacies of the writing for these, the same goes for the production. This is what it is, I'm not going to be able to make it into something it's not.

Horray to letting go!! ðŸ˜ƒâ¤ï¸

Another note. I never mean to use bad language for direction at people or anything like that. I don't know how else to describe when you have utter distaste for certain things, it seems like "bad words" like that are the only way to describe that distain towards it. It never is meant to be criticism, instead just the explanation of that "raw emotional unrest", which is another title on the project. When it's gnawing at you, and it feels terrible. That feeling, I don't know how else to verbalize that with words. I am learning how to get better at creatively describing those kinds of things, as right now, I seem to still be very literal in how I describe it. And I don't know quite how to merge the two universes yet, being my explorative-based soundscape descriptions, and my real-world logic side. I have trouble describing my emotions, and instead, I just describe the root of them. I am working on being able to use the emotions themselves as the vessel, rather than simply the mechanism to get things rolling. Maybe it's a good thing that I am logical-based, rather than emotion-based, in my decision-making I mean. I guess it depends on the scenario, as all things do. I definitely seem to remove myself emotionally from a scenario, before I am to respond using the emotional conclusions. We will see. Lots more things to learn. I hope this is a fun listen for you, it's kind of an amusing one to me ðŸ˜„

name: Horsejaw
description:
This is definitely one of the releases! Heck, what even is this ðŸ˜‚
I love it though.

This is the ~~first~~ second release that was made *kind of* exclusively with Logic Pro (Furious Buttknott was made on my phone, then I tried to mix it in Logic). If anything, I was trying to just explore new and old musical ideas again, in the context with getting used to Logic as the stomping grounds for things. That was one of the main struggles out in the beginning, just losing muscle memory for things I was used to doing. Or rather, the muscle memory I had learned with GarageBand iOS, while it translates a lot in terms of functionality (yay), how you accomplish the same features is a little different. Looking back now (Sept 29, '25), it's not even that big of a deal anymore. The things that Logic allows you to fix totally outweigh the concerns of usability I had before. But again, it's for the final polish where it helps a lot. If I am going to go improv and have fun out and about, just having the iPad and the interface really has no way to be beaten, it's too nice of a UX.

I was allowing myself to have fun with it too, hence why the songs are so random, and a few just unfinished altogether. This didn't have to be a fully fleshed-out release, just a nice effort. I am very happy with what I learned during this time.

The concept was kind of meme-able too, in what the fun of this was rooted in. I mean kind of like how Carpincho was. Not that this was meant to be a continuation or extension of Carpincho specifically, but more in that it came from that same raw silly fun experimenting which is rooted in inside jokes and things like that. Light-hearted goofing about.

And it seemed to end when "real perspective" started to come back into frame again, with things like "New Sights". I had found a YouTube video with a bunch of neat A/V concepts, so I customized it and made a sample of that, which the song is based upon. I think that channel, and maybe just myself internally, felt like I was happy and excited for a new chapter once again, while this had already kind of started over the past few albums again. Much of a recurring theme here? lol. Hadn't noticed that until now.

But yeah I think I was starting to see lighthearted music being the way forward, of something I wanted to look into further. That did end up being the case, and you will see the rest of the music from those projects surface here soon, too.

I think part of the feeling for wanting to move forward, again, was in part by the new Devin Townsend books I got for Christmas, as well as it being the New Year soon. Not a "New Year, New Me! ðŸ¤“" scenario, but moreso that I could conceptually start a new set of things to try, by setting that landmark in time to allow it to flourish into something new. I was still the same "me", but with new concepts, tools, and practices at my disposal. Setting the year point as a landmark of things to actively start trying new, it's inspiring! It's refreshing too.

Tracks 6 and 7 (MEME!!!!!!) were going to be bonus tracks (my feeling, as of today, posting this project), but I think they do hint at the whole picture to this time period, so I am keeping them in the main lineup. The track list was a bit short without them too, so it's not like it was going to flood the length of the album. If it was already an hour or hour and a half, that would be another story. But with these two songs there too, the whole thing still clocks in at under 53 minutes.

name: Growing Into Your Potential Self
description:
This project came about in just a session yesterday. I'm breaking the pattern of releasing things in order of when they were made (I will re-order it accordingly though, this one felt utterly complete as soon as I had finished it though, so I needed to release it now, no questions asked). I still have a bunch lined up to work through from this year, this one came about at an interesting point with dealing with things. This was also fully done with Logic Pro, no GarageBand or iPad this time around, looking to delve into learning new things. The effects stack is totally solid, that's what inspired the impromptu nature of this work being the way it is.

Just earlier in the day, having just discussed things relating to feeling insecure about my music and also feeling out of ideas, after what seems to have been vocalizing that to others, I ended up making this. I didn't know this is how it would sound, and it makes me really happy to listen to. It feels very grounded or earthy or something. I will write down my guitar tuning too, I did what I had been trying on other projects this year (which you will see soon as I mentioned), where I tune the guitar to how I think it should sound (as vague as that may be), this one is some kind of flat open chord, lots of sharps in it essentially.

The stripped-back nature of this is exactly what I needed, and didn't know. There were a few other demos from this which weren't part of the session, but I had recorded with Logic also throughout the week. I think this naturally feels like the marker into using exclusively Logic from now forwards, for the time being. I had also mentioned recently to my close people that it feels like I don't know what's next in my path, but I feel like I'm ready for a change, wherever that may lead. This seems to be the uncovering of that part of the way there. I have just been feeling like, looking over this past year, it has been a great one, lots of changes, new experience, big leaps, and overall growth, continuing a positive trend in my own reflections for how things have been going. I think this premise kind of came with a down feeling, like, where do I go now? Doing that again is making it just regular, and not changing anything makes things feel like there's no meaning. Why keep doing the same things over and over again, it starts to get old? I want to learn and grow as well, and overcoming things you didn't know were in your way also seems to be a big part of this realization period, that was a subconscious part of this output too I think. It's along the path of "you don't know what you don't know", in the way that, how could you have done better, if you didn't have the tools or support to do it? It's also realizing that this is inevitable too, in that trying to keep this from happening isn't possible because things implicitly get passed down without one's intent. You have to know about a thing in order to prevent it from being persisted. And it involves having gotten over it yourself too, which is let along a daunting task. I know this is very obscure in what I'm talking about, but I don't think I'm ready to face this outright just quite yet, I think I am trying to work my way through it still, and understand it and how I want to handle it accordingly. It has presented an interesting set of emotions for this too, because they seem to counteract each other, and both sides of the coin seem to be tearing down walls, good or bad.

I want to get over self-consciousness, working through being able to express this with vocals and words is what feels like I would love to be able to do right now, but I don't feel I have fully embraced it yet, nor have the breadth to do it without causing shockwaves. I don't feel comfortable putting my growth in more importance of possibly hurting others. Maybe this is the pleasing side of things, but I don't think this is exactly the same thing. I think respect has a lot to do with it too.

Leaving the obscurity for a moment, wow I didn't realize the amount of latency that was present when using GarageBand on my iPad! Monitoring on my Mac in Logic is (perceivably) instant, and going back to try recording with what I was comfortable with, I very much noticed how bad it was. This makes so much more sense as to why sometimes I would get caught up in keeping things in time, even though I would follow the metronome to the tee, for the most part. I know I can mess up, but usually it's like a whole section of the song is just offset, and it might switch back and forth being consistently a little ahead or behind. It's like whether I was listening to the beat, or anticipating it. This disparity might be why some sections just get all discombobulated, because I start vibing with the wrong metronome, the one I hear, or the one I anticipate. Something like that. Now that should be much fixed a bit more.

I think the goal for next year is yes, to continue trying new things when given the opportunity (rather than finding a way to get out of it or not try it), but to also just be honest with yourself, and observe yourself objectively, rather than consciously (I might need to re-read that sentence, just wrote it, need to figure out if it makes sense). Find where my intentions are, what I am actually trying to do, what I actually want in the grand scheme of things, being honest when trying to decide when to let go of something, and when to hold on.

I think these tracks are meant to be played together as a whole, a journey of emotion and love (lol what). I picked Deflate as the main one because I have been connecting with that one the most, and I play it the most. The whole journey is great, I think that one sums it up the most though. Deflate is where we are at now, the other ones one way or another make up how we got to this point now (I think this journey is about me, but it isn't only me, that's why I say we. I am where I am because of the push and pull from myself, and because of others and how they interact with me, and also how I interact with them).

Final thing to add, check your expectations, and whether you need to have them. Do they help you? Are they realistic? With the honesty in mind, what is something actionable that will be a step forward for you?

name: Jestershit
description:
Okay, this is the final installation of things, where I was trying to write, after having had the seemingly significant breakthrough that ended up being the two (three) songs on From the Void. I tried to go back into "regular writing" again, and I think it just wasn't in the cards. I was ready for something new. Had to give it one more shot though. Happy with the things I made during this time. I'm also glad I moved on to new things after this.

This album was inspired by a bunch of stuff, and I don't know if I could even pin all of it down, without coming back later to take a bunch of time to examine it. I haven't done really any listens to these since I made them, other than to bounce them. They also heavily suffer from gain staging issue, and EQ, compression, the whole 9 yards. That's also part of why I went to trying new things. This album is essentially me pushing 5000% through the end of knowing that it had come to an end, and new things were right around the corner. Letting out steam before opening my brain to learning new things and taking more new perspectives.

Big words aside, after this set of songs was when I exclusively started using Logic Pro, as I had bought it a few months earlier, but wasn't quite ready to change my workflow over to it quite yet.

B.O. suffers from a bad mix, just so bad. But that kind of gives it it's insanity, so it's okay. It might have taken away from some of the strength it had though. Some of these could use a nice remix. Don't know if I am interested in doing that, I am open to doing it, if I end up wanting to though, if that makes sense. Right now I want to keep moving forwards from here though, as this was another stop-gap of ideas in a way. I am proud with just how weird this set of songs are though. Without the intent of constructing an album itself, these songs definitely make up for a weird mix of things going on. Pretty cool.

There were 6 other songs during the duration of when these were made, and there wasn't anything notable that I liked about them (which were split across 3 unused folders, I like the concept behind one which is "The World is Ugly", which opens with a track "The World is Beautiful", then the title track of the first name is used. I don't remember the songs being notable, but I love the concept).

This "album" is composed from about 5 folders of things.

Track 1 was from Sept 23 2024, and it is the only song in that folder. It was called "(bonus laughs)", I think because the title is kind of a neat observation of randomness I had. I don't know what it has to do with the song, but it is the first title that came to my mind after having recorded it, and listening back.

Tracks 2 and 3 were from the second folder, and it was unnamed. They were both recorded on Oct 19. So I mostly the songs in between the first and second folder, were the ones I didn't use.

Tracks 4 and 5 were apparently on Halloween morning, so Oct 31 '24. That is the one with the working title "jestershit". I don't know why I thought of that name, nor what it means. But for an overview of this whole collage of songs (that's a cool way to put it), "Jestershit" seems to be the overarching theme, and a nice centerpiece to the "normal" parts of the album, per se. Had this album stayed in a complete heavy thing, it probably would be composed of solely things like Essential Pocket, Sporting Shallot, 'Bovine, Spatch', and B.O. But in trying to not make these songs into something they aren't, they are left exactly as they fell.

On Nov 12, I made Track 6 - 8, and they are seemingly back-references to previous releases, which is kind of cool. I think this part of the collage kind of ties things back into how it is moving on to the "next" stage. The following songs after these very much aid in that process, as well. I think this album (or collage rather) really does point to being a conclusion to a time period, even though some of those periods felt like they had already ended in my book. But now they are ending once again, in some aspect. It might just be a neat reflection back to the past too, to acknowledge it, and state how it was important to get to where we are now. "Lonely Eyes" references back to "TragneTrake Hartbeet" from "Sponge, Assert, Expunge". I'm not totally sure which songs "Breathing Life Into You" hark back to, but it is that kind of aesthetic from that same time period, early/mid 2023. This fourth folder was tagged with the working name "Sigh". If I remember correctly, this was very close to, if not the result of, a very hard day of losing a close and important family member to all of us, and I think those three songs were the response to trying to find a way to cope with having experienced that for the first time. I didn't know how to handle it, and I had to do something. I started running a bit more as well, because I needed to let the energy out.

Continuing on that thread of internal strife because of situational struggles, we get to the 5th and final folder, which contains Tracks 9, 10, and 11. It was tagged with the working name "phonemode (phonealbum)". I think I called it that because I did some of it on my phone, definitely "Butt Erupt". It was the other side to the coin of dealing with internal struggles of grief and responding to sadness, it was just ugly anger at things. That's what B.O. is, just pure unrelenting release, but not in a nice way. Just like if you are running out of fuel in your car, but you just do pedal to the metal, and just floor it, just keep pushing. "Ampersand" was made directly after "B.O.", and I think it was the re-grounding after that need for release. So while totally opposite in what they are, they came from the same thing, but are two sides to the same struggle. It makes it very beautiful, looking back on it now. Anger and sadness. There's a lot more to this collage of songs than I realized, and maybe it will need a nice remix in the future. We'll see. There's plenty to work with here. Those two songs were made on Nov 18 '24. The final song "Butt Erupt" was made on Nov 24 '24. I think it wraps things up in a way which brings it back to a more digestible 'smaller' context in a way, not quite as in depth as some of the hard things previously covered throughout the track list. I think I knew after having made that song that what I needed to express was complete, for this scenario of things. I also knew that I was then interested in exploring using Logic Pro, and trying out new sounds, like sonically.

That means this was the last of using exclusively GarageBand on my iPad for some time. I am still using mainly Logic for the grand scheme of things (hello! This is Sept 26 '25 12am while writing this), even if I have gone back to writing in GarageBand, then editing in Logic. This project here marks the last of using exclusively GarageBand, without mixing or mastering, or anything Logic Pro to be honest.

While I knew I *wasn't* moving to Logic to become "a real artist" (whatever that means), it was the last of simply not worrying about the complete product of releases. I wanted to change that. I then just started experimenting, and learning things along the way (which I will now start covering, with all of the music I made through this release up to say about Recreational, which was released immediately, and is complete as we speak, no todo work there). That is another thing which changes, and makes a lot of sense. I hadn't realized that until I instinctively tried to do it, which was to release Recreational as I thought it was finished, rather than leaving it to myself to half-finish later on. I didn't want the context of it to blur over time, like I have done with every release up until that point (this included). I now see and am glad that I tried doing that, because that is the only logical solution to getting ahead and caught up on my releases like this (since this is being released *after* a newer album to when this was written, I know, weird). The only way to get ahead is to finish newly created music as soon as I make it, and to not add it to the stack. So far it is working nicely, while albeit messy and confusing. It really helps set the bar for getting things set up again though, without having all of these branching timelines which splinter across years. I really want to solve that, and I am very much doing so.

"Butt Erupt" kind of reminds me of "The Midranges" too, I wonder if that is some kind of common mental thread there, where I know I am in the middle of two things, and it's kind of a gap between the two.

I actually really like these few releases from late 2024, I just want to make sure I document everything I can remember from it. That's another thing that's hard with waiting too long to release your projects, the context gets blurred with new things you are working on. It makes it hard to be in the present too, which I am also trying very hard to work on. Progress is progress though! And I want to complete all of my music catalog in being public, so I have to do it for at least a few more months of work, namely the early Logic Pro demos from the start of 2025 through to Recreational (all of those singles are not solely singles, they were songs I was proud of, from folders with a bunch of other work in there too; so lots of other contexts to flesh out still).

The artwork was also a placeholder, it was what I had used for Butt Erupt. Again, for whatever reason, the artwork seems to describe this release nicely. I will adjust it with time to make it more official. I need to make full artwork for From the Void too. And that may just be a working title for those, we'll see. I feel it might be too literal and or on the nose, I like when there's more nuance and or depth to it. That was the case with Emotional Literacy, it's way too fancy. Oincy Poincy is much better, albeit totally random. I still have to go back and re-brand that one.

There were a few other songs like "Peeny Dancer", which were just plain weird, like one of them where I called it "Peven Tilson", I think because like PT for Porcupine Tree. It used a sample of my voice saying "Peven Tilson" and it used it as a weird keyboard thing. More boring than intriguing or funny though, so I didn't include it. If I were to make a remix of these songs, maybe I'd include the things which didn't make the cut for this project, as I've mentioned thus far in these descriptions.
