This marks the start of a new era for me, and if I'm not mistaken, that is the following project, "Growing Into Your Potential Self", which yes was all Logic Pro. It continues in the upward trend where From the Void, Ampersand, and Sound Bath left off, in the heart of where it comes from. It's a much more loving heart though, a safe place (actually, it's kind of like the song Safe Place too).

It's interesting, I just went back to try to figure out whether Synergy was part of this chain, and I feel like it isn't. Synergy is more like idealistic happiness, versus grounded happiness. Of course it is nice to have both as different tools for different scenarios, but I think the groundbreaking thing which some of these songs I mentioned that start with new, is that it's grounded happiness, something which I seemed to have been hard to write and or cultivate in myself. Could dive deeper into this, but I think I might have found something else to look into in terms of being able to articulate it. I think right now, as I speak, I have just found how to surface true happiness, or rather I have found things which make me happy again, and I was missing that for a while. I think it is rooted in trusting the process. Will make a note back to this later, when I have more insight.

All of this work really helps me here, and if you are working through similar things too, I hope this can feel relatable to see this process explained outright as well.

Cheers to the human experience! (instinctually thought of that just now, it applies nicely!) I hope yours is going well (lol what is this small talk).

Watched the Karate Island DVD today, and I think I learned a lot of context about my world view, and self-view from watching it again. It has lots of inspiration in things I am working on too, so that is an awesome tie-in to that too. SpongeBob is such a great show, but not even for the things you'd think it'd be. It's the subtle lessons and hints which are inscribed in the writing and character structures, it's very beautiful.

name: Devoid of Everything
description:
This isn't really an album, I don't know what this is. It's not an EP, it's not something I intended to make.

These were two songs which were part of two separate folders of demos, and I completely fell in love with these. They are the only things from those two folders that I have any connection with at all. They connect with me on such a deep level, it's astounding. I think it's because I didn't expect to make them, and they kind of just happened. They are what I feel to be some of my very most best work thus far. Not in that it's groundbreaking or something totally new, but for how they make me feel, they really seemed to reflect a very honest side of myself which I had just discovered at the time. It's a very big, big thing. It's like when you look into the sky and see how big the universe is. However, for this time, it was when I had discovered the realization of myself, me as a person. I realized my being, and what the scope of "me" meant. I know you can't really figure that out into anything tangible, but I think that's why I connect with these songs so much (hello, Sept 25, '25!). It's like when you begin to trust yourself, and you see "you", whatever that means. This was part of that.

If I remember right, both of these songs were ones I wrote after having come home from a long day at work, slept because I was exhausted (not yet used to full time work), then woke up, and made these songs. So it was that fresh state of mind, while also being late at night. So it's like a very dream state or something, maybe that's why it felt so tangible. Not that I was able to read my dreams or something funny like that, but it's like that state of happiness or content, that somehow came across into reality, and I haven't, or rather, don't get to see that too much very often. Feathers is very much the dream song for sure, state or bliss. There are still scary parts, where there is uncertainty, but it comes back home and surrounds yourself with trust again.

Sonically seems similar to Up the Downstair, C418, things like that. Not intentional, just what came about.

There's something so innocent that's beautiful about Feathers, and I think that's what it's reflecting on in some way. It's when you can't really see the innocence in yourself sometimes, and this is a large reflection of the time when I was starting to become aware to that innocence, which we seem to lose touch with over the years. Not that it's not there, but to where you don't practice connecting to it as much anymore. I'm not sure if it's just not something you remember how to do, or if it's that you feel you have moved on from that.

It's like when we are no longer here, or we are asleep or something, that presence, that "you". That's what this is embodying. Again, not trying to sound all kooky, I just don't know how to otherwise explain how this song makes me feel, or what I associate it to.

As I write this, I thought this project would be called "Into the Depths". Now I think it makes sense for it to be called "From the Void", as that's a great description of what I feel it was derived from. That unfiltered, ambient presence that is "you", that's what these seem to have been created from. It's beautiful. Again, I didn't plan to make these songs, and I love how they turned out. I don't think I can make something like this without it having come naturally on it's own, so while I wish I could create things like this more, I can't expect that of myself. This was purely situational magic.

Not trying to pat myself on the back, again, as I try to explain. I simply am just very happy with these songs.

Most of what I wrote thus far has been about Combo Brando / Feathers. I will write about Bungleow after this line.

Bungleow was very much inspired by Infinity and Ocean Machine, whether intentional or not. I think that big connection to things I mentioned above, Bungleow is fraught with that as well. This seems to be that similar kind of experience that Devin wrote about for Truth. These songs seemed to be what came out of me when I sat down with the need to make them, in a compulsion kind of way. Late at night, after having napped the afternoon away after work.

I haven't been totally happy with the final production sound on Bungleow, but looking back, it is another case of where I think it sounds how it does, and that's that. It very accurately conveys that message mentioned above, and that's the only goal.

Bungleow is like a final hurrah for a period of time, in a way. It's like a kick at the end of a race. Not that I intended for it to be the end of a period of time, but it was like a final burst of energy before the next wave of things to come.

It has a bunch of influences, namely Devin as I mentioned above, as well as SYL The New Black (I was into that at the time, new to my collection), and 200 Stab Wounds. That was new to me at the time as well. So that mix of chaos and clarity, it sums together very awesome I feel. I totally dig what happened in this recording. I have tried to go back and reference it with work I've done since then, this one came natural though. There is also the part where all of the instruments play together before it goes calm again, that part is very Marco I feel. So this also has hints of his inspirations for me, too.

I feel like I may have already talked about this song in other threads of mine, I hope I have, because there is a lot of meaning behind it to me too. The heavy part that's out of random in the quiet part, that riff is a reference to The New Black, I think it's Monument? I don't remember for sure. And the silly little drum part that the guitars emphasize with the weird noise (it happens twice), it's the P.H. intro beat. I know, kooky for sure. I think it was meant to be a fun little play on things, like a little funny "Norm-ism" if you will, like a little funny echo in the sea of seriousness.

This song is somewhere in the chain of songs like Legendale, The Land of the Dear, ones within that. Actually, listening back to it yesterday, I think a lot of these might actually be rooted in "Above the Roses" by Marco, if I remember right. It's something with that, it might have been Schattenspiel and or Borrego too, I can't quite put my finger on it, but whatever it is I'm picking up on that the common thread of those contain, that's what this is harkening back to, because I loved that "presence" of things then as well.

I guess maybe this is a counterpart to something like Feathers because it also has to do with that awareness that was gathered in that song (or time period, what have you), then it was plainly stated outright (the beginning of Bungleow), as well as then shaken to see what falls out (the heavy metal SYL/200 S.W. parts). It's like a "I got you by the balls, now lets see what you are all about!" kind of thing. It's not a menacing thing, but more like an "I have the power now, what's your explanation, what are you rooted in?", and the silly part drum beat is like a "you think you're so funny, well I can see you plainly now, so haha, good joke". I'm not sure what these descriptions really mean, but something about this makes sense in some way.

And the name itself? Bungleow is composed of two things, the "
Bungalow ASMR" channel, and "Mr. Bungle". These two things (ASMR, and silly music as whole) helped me through some hard times, and helped me realign my compass into things that I can see, and be aware of. That's a sense of self, and the ugliness that runs through one's head, which is hard to debug because it is like a computer virus, it's disguised to appear like a regularly operating program. Your brain only knows that it's how it functions, it doesn't know that the program has gone rogue. So learning to be present and see what things run rampant through your mind, that is a large step to progressing, I feel. That's what this time period was all about, debugging how your mind operates. Looking back now (Sep 25 '25), this was the start, and or continued execution of this concept, and it really started to go into place around this time. It's becoming aware of how you operate, and whether it's intentional or not. What roadblocks are you putting in your own way? Why are you doing that? What may have caused you to do that? What can you do right now which will lend itself to helping you with that? It might not work right away, you might not even have all of the answers for these. But that's the point, you are there, and you are not working at it. Great job.

Going back to talk about Feathers a little more. I think it is essentially the "bottom" point of this time period. Not good or bad, but it is the hinge by things rotated upon. Not that it is the end or start of specific areas, but more like a new beginning into what is properly the next thing. After having done Feathers, and Bungleow to an extent as well, I felt something had changed. It was a new perspective, a new line of goals in a way.

This was called "From the Void" when I released it, and after trying to quantify what these songs came from, I think a better way to put it is simply just "Void". It doesn't imply good, bad, or a place. It is simply just a presence.

Edit edit, while listening to Feathers (which I seem to always type as Featuers for some reason), I felt like "Devoid of Nothing", then "Devoid of Everything" would be a good title. So it is now that (I keep typing "not" instead of "now" as well).

If I remember right, not sure if this point in time whether I had started listening to it yet, but I had just started getting into Terria as well, so I think maybe that's kind of how things wrap around in some aspects. I'm pretty sure by the time I was working on the fourth folder that ended up as part of "Jestershit", I had been listening to Terria. I think that could have been a part of why I started delving into that "earthy" kind of thing again, and or it became a way that I could start seeing myself in new light too.

Within the 6 minute mark of Bungleow, those big open chords, I think in a way, the way the rhythm ties in there, and that kind of thing, it is meant to represent big breaths out as well, if anything that rhythm and flow there was meant to represent how that was correlating into my mind at the time. The big echoes of the song definitely emphasize the "devoid of everything" concept too, if anything, it's more that the music elicited that name though, as this was a music, and then concept kind of thing. The music spoke to me this time, before I spoke to the music.

I think Bungleow has been the definitive observation of that blissful nothing kind of thing, not just as a song, but in terms of a state as well. In the line of songs I had mentioned before, this is definitely the one.

name: Moonview
description:
Looking back, this was another case where I was trying to make an album, but there were too many things up in the air, whether that's with life, or with my writing styles at the time. I think being frustrated with the results of what I was making was also part of the struggle, in that looking back now (Sept 25 '25), it was all because of gain staging issues, which resulted in heavy compression on the master bus, and possibly clipping too, but I'm not totally sure. But now I am fully behind the sound from this time period. Not because I enjoy the sound specifically per se (it sounded much better in the DAW than when bounced, but I hadn't yet distinguished this; I thought it was "GarageBand's fault"). And because of these records from this time period, that is what led me to take the next steps to get to where I am now, and I am very grateful for having gotten to. I also was very happy with where the writing itself was going, it just didn't have a clear vision at the time, it was very fractured across multiple different things. Again, that's okay. I think it was the tail end of my experimental works with HARRY in concept (HARRY was already done, but my liking to that project and some of the others was still present), as well as the heaviness that that record has. I think Longevity was part of the movement (along with other songs) into the bigger open sound I started getting into for probably the next 6 months or however long it was. It was from Fall 2024 to probably Spring 2025, it was a big deep dive into more things of finding myself as a person too, whether intentional or not. I don't know if I can articulate it totally yet, even to myself. But I do know that something(s) changed, moved, rearranged, and repaired themselves internally. I think I have gone over some of this on the works I have released from this period thus far, I just don't want to worry about it right now while going through the music for it. It is key to the reason for why the music is the way it is. I just can't worry about that parts of it just yet, while making these complete. It gets to heavy and or complex.

This is another "in-between" project. I wanted it to be a full thing, as I always try to do. It's okay when it's not though, that's part of the fun. Part of the trip has been realizing this aspect of it, too. Crucial to the process, but maybe not a landmark to stop at. More like, you see it looking out the window as you pass by. Necessary for the journey, but not something you want to admire at. I love this record still though. There are some really great songs here, and in a way, I wish they had better production and maybe a better context within a full album. But I have learned that I can't worry about that for every single song I've made that I like. It has to be the best it can be at that time, which was possible for me to accomplish.

name: Pivotal Inclinations
description:
Hello as of August 26, 2025! This project is now released and available to the public.

This is kind of the segue and or end of the previous run of things. There is still some crossover with things like Trashmouth. There is a lot of information inside of the podcast portion of the album.

I have been sitting on some of these songs for a month or two now, I think because they have a weight that I needed to digest a bit, and to figure out what they mean to me. Trashmouth through to this project, everything is very raw. It wasn't meant to be, but it turned out that way. Whether that's how the music emotionally conveys things, what have you. I think the lack of vision for these, that's the vision, if anything. That's what it's describing, and it does it great.

I was very much going to cut Bell Dancer + Podcast and Provocative as simply demos, and just include the more straightfoward songs as the final product. But after coming back to this, I now see again how those are crucial to the point of what this project was and is, as well as what it isn't. This is another one of those projects where it is kind of aimless in a way. Trying to find something to grasp onto.

I very much like the melody that occurs later on into Provocative (9:20 onwards), if I wasn't to include the whole song, it would be that part on it's own.

I think including these things really hint to the direction of how things got to where they go later on, as we progress into writing things.

I now recall how this was when I was trying to work on these. I very much wanted to return to the loose structure of writing I employed back when I was working on things like Electro Capacitoritor, through to A Sight to Behold. It was that loose and albeit scary feeling of letting the music take you where it went.

There must be something to me and when I write and or finish albums. I am finishing this about a year later from when I made it, and seeing similar weather to how it was back then, and staying inside because of the heat, things like that, all of that, that influences how I feel about an album at a given time. So if anything, if an album needs time to digest, it probably will take a year before I am able to feel like I am able to process it correctly. It has to be long enough where I can reflect back on it objectively, not something which is still relevant to the present (wow gotta write that down; relative to the present).

So this album is almost like a goodbye for some reason, but because it will allow for new things to come. It kind of has some kind of sad feeling to it, at least for things like Provocative. I very much enjoy that song now, looking back on it. The mix was what it is though, I was still using my iPad, and just didn't know what I was doing for things like EQ.

*edit: Okay, ended up combining two "projects". This was done with ending at Provocative. I thought that they were two distinct things, when making them. But now looking at how they relate to each other (and the time period of only about 7 days or so for these songs), they are the same coin, if anything maybe different sides to it.

Provocative is the end of the first half, Logsong is the second half. Even if this is not a regularly-composed album, this is the same "thing" if you were.

Part of the divide is also the stress of moving to a newly-opening place, and that took place between the two halves. Logsong was on opening day, after the stress was relieved, the unknown closed. Time for new adventures!

Again, sorry for the squashed mix on this. Using auto-normalization (non-configurable on iOS), master bus limiting (not inherently bad, but paired with..), improper gain staging, and overdone EQ, these really did totally break the sound of the final bounces. Some songs are worse than others. I am glad I did all of that though, because it allowed me to start learning about how to do it properly, and it prompted me to get Logic Pro on my Mac. I started to see how the lack of tools was actually the hinderance. My heart of the mixes were in the right place, but I just didn't have the visibility to know what I was doing wrong (aka mixer would help a lot, to see).

I absolutely love Sound Bath. Now that I see the entire project here all put together, it is a great way to end this list of songs. I think I had started listening to more ASMR for meditation, if I remember right. Definitely for a few later on, namely Bungleow (soon to be released).

If I remember right, again, I got home from work, I was still getting used to my full hour days, two more than before. So I would come home, and just be exhausted. I'd sleep after having tried to watch YouTube videos while laying on my bed. Without fail, I'd wake up 2 or 3 hours later, and it would be dark out. One of those nights (namely, the 5th, since that's when I recorded it), I felt like I really needed to record. It was the obvious thing to go do. Just went into my recording spot, and made Sound Bath. Maybe that's why it's such a great song for me. It wasn't intentionally, it just happened, and it was all just natural. I could venture and say it was the sleep and or relaxation that made it happen, it might have been. In a way, it very accurately feels like it seems like a dream state, and maybe that's why I like it so much. It was a very awesome huge big breath of fresh air. I think that might be why the project ended after it. I did make some other demos after it, but nothing felt like it was clicking. It's like I had already decided that this run of things was over. That's when I took a little time off from music (a week I think?), then came back and started working on Moonview (also soon to be released).

Looking back to this again, I think I wanted to make something new, but I was preoccupied with the changes happening in my life (new things in the works, as mentioned around Logsong). So I gravitated back to what I knew how to do because that's what I was capable of at the time. It wasn't what I *wanted* to make, but I could, and that's what I needed.

I had a bunch of random names for songs all lined up, but I only made these few. So I didn't get to use all of them. One of the names denoting a thing I was doing at the time, it was the Monomyth-ish part at the end of "Piss". It is meant to poke fun, and a friendly nod to Monomyth, I think it is a funny pyramid pattern I came up with while on break one day. If that part was it's own song (I think I thought of the pattern before making "Piss"), it was going to be called The Baconator 5000. How do I know that? In the note, it says "(monomyth pyramid thing)". I think when I am preoccupied, nervous, or don't have things to do, I tend to make drum patterns. At least I used to do that in my downtime when I was in school. Before starting a cross country race I would start playing drums on my chest too. It's a nervous-energy kind of thing. I have this weird whistle I do sometimes too, like a passively-playful thing, which is fun to do, albeit silly and probably annoying to hear every 20 minutes when I change tasks. It's like a mental refresher or something, just to be like "hey, I'm here, silly thing in action!".

Edit same day: Listening to Volatile Temperaments, I am reminded how much I was listening to the debut Mr. Bungle at the time. It was definitely a marker of that time period for me. If anything, I absolutely love and loved finding that album. I think the depth of it was still so new for me, it almost might have paused my ability to create my own weirdness, it's like it filled the void that I usually try to do myself. I still haven't quite made an album to the extent that Bungle influenced me. I think musically I haven't made distinct connections to Bungle yet, because I haven't let things get to that extent. I very much would like to in the future at some point. It would have to include vocals though, and I haven't quite found the most simple way of managing that yet, because you'd need to be loud, weird, random, and I don't quite feel I can do that just yet with the surroundings I have. I don't have a place I can go to make crazy recordings without headphones. Or at least, I don't want to do it without having some place to do it dedicated to it. Same with metal vocals. That's why my old drive to work was awesome, plenty of time driving out there with not many people nearby, you could just totally practice growling and screaming, and it's just on the road. Can't really do that in town, I think it would be too obnoxious.

name: Volatile Temperaments
description:
Hello! This is now released as of Jul 14, 2025. Here is some more insight which follows for this release (writing first-person, but in reality, looking back on that time period that this was made in)

This was a very interesting time and series of events for me at this point. A lot of changes in progress, and on the horizon. I think it was a major turning point for me, for a lot of things. So my own sense of self was a bit confused as to who and where I was at that current moment. I felt the most clear as to where things were at, but this at times is the most confusing for me. It's when things are in the unknown that I feel the best I think. It might even be the other way around, I can't quite figure out how to explain it. A lot of changes were on the horizon for me, and I was just stepping in to get used to them. I think this very much obstructed my ability (once again) to write clearly, and this is why it's been so fractured over the last few releases. I think the hard part is that there's not really any other way to communicate this, in terms of a proper release, because it really was driven by confusion and raw feelings. It's not something with a clear goal or intent, very open and (now I can see) responsive to the state of things at hand. I think I was also once again tired of the writing I had been doing, stylistically, and I knew I wanted to change, but didn't know where to try into next. This frustration and lack of clarity (because my focus inherently needed to be applied to the new changes at hand), means that the work is unguided in what it is. Even though the goal has been to release more listenable and straightforward works, I think I once again see how I need to release these still, even if it's ugly, and feels like a bleeding blister. If that's how it was, then that's part of the entire picture. My goal has and will be to show the entire picture of things.

This is a strong release in terms of expression, but certainly not clarity. The stark contrast between something like (excuse my language) "Dumpster F**k" and "Safe Place", it's astounding (not to toot my own cheeks, if you will), but more like, how else would I even be able to compile this into a release of this extreme nature? I don't know how to yet, other than to just let it go, and let it be what it was, in it's raw form. It feels more like something to have worked through rather than to be an ultimate statement about something.

Because of this, I now see and am starting to accept the ugliness of my releases, once again. It is what it is, things are bound to be ugly. And I now see that I have to release them in their entire ugliness, and accept them for what they are, and move on from there. That's how I can allow myself to be open and available to the "complete, intentional" projects I have been hoping to work on.

I have to release this because I feel it will bother me if I don't. The projects that follow this one only make sense in response to this, and what it was bound from, and how it came about.

In the context of when I am writing this (as mentioned at the start, a year later from when these were recorded), I have started learning SO MUCH about what I have been "doing wrong" these last 4 years in terms of recording and mixing quality. It is astounding, and devastating. I had no idea about gain staging, in the sense of making sure it is not clipping or limiting at the master bus. All of my work has been doing that ever since I started. GarageBand on iOS does not make this visibly apparent, and this is very unfortunate. I also had no idea what I was doing though, so there's no question it was also user error on my part.

The last week or two I have been contemplating re-bouncing a large chunk of my catalog simply to "replace" the original masters, but now I see that this is counterintuitive to my goal here. Remember the bloody blister part from earlier? Exactly, I can't go back. I already made the mistake. I have to wear that now. The songs are already known for the way they sound, when I first released them. The damage has been done.

The hard part is that the masters sound nothing like how they did in the DAW, and I simply just didn't have the ears to notice that, somehow. Again, it's a thing to learn over time, it happens. I am just glad I noticed it now.

Long story short (theres other nuances I could cover too, but I might do a dedicated podcast about it instead), I am simply going to rebounce only certain close-to-heart releases, ones that are important to me, or ones that I feel didn't sound how they should have when I released them first. I will release them as a second album, with the suffix "(Rebalanced)". I don't know yet whether I will actually remaster it, or simply fix the limiting issues on the master bus. It's just the dynamic range of the songs that's the issue. If all of the faders were turned down to not be above -0.1db total, then we would have no issue. It audibly sounded exactly as I wanted in the DAW, while making it, I just bounced them all incorrectly. I plan to do it for ones like "so, many, bad, decisions" (ha, what a coincidence), "Carpincho", "HARRY", and maybe a few others as well. I am still deciding if I should just wait until I learn more about proper mixing and mastering, and maybe just do that in the same go for those as well. I don't want to entirely change their character though, so if anything it would just be a remaster. I still want to at least somewhat know more about what I'm doing with that though. I don't want to mess it up a second time, lol.

name: Indeterminate colon muffled conundrum
description:
Was on vacation, brought my iPad and acoustic guitar, ended up recording what would become this project. It didn't end up being too much, as much as I thought it was at the time. It was still a key part of the process though, looking back (hello, as of Aug 12, '25!). I think I might have made the art for this (as well as naming, styling, that sort of thing) a bit too 'perfected' when I released this a few weeks ago. But I think I was in the moment of doing that. This project doesn't feel exactly like the cover looks, to me. Sometimes it's messy in that regard. I think the projects from this time period were like that in general though, not really a singular point of thought like there is for some of my other projects. I am happy with the aesthetic, but this album feels much less perfected than it looks on the album art. I very much like the album art though. Much like with "Emotional Literacy", I feel the same way. The title and artwork just feel a bit off for some reason. It's like I don't quite know what these projects represent, even though I made them. It's like their unknown feels odd, a void or something.

I might just be talking, I don't know if that is the truth now, I think I am looking too deep into this. Sometimes projects just don't have much to them, it's probably just that. It's the projects that I spend more time on, that I tend to know what they are, in the grand scheme of things. That seems to be more accurate of an explanation. And plenty of times, I still and continue to release projects which don't have much initial backing, I just start making, and that ends up being the project.

I now see, that's okay when that happens. It's going to happen. It's part of the process.

I think I more connect with the mystery of this album, and I think I kind of tried to not make it that. Adding these names, this title, the artwork (in how I edited it), I once again tried to make it into something that it really wasn't. Or rather, maybe I just mistaked it for what it wasn't.

I more so connect with the demo artwork and title, albeit fairly obtuse and ridiculous. The artwork was a placeholder anyways, of me with my acoustic sitting on the couch, first person, my legs on the coffee table. The working title was "Indeterminate colon muffled conundrum".

You know what? In the spirit of making this right for myself, I have the ability to bring this back. I am going to bring back this title, and the picture. Heck to it. I like the demo artwork that's all artsy fartsy, but it doesn't work! Let's make it right.

("Old" name was The Guest Room, now back to the original, unexplanatory name, which feels more accurate to what this is, for some reason)

Edit a few minutes later:

Renamed the songs with formatting in the concept, that the ones with parenthesis didn't have names, and these are the names I "made" for them. They aren't the "names", but more like specifiers. This project feels like a void, as I mentioned. Like a place you have returned to, some kind of peace. It's not meant to be explanatory, or show something. Just a, vibe?

This project kind of feels like The Midranges to me, in where it sits with me.

Edit 8/25/25: I don't remember if I even mentioned above the origins of the title for this project. It is meant to be an exaggerated way of describing when you have to fart, but you don't know if it's poop or not. That's what it means. Just to let you know, in case you didn't get it.

name: Snake Oil
description:
This project isn't done yet. I'm actually more happy with it the more I come back to it though. Going to refine parts of it over time, even though I'm releasing it right now. It's not just to get it out right away, but moreso because I want to iterate over it easily. I guess I release my albums like I do my software, there are multiple versions of it. Think of it like a beta stage of this album. It's not totally done yet. Some of my other albums never got to a full 1.0.0 though, that's where it's unfortunate, where the idea wasn't totally there to allow it to be a 1.0.0.

I'm going to trim some songs, remix a few songs because the original exports weren't correct to how they used to sound when monitoring them in the editor, things like that. Oh, and sequencing, might change it up a little here too.

Edit May 15 '25: Okay, now I think it's essentially done! Got the track order figured out (I think it's the same as the original, it turned out; not intentional, but makes the most listening sense it seems. Still using that as my main metric for how it should sound and flow, rather than 'what period it represents' solely), adjusted the trimming of some songs (extra bloat), and omitted a few songs which just didn't quite fit, or didn't feel like they added much. Even though they were part of the process that makes this what it is, this shouldn't waiver it's strength as an album just for the sake of including those. So I'm getting better at that! It's a more cohesive statement. I am very proud of this one.

Taking more time with projects, I am starting to feel better about them again. It seems like I tend to let it rest for a bit (I think it's been about a year (already???) since I recorded this, and now I am just now finishing it), then I come back to finalize everything and look at it from a different point of view. I this this makes it easier for you to look at it as something cohesive, since otherwise you tend to be too close to it to review what it is yet.

There were many hiccups along the way, the main one being around Synergy. The original bounce was an M4A CD quality one, yet the rest of the project is 48khz 24bit. It's because exporting the project again with the synths it used, GarageBand must have changed their synth renderer implementation sometime between when I made that song, and when I went back (last October, maybe this March?) to bounce it in lossless. So they sounded drastically different, so much that it changed the entire vibe of it. I ended up "cheating" and remuxing that original M4A file, into a WAV, and upscaled it to 48k-24 afterwards. I know that doesn't raise the sound quality. I wanted the whole download to be consistent though, that is important to me. Now I see why Bounce-in-Place is a good idea for synths and mixes in general, because then they are a complete snapshot of the original, without needing the effects chain and things like that. The tradeoff is that those are no longer editable. Both have their reasons. If anything, it does make sense to try and finish figuring out all of that kind of creative stuff early on, because for me at least, I don't tend to want to change a bunch of stuff later on anyways, because then that will change what you originally wrote, which was a fingerprint of that time period to begin with. So going back with new eyes and making a bunch of creative adjustments, for me, that doesn't add up.

I am still trying to decide how I might handle remixes and remasters of my original projects, as it is in a similar vein to this concept. The bad mixes of the originals are kind of the point of what they represent. It's true that I didn't know what I was doing when I made those songs. That's why they sound like that. So of course they would sound like that.

It's another thing to just plainly do another version of an earlier song you made, I do want to try that, and I have been trying that too. It is really fun! To me, that seems more like a v2 than a v1.1 kind of thing though. It's meant to be an addition rather than a replacement.

I might do a 'best hits' kind of project down the line too, but with remixes/remasters of some of the favorite things I've made. The idea is to showcase the broadness of the things I've written over time, and with clarity from the new ears I can see with now (lol?), now that I'm getting better a mixing and mastering, and dealing with dynamics and EQ. I will wait still before doing that though, I see I have a lot more practice to do before trying that. I might 'try' it, but it won't be the definitive collection of "songs we're fond of" album thing. I want to feel more confident in my mixing before trying that officially.

This is a very solid proggy project! Seeing it now, I had really started to look into EQ and things like that, definitely by now. I don't think I was doing it really yet for HARRY/arse. I wanted to start with the result of a new album cycle, rather than changing mixing practices partway through the writing of things. I think I've done that in the past, and it kind of makes the album experience confusing, because it sounds totally different when you get to later songs in the project (Scary House for example, it changed amp styles part way through).

I'll come back another point to write about the inspiration for this album, as well as the intent behind it, and what it explains. I'll have a fresh brain to document all of that. Love this one!

Edit Jul 25 '25: Re-added ELLIPSIS to the main lineup, it really does add part of the context for how the flow/'story' is supposed to make sense.

name: arse
description:
This is the bonus extra content disc to "HARRY", out now! The second release for my main albums are where my demos go to die ðŸ˜‚

This one is chock full of insanity. Plenty of them I really liked, and really tried to keep on the album, it just wasn't working out accordingly. I was almost going to do a double-album between these two sets of songs, but I have been trying to work on making more cohesive albums at the forefront, things I'd actually like to listen to here and there myself. I can still have fun experimenting with new ideas and concepts, but it doesn't have to take away from making the main album as cool as it could be.

Some of these are actually just bonkers songs, I think "FullBore" is the craziest I've ever made. It is as big and as fast of a song I could make in GarageBand for iOS, and I exported it at the lowest setting possible, because why not. If you zoom in on the timeline with the project open, the app will crash, every single time. You will never be able to get the repetitive part out of your head, it's sure stuck in mine.

I did try to keep these all on the same album (between the now two discs), but yeah it just would've been too heavy of a listening experience. If I don't want to listen to it myself all the way through, then I imagine less other people would too. The runner ups that were almost on the main album were 1, 2, 4, 6, 7, 9, 12, 13, and 14, if I really had to trim only the other few out. But I want to try making my projects to fit onto single CDs if possible, as I've been getting into that lately, and using that as a metric for compiling my projects really helps put things into perspective for how long they are. I might make a CD for this, might not, we'll see. Elkosaurus is only 4 or 5 minutes too long, I didn't have that into perspective just yet when making that, I wanted to focus on the entirety of the project itself instead. Definitely will make one for it later on though, might remove "Wobble Fog" and "Clam Chowder" I think.

Things have been going great with life lately! Not like in a surprising way, or like a lucky way, but more like a self-acceptance/realization kind of way. I am starting to see what my goals are, what they aren't, what I can currently achieve, and where I need to go to do that. Right now, making music is my way to learning how to grow as a musician, mixing, mastering, producing, distribution (Carpincho is out on all platforms!!!!), and following my gut more closely, overthinking things less. I can still overthink things, but I can also trust my gut when the time is right. I love myself and everyone close to me, and I am working out how to conceptualize my feelings internally, and also learn how to express that with music and lyrics. Words don't have to be fact, just a way to convey how you currently feel.

Work your hardest out there, life has so much opportunity for us to grow into being the best people we can be! Heck yeah bro ðŸ‘Š

name: HARRY
description:
Yaay, this out is out!!!

Looking back a year or so later (when I am releasing this now, so March 2025), I am very proud of this one. It isn't quite as fancy as I remembered it being though, maybe just because I've been working on it a lot again though. I reminds me of a time in my life when I was feeling bummed at where I was at, and the emphasis of getting over it, and working towards being more "productive". I don't mean that in the regular sense, but more in that you can start making your own choices for what you want, trying new things, but not because you have to or are supposed to, but because it feels great to! There's nothing to be afraid of! Try out that new skill you've always wanted to look into, stop being so afraid of everything, just take a leap and get going with it. Looking at my frame of mind back at that time, and prior as well, I have struggled with standing behind things I think, because I am really good at seeing things from more than one angle, so I tend to prove myself wrong a lot, trying to find ways to counter my own opinions with a different angle. It's like I am trying to make things more stronger, but it just holds you back if you do it too much.

This album also reflects a time when I had just gotten over the fear of having a drink too, which is what the previous album was about. I learned that I can trust myself afterall, and I just have to be honest with where I am at, and take accountability for what I might be doing, not doing, things like that. Not doing that seems to be what would result in a drink or some other kind of way to let loose.

This album was initially very uninspired and kind of sad, in a somber tone. Then as I started working on it, you can hear the tone change. I really worked to emphasize this in the sequencing as well, not to be intentionally drastic, but to really convey what was going on for me internally. It's like I stopped feeling sorry for myself, and let myself free. The madness of holding yourself so tight is suffocating at times, and if people get into your internal (head) space, you have no way to keep your responses from poking and prodding at the internal self-destruct mechanism that's ticking away (in terms of sadness and emotion, not the literal sense).

This was a very awesome and needed step forward for me. It did lead forward to an also interesting path after that, to where we are now. I started to feel like I didn't have as many ideas to write about (now we're talking about after this album, yet to be released!), because I started to feel much more guided in terms of my internal compass for myself.

Now we are at a very interesting place in my writing (right now, as I am typing this), because it is much more straightforward, and experimental (compared to how I had been writing for years up to this). Now I am using Logic Pro on my Mac, I am much more interested in mixing and mastering quality, learning about cassettes, working on a multi-media live session I recorded with my guitar out in the hills on my truck, and much more free to explore things that aren't necessarily "my thing". This is very unlike me, and I am LOVING IT. I have been working to find a balance between doing *too much* new stuff, because sometimes it feels like you are compensating for something, like you are blinding yourself from just relaxing. So I have been working on that too, making sure to take care of myself on the everyday, rather than just doing things so I can prove to myself that I was "good" that day. Having a great day can be every day. It doesn't have to be every day, but you putting your best foot forward for yourself by all means will help with that to some extent. You can't control what others put on your plate, but you can choose what you can handle, and what you want to put up with. Whether that's stress, rude people on the road, or people that aren't as empathetic as you are. You don't have to be a good person to prove it to other people, just do it because it makes life easier for you, and it really does feel great. Note that it's not to compensate though, there can't be any ulterior motives, you won't gain anything from lying to yourself about your own truths. What is it you want to do? Why don't you go do it? If you don't actually want to do it, just let it go, if it is important enough to you it will have it's time and it will come back into your life one way or another. You can't do everything you aspire to do. Just choose things that you know you will be able to accomplish, to at least get off the ground walking. Then you can learn to run. Just because you can't run right off the bat doesn't mean you aren't able to. It's just not in your abilities right now. And that's okay.

Alright, love you guys, I don't know haha. Just be nice to yourself, you deserve it!

rBnaodn

P.S. Don't worry about how bad your mixes are from a year prior, just like things coming back into your life again later: If that song is important enough to you, it will surface again in your mind when you think it's worthwhile to do it again. It's okay if the initial version is ðŸ’©

name: Progscapes
description:
The name and artwork haven't been fully completed yet, so the demo name and a picture of me with Hevy Devy will be a nice holdover in the meantime! I've had this all line up and ready for release for about a month or two, just waiting on that final packaging things, I still don't quite know how to describe the work itself, other than it's intent. Thinking of calling it "Expanses", it was the word that came to mind when listening to Landslide.

Okay, onto the original description:

The process around this album was actually fraught with a difficult set of things to overcome.

Sobriety has been a keen part of the household while growing up, and adjusting my perspective to turning 21 around that was the struggle at hand. Should I try drinking? What if it results in my own loss of control as well? This premise was really nagging at me, and my birthday was coming up just after I decided to end this album.

This ended up going from a kind of uninspired, goofy project, into what was a feeling of possibly losing control and or losing what I thought to know myself as, and my response towards dealing with that. I did end up trying a drink on and around my birthday, and as we had been discussing at home, it's not like the world was going to end.

I think the inability to "control" where you go next in regards to what comes along with your age going up is what I was learning to deal with. I had dealt with this kind of concept before, and it was coming up again here. Turning 18 was another challenging one, because I didn't "feel like an adult". Or rather, it was like imposter syndrome. Looking younger than I am is part of my self challenge as well, so that was part of the issue. I think it might stem from me being smaller than kids in my grade when I was younger, that's just an observation though, I haven't thought about that until now, as of writing this.

This also stems into my challenge with the drinking dilemma, as I felt uncomfortable appearing younger than I am, while drinking, because people would assume that I am doing wrong while it was actually fine, since I am of age.

Part of the worry of mine was also being unsure how I may respond to such "freedom" per se. What if I started to slip on the things that made me me, like being truthful, and or not being healthy towards myself emotionally and physically? Would I be able to uphold the morals that made me being so proud to follow in the sober footsteps throughout my teenage years, even while allowing myself to drink?

I would overthink this and it was just nagging at me until the time came to pass. I am very glad to say on the other side of this, that things are okay, and I now understand that I can trust myself and uphold the values I have grown up with, while now having more things at my disposal which have the possibility to reverse that.

I had started feeling like I was going to push through this, and I began running a good deal more in the early winter months when this started building up, so part of the atmosphere for this album also reminds me of being out in the hills with the cooler air, really just working hard and running.

After trying to sequence this album like I've been doing lately, to make more cohesive projects, I just couldn't quite find the best way to sort it with it conveying the same intent that I've described here. The progression for this work around myself was messy, and trying to describe it in terms of a cohesive album just didn't make sense when I realized what this album was composed from, and what part of me it represents. It was a messy process to get here, and it didn't have a clear vision in terms of the sound or what I wanted from it. I was just working with trying to sound better at what I wanted to make, and trying to pull it off better. The vision itself didn't make itself apparent until after the fact to where I am now (Oct 28, 2024 as of writing this), and now it makes more sense what this is.

Near the end of the album, I think I wrote "No" and "The Winds of Change" specifically about this situation, to where I was saying "NO" to what I felt like I might become if I let go and follow in what I possibly *could* become. So "No" is about saying NO to how you feel, like in term of the worrying and skepticism, then letting go and having things take their course. Trust your intuition in that you will keep yourself safe, and you know when you are crossing a line into something that will hurt you. "The Winds of Change" kind of felt like a cliffhanger in terms of the album and to where it might lead next for the next project (I didn't know what was next, both in music and my life and my personality), so it was like closing the lid of a book in the meantime, meant to be opened again when you are ready to write the next page.

Another factor in the difficulties of deciding what to do was also that I felt if I decided to drink, that "I would be letting my knowledge of sobriety down by giving in to the drink". Along a similar overthink trajectory to how I tend to go when I try to deal with things, I started to conceptualize whether someone could be definitively an alcoholic, without having had a drink before. It's these kinds of things that I start to gravitate towards, which will lead me to decide what I will go with next, and I have to choose whether I think my realizations make any sense, have any truth to them, or if I'm just trying to think my way out of a situation. Also unrealistically, I was concerned about whether I'd be letting my family down by "giving in", and that my sobriety through childhood would be lost if I chose to go through with it.

I was also up to having just figured out how I might deal with this scenario, and one of the resolutions I came down to deciding it with, was that should I just "ignore" the concerns, and instead stay sober, not dealing with testing the waters to see what happens if I were to try drinking. The other option I went with, was to just take the leap, and just see what happens. I might as well try it now, it's okay, I have close people around me that will be able to help me get through deciding what to go next in that regard. If I had stayed completely sober, through my birthday, and to however long into the future, my other concern was that my curiosity might build to a point where it *would* turn into a problem, and I might just break, and what if I went haywire, and it turned into a big problem? I don't recall having a scenario like that before in my life, but it's still one of the overthought cases that I didn't want to have the possibility of, I'd rather know it up front and deal with it now, rather than being a "SchrÃ¶dinger's alcoholic", for lack of better words.

I think things went much better than it seemed like I was worrying about, I learned to let go of these concerns, and to just handle what happened as it comes. Allowing myself to grow into the things that come with growing up isn't a bad thing, and there is still room to try new things even while it might feel like you are leaving behind parts of what you've known to grow up with. It's actually the opposite I've found out, because I've instead turned that energy into being more self-improving, rather than concerns over drinking. My current view is that the best way I can keep it from being a problem, is to where I can keep working on myself as a person, to where it will most hopefully prevent the drink from becoming a problem. The drink is the way to cope with the issues you haven't yet handled, so the precursors are the things you haven't worked through yet. Drinking is okay in the current realm of things for me, I just have to ensure that it isn't something I use to cope with, and for it to stay specifically as a recreational here-and-there kind of thing.

Self-improvement â¤ï¸

Edit: After looking though pictures and other media from this time period, while trying to think of the album name and artwork, I also realized the other side to this coin of this period. It was also a big reflection that I felt like I was worried about becoming stagnant in life, and that I wanted some kind of change, and to try new things. I think that's part of why the songs took a new turn, being shorter than they have been in the past. Rather than going all-out on going with what I thought was neat, I really wanted to try making something more concise, and each of the songs seemed to follow that trend for a bit. So with the struggles of dealing with people you love starting to age, I felt like I had to start making more big leaps, because life didn't seem as big as it was before, and I had to broaden my horizons, like trying to apply to job interviews I had been meaning to, run more often, try not to eat as crazy as I had. Foreshadowing down the road, it's hard to do this kind of things as well though, and even while expecting things not to always go your way, I also later learned the disenchantment that you can't just "work hard" to get through something, sometimes it plain just doesn't work out, and you still have to keep going, even if you think your abilities will get you though. Sometimes you just aren't enough, and now I've learned that that's okay. Getting to that understanding though is challenging, and I still haven't fully accepted that internally, I work on reiterating it to myself though, as that is the most important part. This very big positive push from myself then was hit on the head with the self-confrontation of deciding what to do with being 21, which I covered above. So that duality was what this time period was about. Trying to be good at moving forward, which inherently means you run into roadblocks you left behind, and now you have to deal with again. I wouldn't have had to deal with turning 21 previously, but the concept of it had been such a distant thing to decide what to handle it like, that I didn't choose to face it until I was there.

name: The Reaction Factor
description:
I'm not sure how I categorize this one yet, it started out as turning a new leaf, making something more listenable and tangible
But then going back and figuring out which songs I wanted to use for it, it kind of goes into two separate concepts, it's still like a spacey curious album, but hints of tongue-in-cheek goofiness, and heaviness
The underground concept of the album seems to go with that in mind as well, the main song for me is "Scopes", it is what the artwork was meant to represent
It seems like the album as a whole kind of lines up with it too, which is interesting
It's like there's a disparity between a nice and tidy inside, safe world, then the outside of that protective wall, it's the unknown dangers of the unexpected
And I think it might have been one of the metaphors I was wondering about at the time, and it unintentionally came into the music
Do you choose to live your life in the safe, assured place? Or do you live on the outside, where things aren't assured or known?
Both have their merits, and it seems like it wouldn't be viable to go with solely one or the other, and it's up to you to decide when it's time to go one way or another

name: duds
description:
"Derivative, out of ideas, unguided, and frustrated about that"

Listening back to this one though, I actually kind of like what it conveys, it's like an accidental concept project. There's a few recurring themes throughout, and I think it really was accidental, just because I wasn't sure what to write really. I didn't have a sound planned ahead for this one, and I had wanted to make another new solid album, when working on Carpincho. I think I was bummed that it didn't end up being that, and I think I was plainly just burnt out on ideas by then. I had been writing a whole ton for probably about half a year or so.

I had just found "The Mistakes", if I'm not mistaken, so the silliness around that was stuck in my head still as well. I think looking back now, I think a lot of what you write is based on what you've been listening to. It's like being an athlete, if you don't eat good food, you aren't going to perform well. Not to say that "The Mistakes" aren't great (I absolutely love it!), I think it's more where you energy is going, is the point of it. I think something like that album is very self-indulgent, and that's where a lot of my music seems to trend towards.

Before this project I took a little break, reluctantly, because I was bummed that I wasn't writing what I wanted. Then after this, I took a healthy break, and came back and worked on "The Reaction Factor". I think with that, I try to work on something that people might be wanting to respond to, rather than just trying to amuse myself with my music. It's not about catering to other people instead, but to not be so selfish with your own writing prospects. I think just having other listeners in the back of your mind for the sake of it, helps sometimes. It helps you not cut as many corners, and to just start caring again.

Been listening to the Devin Townsend Podcast / PowerNerd updates, and it's been very helpful! Learning a lot from his insights and outlooks. It helps to be able to relate on certain similar struggles in that way. I think just with the resetting of your mind every once in a while helps move things along. And it's important not to force that, but to know when it's not time, and when it's time. For me, uploading these is an example of that. I've been trending towards being out of ideas for my current sessions since February, and I'm reminding myself it's okay to be out of ideas again, that was a great long set of sessions (100+ songs to work with!), and now it's time for one of those healthy breaks. Another time will come when your creative insights will be recharged and ready for something new. Forcing it out will sound like Carpincho and this album. While I do like both of them, they kind of make me feel bad because of that, I wanted them to be something that they weren't, and that's where I am learning to change things. Looking at this one, I like it better, because while writing this one, I was okay with just tossing it aside, just to let it be one to help me move fowards, rather than having another great project. And I think learning that attitude (looking back), and the actual sound itself, it's kind of a nice summary for the last few projects in 2023.

This isn't my best album, that's not why I decide to share it in the end. It's another example of one that helps me get to the next one, which I am working to remember, they aren't all gonna be great! Hence, I think that's why I had the working name 'duds', and that seems like a great way to sum it up, as the full name itself :)

name: Carpincho
description:
Coming back to this album again, I think it is still a surprise to me even though I made it. It has gone through a bunch of ups and downs, but I think it taught me so much along the way.

Initially, I had plans for a big huge CF of chaos, and I was excited to make that. During the writing process for it, I ended up starting to feel burnt out on ideas though, and that really started to frustrate me, because I had the drive of making something great, but it just wasn't coming out like I thought of it in my head.

"Lucky Rock" and "Uke on a Uke" were both recorded on the same day I think, and they turned out exactly how I could have wanted, and better honestly! Looking back now of course I think they have much to improve on for various things, but for where I was when I made this, it was the most accurate depiction of what I wanted to do.

So when I went to record more material after those two, I just started feeling let down that I wasn't able to write to the caliber of those. I kind of started feeling a bit lost in my music writing abilities, and whether I was actually doing anything productive with it. Just one of those snowball effect moments of having the Imposter Syndrome (funnily enough, that's mentioned in the demo song "ÃŸuÃŸ". I might have been self-observant of where I was back then, and I just wasn't ready for it).

This is September 4th, 2024 as of writing this, so this album has been 'complete' per se for about nearly a year now. I think the roots that this album is grounded in were likely my own perceptions of myself back then, and how I was starting to get out of it, bit by bit. Hence similar names of "Catastrophic Failure as a Human Being" (gosh, that's a bit much don't you think?), I think my move forward in confidence to make things also came with a much greater imposter thing, or something like that. It might have just been tied into not feeling like I was doing enough either, or just being insecure about my accomplishments.

Starting with following records later, into the new year, I worked on taking the approach of being more hands-off with things, and just letting the music speak for itself, and not have to be tied to my success as a person. Just because I made a crappy song (or a freaking BOATLOAD ðŸ˜‚), that doesn't mean that I'm a lousy person. Same with moving forward with life goals. It just means that you are now more observant of how you need to move forward, and you are aware of what direction you would rather be heading towards, and (hopefully) how to get there, bit by bit.

So the new consensus of this record for me, it's exactly what needed to come from that time period, to get me out of that funk, specifically by getting me in that funk altogether. Maybe it's not even this record itself that I was focusing on. More likely, this record is the representation of whatever thing I was getting through at the time, and that's what was nagging at me. I've been learning that from Devin Townsend's podcasts, which have been completely great! The music you write is how you self-reflect your feelings of things in the current moment.

I still love making ass songs, I think it's comical and funny to do things that catch you off guard. I think I just didn't know that it was this record I was making, and hence it also caught me off guard, meaning it really is hella legit (lol who says that anymore). So it was so out there that it even caught me off guard, the author/artist.

So what I've learned to try is to make the thing I'm making, to the best of my ability, regardless of what it was I intended it to be in the first place. Don't take yourself or your success/goals/failures too seriously either, just try to move forward and learn how you can improve next time.

Not sure if anyone else would actually want it (merch), but I think I'm going to make a single standalone t-shirt with this album's themes on it, it sounds perfectiously cheeky to where my own t-shirt of my own album to concerts, and the album isn't even that good ðŸ˜‚

Maybe the artwork is what's turning around for this one for me, too, that turned out outstandingly to me, better than I could have thought it to describe the sound of this one.

I feel like I could keep talking about music, and the process for even longer, so I'll have to wrap it up. Keep working to being sincere and honest with yourself, you know the answers to your own problems, you just have to let yourself believe you know the answer when you do.

Edit Feb 23 2025: As of yesterday, I submitted this to CDBaby, and now the main 3 songs of the album should soon be available on all major streaming platforms! This is a big step forwards for me. It's not in terms of the album or music itself, completely. It's my own realization that I don't need to be doing this for the sake of sharing it to people, or getting their approval. I am doing it because I want to learn how to do this kind of thing, and I am now conceptualizing the idea behind learning how to make "nice to listen to" music. It's not because I want to cater to getting popular, or making things that people want to hear, but because I want to learn about what makes it nice, and that kind of thing is an interest to me now. I've been picking up some more "streamlined" releases lately, and I am really admiring the 'less is more' kind of sound that they have. It's not that they are doing that on purpose, but because that's their honest sound. I really admire that. I think I had misunderstood certain song sounds and styles for this reason, because I misinterpreted how the music was meant to be enjoyed, and what it meant to the artist in terms of why they made it, and what it does for them.

So for me, this is a stepping stone in allowing myself to experience more "normal" things in life, not because I want to do it to appease others or to get their approval, but because it's okay for me to do that, and it's starting to feel natural for me to do that. What has to be wrong with allowing oneself to not be so contrarian all the time? That's been my thing for a long time now, maybe even since I was little. I'm really curious what that stems from. I'm now learning how this doesn't have to be the root of everything, anymore. I still very much value this take for oneself, but now I am starting to see how living a multi-faceted life is very awesome, because things **really don't** have to be so black and white. I can like crazy music, and calm relaxing music, heck, even pop music. It's only a matter of exposure and understanding. The only reason you are the way you are, is because you decide to be like that, don't know any better, or aren't comfortable giving it up for something new. The only way to grow is to let something go. I don't know if that statement is really that black and white, as always it's more nuanced than that. But the concept still stands, I can be okay with letting things go, trying new things, that's what this is all for anyways right? I'm learning that my own (self-limiting) boundaries are only there because of my insecurities, and or things I don't know enough about to make decisions based on. So I have the ability to overcome that, it just comes down to whether I am able to or not, and now I think I am working towards expanding out a bit more.

Cassette-related content will be on the way soon, get ready for some cool stuff! Ordered it in the mail, let's see what happens.

name: Colloquial Outtakes
description: This is the collection of other tracks from the "so, many, bad, decisions" sessions, which didn't make it to the main album, or felt too big to include in it. There are a bunch of concepts and ideas I really like with these, I just didn't want to bloat up the general idea with the main album to include them. There's a lot more ambient jams that I didn't realize I was writing over time. I think those didn't feel like they fit into the concept of the main album. I seem to end up exploring that later on in the projects coming up next.

name: Catastrophic Failure as a Human Being
description:
Still partially finishing up this project, releasing it as I work on it, still trying to figure out the final songs and play order. This one is very long, so I'm trying to make sure it's right.

Edit February 2025: Wow, am totally realizing why this album was a total CF for me, as well as the previous ones to this. By having not kept track of the order I wrote the songs in (intentionally), this completely destroyed my way of understanding the intent of what the songs were meant to convey, and how they were to align with the neighboring songs in the project. Realized a little bit ago (I think last month?) that the contents inside of a GarageBand project don't change their dates, only the containing folder does when you re-save the project. So by opening the 'package' on macOS (I only would have discovered this from having been done trying to make this work on my iPad, where this isn't user-accessible), I can see the actual/original write dates to the individual audio tracks within the songs. This makes it possible to re-discover the ordering of the tracks, because the metadata was never lost all along! This is mindblowingly great news, as it also applies to my demos from a long time ago, back on my first phone. Again, when you open a project on iOS, it modifies what is shown to the user to be the current date, so if you didn't keep track of it beforehand yourself, it would have seemed like you lost it forever. This is not the case though, at least with my files it seems.

With this new track ordering information/intent back in knowledge, I think I can re-build the ordering for this album, and make it not such a complete disaster to how I felt it was. There's a lot of great things here, I just had no concept of understanding how it all originally felt together. Duly noted, not going to remove the ordering of things anymore, I will only do that after the fact, intentionally. I guess it depends how you write your songs though. Usually how I write the next song depends on how I felt the previous one came out. It's like an `async function* writeSong() {}`.

I still need to properly go over the intent with this and the previous albums, with what went right, unexpected, and what I learned from it, what I changed afterwards, all that good stuff. Analyzing your past progress is so helpful! I don't want to get stuck in that though, I have now learned that that can also hinder your movement forwards :)

name: Orange paradox
description:
This one is an interesting thing for me as well. I think it might be one of my most messy albums unintentionally as of the ones I've made so far.

I wasn't completely sure what the goal for this one was, and I think that showed. I didn't know where I was going next in terms of my writing. I think it's one of the low points of mine, in a good amount of areas. It's not fully something I like to listen to, other than a few parts, but I think that's also what I like about it. The fact it was not what I hoped it would turn out to be is also what led me forward in projects to follow onwards.

So yet again, as mentioned somewhere in the album itself, as well as the nature of the whole album, this is yet another paradox. Had this album been what I wanted to make, I would be happy with it. But then I wouldn't have moved onto new sounds, ideas, and concepts that I tried out later on.

The name itself came about randomly if I remember right, it was another one of those random things I came up with, and it somehow also ended up being the perfect way to describe the album and what it means to me.

I actually do like the creativity behind "Sizzelippe", and "Horse Scream (Ice Cream)". Both of which were made on the Mojave Trail, as well as all of the others, except the title track, "Toe Funk", and "Tumbleweed Scandal", which were recorded at home.

I think I also partially knew I had to have a stopgap project to figure things out. My writing and ideas were still a bit messy from "Sienna", and I still liked the absurdity from "You Singleton!!!". Honestly, I still really like that song hahaha (Hi! From Dec. 26, 2023). I think I managed to blend that one back into my songs again later on, which I think moved to a heavier sound in some aspects.

Like most of my projects still, I hold the bad parts near and dear to my heart still I think, and leaving behind the whole picture feels like a disservice to the point of what I'm doing here, so that's why I still finish these ones out. I'm not sure what I'm doing here, and I don't really get my goal completely, but not including them also feels wrong. Yet another paradox, look at that!

"Horse Scream (Ice Cream)" was another step forward for me, even for a silly song like that. I think it was the sonic quality of it. It started with the synth parts on my phone, then when I was back at home and could record with the song, I added the guitars in hopes of making the song "worse-ish", by making it unexpectedly heavy, since it didn't sound like it needed to be initially. I thought that contrast was funnily cool. Having experimented a little more on double-tracking with that, and some more panning/improved mixing, I really liked how much more filled-out it sounded, and I think that concept moved forward in inspiration for writing future songs, which is something I really do try and handle properly for more fleshed-out feeling songs. If I think a song is going somewhere, now I have been trying expand it with a little more wind in it's sails, make it something broader to listen to. I had done this with previous songs in the past as well, but not so as much with the more improvised works. Usually it was something shorter and riff-based. I realized I should try to do this with my longer songs as well, and to not have only a few single tracks for the final thing. Just having a better fleshed out mix and panning can do wonders to a song when it's only in the "potential" stage.

After having written the title song, I wasn't sure it was anything meaningful. Listening to it again now while writing this, it does point to the future a little bit, as well as back to the past in some spots.

I think while I don't fully like this project in a few different ways, I really found what I wanted to do next from it, because it showed me what I didn't like what I was doing. It's like how learning to do things the wrong way teaches you to do things the right way, that's an example of this lol.

Sure a fun journey!

I guess another thing I can mention is I think this was partially inspired by the craziness from Mike Keneally's work, but I feel like I didn't do it justice. I'm not sure. His goes all kind of different places, but you can tell of his confidence and charisma in making it. For this one, I don't think I was fully committed to the sound, or rather I wasn't sure if it was what I was going for.

So maybe it's not the work itself I'm criticizing here, but rather my own reflection of whether I felt confident in what I was making. It's a combination of that, as well as knowing what you wanted to make. It's the ability to make the work you do make, and to be able to stand behind it and say it's yours, and not be afraid of it. It also spurs down to my early projects like Elkosaurus where I intentionally wanted it to be bad. I think I wasn't confident in making something to my 100% at the time, so I didn't feel ready in being able to pull that off. I'm really glad that project happened as well, because I learned that not everything has to be perfect and just right. I think that's also part of why I didn't want to try my "100%" at a project, because I was going to work it to death in making it perfect, and I didn't yet know how to "just let things go". So I'm glad that I stepped over that boundary, because it has allowed me to do so much over the last few years (2 years now???).

I think this also comes back around to this project. I had become so used to accepting anything came my way in terms of quality and sound of my creativity, that I was starting to feel sick of hearing the "garbage" parts being left in. For the next project after this one, I wanted to continue writing a lot, but to allow me to have a much larger queue of great songs to choose from. I didn't want to keep the bad ones if they were just "alright". Throw out some of that picture of the whole thing, it's ok! Rather than having 3 albums/EPs with marginal songs mixed in with some gems, why not just work on the concept for a bit longer, and only keep the songs you really love? That's what I'm looking forward to show you over the next remaining projects from this year. I am actually looking forward to listening to those normally in the car!

Lots to say for this one, I can probably keep going. Gotta post this so I can move onto the next one though! My goal last year was to hopefully finish and upload all of my music up to what I had been writing, I'm almost there! These final projects are much bigger than this and the ones before it, so I think I am proud to say I moved a heck of a lot forward on that. It's okay if these last few go over after New Years, because I would rather ensure they are the great albums I hope they can be (hence recording more songs to pick better ones from), than to have it up in time, for the sake of completing my "resolution". I mainly had the resolution to get started on this anyways, since it was getting heavily worse with each new album I did. Adding more music to work on over time was getting both stressful to keep track of, as well as it being something I needed to come back and recount later. Going into 2024, I will be caught up on all of my projects again, since about 2020-21.
