I plan on releasing things in a timely fashion in relation to when I actually complete them, one at a time like a sane person would likely do. I will like to keep trying to make as many as I need to (need? this is a great outlet for me!) throughout the year, so I don't plan on trying to slow down on the concepts and releases or anything, but rather to complete and properly release things as they are finished, than leaving it to be handled by future me later. After these are all caught up, it may be fun to draw a chart of how messy this whole shebang was, to see where the projects were released in contrast to when they were made and or completed.

For reference, just last year, I was finishing up "Corruption Junction". That makes this the *20th* thing I've released/completed this year. I don't like number things like that, I'm not looking for a status with that. It's more a metric for myself to remind me to chillax a bit, because that's just ridiculous. I stress out about things being one way or another, I work on reminding myself it's alright.

name: Sienna
description:
This one was a bit of a mess honestly. I think I tried to let loose a bit again with this one, trying to make new kinds of sounds. Some parts really shine through, and I really like them. But others are just a bit sloppy I think. I kind of had a love-hate for this one, because when I started working on it, I wanted it to be a nice and clean album, but it's actually really gritty and dirty I think haha. But looking back on it as I post it, I think it's actually a very solid set of songs.

'Frogdad' wasn't going to be as experimental initially, it kind of just evolved into that. I think that kind of disappointed me initially once I finished it, because I thought I had taken the 'easy road' out again, by just goofing off rather than trying to make something tangibly nice. I think that's part of my love-hate relationship with my goofy sound, having made a lot more music since starting it. Now I think I know how to accept it, I just have to do it in combination with other songs with a more conceptual take. This album actually does that really well, thanks to songs like 'Carnigee MelloÌn', 'Spaghetti Nightmare' to some extent (it's a bit wild in some ways too hehe, I think it's a nice cross between the two, in a single song), and 'Fading Off Into Silence'. The last two songs were really one, and I had already planned on having them be two sections. Bandcamp didn't let that big of a single song to upload, so I ended up properly making them into two, rather than having a double-name. 'You Singleton!!!' is absolutely one of my favorites, that turned out miles better than I intended. I think I like what's going on there. I come back again to expand on that concept in future projects up. 'Loveland' turned out nice, but I was hoping it would've been more than it was. I think I didn't quite know the plan for that one when I made it, so it was a bit messy unintentionally, and I think that's what bugs me. I wish 'Trailerpark Lingerie' was a bit more also, the concept for that one was good haha. I wanted to make just a revolting song, hence the name. I didn't really know how to expand on it, I may come back to it again later on to finish that concept out. I think it relates to the absurdity of 'Farm Animal Gore' and songs like that, where they are essentially just meant to be putrid in nature. Oh yeah, and I know how lingerie is pronounced, but I kind of internally pronounce it 'linguree' just for the sake of it. Oh yeah and 'Carnigee MelloÌn' is another one of my broken analogies of some sort. Same with 'Frogdad' and 'Spaghetti Nightmare'. 'Ghost's Revival' is a reference to what I thought Opeth's Ghost Reveries was called. I think I had just found and been listening to Blackwater Park around this album and the previous one.

There were also a few other entertaining demos from these sessions, but the small bits that I do like aren't worth adding another 10 or 20 minutes of fluff just to get to those parts. I'm trying to limit the amount of fluff I keep through to the final result of my projects. It's still happening a bit for me I think, it just depends on the nature of the project I feel. If there's a concept I like, even if I didn't execute it fully, I'll usually try to keep it around if it isn't too burdensome to the listening experience. I had a few of those which I feel I should have probably trimmed out from projects like 'A Sight to Behold' and 'Scary House', which I think could've been much shorter and more streamlined without those in there. But since it was getting time-wise further away from when I actually made the project, I didn't want to filter everything out that made the project what it was. That's less of a problem as I finally catch up on my music, because I am trying to plan for not including fluff from the start, and I am getting a better idea as to what might be fluff before recording it. Or rather, if it isn't going anywhere, then I don't want to keep it around, even if it might be a good concept. I'm trying to focus on execution and completeness going forward. I also started (in projects coming up) just trying to make more, hence allowing me to drop more cruft, and have a bigger collection of better things, so it can still be a big project, but not have filler for the sake of it. I try to notice if it's a song I just want to skip. If it is, then it probably shouldn't be included in the final project.

name: Sponge, Assert, Expunge
description:
This one was a fun mix of songs, maybe almost a little too much. It also felt less unguided, similar to the last two projects. I wanted to improve my writing practices/creative decisions quality, but there wasn't a specific direction for the album. I think that sometimes can make things a challenge, when you want something new, but you aren't (initially) happy with what you've done. Coming back to it later, these songs are a continued step up in focus compared to my previous projects I think, and I'm really happy with that. It's okay that I wasn't completely sold on it at first, or that it didn't have an initial plan to start things off, sometimes that's exactly what you need. I ran into this again about a month ago (this is Nov. 2023 me writing here), and that let me start working on this 'The Reaction Factor' project, which I didn't have a direct plan for initially. So that break in a creative vision helped me try something new!

Coming back to these songs, I also find how much they really do mean to me, no matter how strong or not they are on their own. They really communicate things I don't know how to show, and they also greatly sum up my challenges and emotions throughout time as I go. I think if you can do that with music, then it really is working. The fact that I've done these makes me really happy, this is so much to get done, it's kind of crazy. Anyone can make songs like these, but they haven't, so that's saying something. <- someone has said this and I'm quoting them, I can't remember who it was unfortunately.

The name of this project was actually planned though. It was after the song itself (I'm not sure whether the rest of the songs work towards the meaning specifically though). But the concept is that I throughout my life's experiences, I sponge up information and learn things along the way. Be it, emotions, learning from misunderstandings, new skills, challenging situations or decisions, what have you. Then I write a project to represent that (assert it, 'speak' it), and somehow it conveys those things and gets them out of my system. Then I can expunge them from my backpack of things to deal with.

This seems to be very similar of a path that Devin Townsend takes with what his music means to him. It's actually mindblowing to me that I discovered this kind of way to deal with things, and then I later discovered Devin and his music after that. So I hadn't learned that from him, I hadn't dived into his work yet. I first *heard about* him around the time of working on 'Transcend', on a trip to Mammoth, but I didn't look into him yet. It's almost like finding him wasn't supposed to happen yet, because I needed to figure it out on my own first. Then his music has absolutely clicked for me the last few months, crazy how that works out. Weird things like that seem to happen without you knowing, it's funny when it happens when you keep your eye out for it. I don't know if it means anything, but it is a bit conspicuous for life to provide that to you, it is amazing.

name: Nosebleed
description:
This is going great! I'm very relieved to be finally working on projects of mine from within the same year I made them. This one was also from the start of the year, around my birthday (two of the songs were made at the desert, 'Over the Ridge' was specifically on my birthday). I had a little idea that I mostly just tried on this album. The concept was to try making songs with non-instrumental things out in the world, and making music from them. It went interesting for sure, and it was a fun idea. I want to continue to expand on it, I think I just need to choose better sound sources. I really like how 'Sandy Suskatoon' turned out. We were walking around exploring some things around camp, and found an abandoned bunker thing, which had lots of old things there, I think people just left it there over time to kind of mess up the place. Kind of unfortunate and rude since it's just in the middle of the desert, but it looks cool so eeh haha. There was an old rusty metal spring mattress, and some sticks from a bush I found. That's what I was playing 'Sandy Suskatoon' on, it actually sounded really neat. 'Over the Ridge' was a stick too I think, on a metal post next to a dropdown in the canal. It didn't audibly sound that good to me, coming back to listen to that one, but it's key to the point of the project, and it sets the vibe accordingly, so I think it's a keeper. This was kind of an in-between projects project, and it was meant to be lighthearted and just a little simple. I think it works well for that.

The heavier songs were recorded just before the trip, as well as 'ROOOOaggh'. I was continuing to experiment on yet again more properly working on making a song-song, one that's memorable, and that actually sounds nice. I think my favorite is probably 'Pizza Carl'. I didn't want to push these smaller changes of ideas into the next new project just because this was small, I wanted that next one to have it's own feel, whenever it were to start fleshing out. That's part of what I've been learning with this. Sometimes your writing comes in waves. Posting these last three or four projects the last few days has come out of not having written too much the last few days, this is my choice instead of writing something new.

I also want to (realistically, it's ok if I don't fully complete everything) continue with the goal of maybe getting all of my projects up before the end of the year. That was my goal at the start of the new year, at least a glimmer of a thought. At that point, I didn't even have Bandcamp set up yet! So the mark of putting this project up, is where I was at the beginning of the year, when I made my Bandcamp at the first place. So, in Feburary, this was my newest project, and I was just posting 'Flatlands' on Bandcamp I'm pretty sure. It's hard to keep track of the timelines, since things are behind still. Looking through the pictures and screenshots on my phone, it I was working on 'Centerland' when I was posting 'Elkosaurus' to Bandcamp. So yeah, that's how that lines up.

I think my writing has definitely started to progress this year, I'm really happy I've continued just pumping out all of these projects. After these next few smaller ones, I have two more extra big ones (like 40 or 50 song ones ðŸ¤¯), then I'm at what I've been writing the last few weeks lately. So I'm almost there! It's mid November too, so I have more time than I think. Not to say it's a lot, but it's not down to an unrealistic timeframe to be able to complete it. That's why I'm kind of pushing myself to get it out.

I think my goal for 2024 will likely be to release projects that I'm actively working on, to not be behind on it anymore. I think that will be another driving factor as to help bring the quality assurance and second-takes up a bit more. I will be more okay with taking time on things like album art and improved mixing because I don't need to catch up on getting things released. I still want to go back and make the best album art for the last 6 projects or so, they aren't completely done I feel. I really like how ones like 'Streetlight' and 'Elkosaurus' turned out. I think 'Elkosaurus' took the most time out of all of the album art, and 'Streetlight' actually didn't take too long. I think the instinct came really fast for how that one should look. I really like 'Emotional Literacy', I almost feel like the art looks too good to represent the music of the actual project haha.

Wow this went way too long.

One more thing I forgot to mention, the desert spot is actually not very far away from the cover art for Mike Keneally and Marco Minnemann's 'Evidence of Humanity' album, pretty neat. We didn't specifically go to where the people live out there, it's just that it's the same desert in general.

name: Centerland
description:
I think I've kind of forgotten how much this album was a big step forward for me, I think it really bring up the quality of things a bit compared to previous projects. This is the first time in all of my projects where I didn't keep track of the order I wrote the songs in, since I have always up until this point ordered the tracks on the albums as they happened when writing them. So this is the first time I made a purposeful run list as to what I think sounds good together. That was a new thing, and as well as the goal of the project to be on making something more streamlined/listenable. I think it still has my style all over it, maybe just a bit less of the weird/abstract parts. It still goes in a lot of different directions across the duration of the album, but I think it was purposefully a bit more contained this time. I'm really happy with how this turned out, as sometimes when I try to go for a specific goal, I end up veering of course, and it turns into something a bit less streamlined.

Things are still a little rough in that I don't really go back and perfect things later, like quantizing, or second takes for instruments, things like that. I still have liked that raw sound. As of writing this (Nov. 2023), I'm trying to work on those things a bit more, but this project wasn't too much with a concern for that yet still. The goal was instead for improving the listenability of the writing, to where it's something a bit better as to what you can follow.

name: Ooble? Yeah!
description:
The artwork for this is so bad I may have to keep it just because of that. I made it in like 5 minutes, and it was a goofy picture I took around the time I recorded this one.

This song was a one-off in addition with a few others, which was between the album cycles of the previous project, and the next one, which this one felt like it should be it's own thing. I didn't know what direction the next album was going to go in, so I didn't want to group this one with that once I started to work on it. I really like the quality of it, considering how quickly it came together, and since it's a little shorter of a song.

I think it felt like a new direction also because I didn't want to go with the all-in impromptu nature of the previous album, so I tried going for a (still) improvised sound and style, but with more of a goal of making it song-oriented, something that's less consuming to listen to. Sometimes some of my songs/projects are very big, in a sense, and they are very abstract. The nature of their incompleteness is almost like the feature of what it represents. From this time and onwards, I wanted to continue to try making more listenable songs, something that you might like to listen to again, rather than it being something of a musical challenge. I guess I was doing that with Lordsmith and a few of the other previous works, but I think I kind of felt like I went back to the abstract writing with Emotional Literacy. One example being that the concept for that album was intentionally to write an album all in one setting. It was less about the art first, and more about the exercise it seemed like. The sounds and ideas on that album I really like, but it kind of runs out of depth in some spots I think.

name: Streetlight
description:
Lol I've been putting no time into good album art recently.
This was the picture I took [for the artwork] which had the vibe for the title song of the album, and I recorded the song after seeing the lone streetlight out there in the distance.
It was a feeling I had coming home from work late at night, which I then tried writing a song for.

name: A Sight to Behold
description:
Ok it's getting a lot easier to release these later albums, most of the songs were already leveled and everything, aaah! Not quite sure if it's the final artwork yet. I'm also not sure about the selected tracks yet, but I'm gonna try all of them because why not. Some of them make the length of the album a bit long-winded, but their vibe is really something else. And some of the ideas were incomplete too, but I'm gonna see how they fit in terms of making it an album.

The key tracks are
- A Sight to Behold
- Sunlight / Content
- Cheddar
- Some Kind of Potatoes
- Meridian

I'm not sure if I like/will keep 'Pug' or 'E', but I kind of just want to leave them because why not ðŸ™‚

The writing for the album started with 'Meridian', then 'A Sight to Behold' right after that. Those were on the same night! I didn't want to open the album with a dark song like 'Meridian' though, it doesn't quite fit the vibe for the rest of the album. But I might change that back around later, not sure. It sure as heck helped inspired a new writing kind for me though, so it's absolutely a keeper track as a whole, just not sure how to package it up.

name: Elkosaurus Tex
description:
Alright, here we are with my seventh album! This one was recently recorded from Spring to Fall 2021. Ready for it? GOOD LUCK! This one is a wild ride, if you can hang on for 1:24 of playtime.
The main goal this time around: How bad can one make an album? Some parts shine through as pretty cool, and I like that.
This is not meant to be good, that's the point! So don't be worried if I think it's good, it's meant to be hilariously bad! I think it's amazing in the sense that it's a meme album.
The later portion of the album inspired my next direction in writing for the album after this, and I can't wait to finish the production for that one so I can show you it too! It has a much different writing purpose than this one does.

Edit Apr 13 2025:

Coming back to this later on, after listening to Larry the Silver Waterfowl (Park & Ride) from Carpincho, I had a realization. I think this counterpart to my writing is inspired heavily by Marco Minnemann's album Schattenspiel. I originally heard about it when we were getting into The Aristocrats, back when I was in middle school. I only had my own YouTube rip of the song "Sandwich" for the longest time. That song seems to be, looking back now, one of the biggest eye-openers for me to this kind of creativity. The way the song structure worked was like nothing I had ever heard before, the way he composed things around the drumset, which is the centerpiece of the song, rather than something like guitar or vocals. I had this song on repeat for the longest time, and I watched the video a lot. It wasn't until 2020 or 2021 that I remembered that I had never actually gotten into the full album. That was just after I had gotten into Marco's solo catalog too, so things were starting to click for me in that regard. Marco's catalog was the music theme of the pandemic for me, hands down. I think reintroducing myself with Schattenspiel at around that time resurfaced my interest in that kind of structure, and my realization that I had never tried that out before, even though I had loved it so much when I first found it. I think this album, and the style I ended up making out of it, I'd like to think could be a nod back to that. It did morph with my own style though, with the concept of making a "bad" album. It's like the song structure from that and the way the song is constructed is what I used to drive the process for this and the other albums early on. I think that video and song was fairly tongue-and-cheek driven to start with, but I feel I also added a little more of that into the mix. I was trying to paint a friendly omage to that, but with the concept of something like Eeps as well, where it intentionally sounded "bad", I think I heard Marco say at some point. So it's like if Eeps was constructed with the way Sandwich was, but also on a very low budget, aka just with GarageBand synth samples. That in and of itself is part of the joke for me too though, at least for Elkosaurus. Part of the initial joke that didn't get fully fleshed out (sadly) would also have been if I exported this album as full lossless, my thought for that being funny would be because the nerve of making the worst album ever, but then also having it be very high quality, now that's freaking hilarious. I think I still have that in the back of my mind actually, now that I'm more focused on lossless, mixing, and mastering, I definitely want to try making another horrible album sometime. Balls to the wall, yet high quality haha. Maybe it could be explicitly a double-album too. An unrelated realization right now too actually, Elkosaurus is meant to be light-hearted. Some of my work is a bit of a downer, at least sometimes it comes from a place of what might be despair, stress, or sadness. The pandemic likely was a driving factor in that regard, but Elkosaurus is meant to be humorous, not sickly self-indulgent, or self-harmful. Ah, that's the word, masochistic. I didn't want to be that. If I included something like Infinitrack, it would have raised the bar on that metric. Hence, that's why it wasn't included. This album still has it's lower parts, like around Hazy Light and Wobble Fog, but it doesn't get dark really.

I think the biggest struggle with making another ridiculous album, is it will be challenging not to make it intense. Say for example the parts on HARRY and Carpincho, it gets a bit dark and masochistic, not as light-hearted as Elkosaurus. I think maybe that's part of what I was bummed about with Carpincho, now that I think about it. But for HARRY, I was in some regard, embracing it/allowing it to flow. I wasn't trying to inflate it intentionally though, which Devin mentioned he did for SYL Alien. I was fine if it went there at times, but I didn't want it to get too crazy, and destroy itself (talking about HARRY). HARRY is probably the closest thing to Elkosaurus since the original, with a few other having some aspects borrowed too. Carpincho was like Elkosaurus unhinged. If anything, Carpincho is so short because I couldn't handle the extent it was getting to, so it had to be shorter. I just ran out of writing fuel to continue at that level of energy. It also would just not be fun to listen to if it kept going. It's like you feel sick or something. Now I can look back at it and stay separate from it, and I admire the honesty in what it conveys. It is very strong though. I do want to explore something like that again, it comes from a very specific place though, and you can't force it. That's the biggest thing I've been learning and have been making note of. What I write currently is what I write currently. I can't influence the style it is, I can only curate it to reflect it better to represent myself. That's okay. The time will come when the types of albums I want to make, can be made. It just involves a set of circumstances that will lead to that happening.

Love you!

Edit again today:

HARRY is also a bit more honest with how I was feeling at the time, mixed with that creative funness too. Maybe that's why I am really fond hearing it after the fact. It's very open, yet also light-hearted in that it doesn't worry about itself being open. Elkosaurus kind of lacks a vulnerability. It kind of is a very surface-level thing. It's great in what it is, but it has less for you to grab onto I feel. It does have it's honest parts though, I think nearing the end of the album it get's more open about feelings, almost like an inverse to HARRY, interestingly enough. I wonder if Elkosaurus is the beginning of an era, and HARRY is the end. I feel like Snake Oil is really the conclusion though, now that I'm seeing how things like that are. It depends on what aspect one looks at. It's a positive lookback though, none of these projects could have happened without the one before it. I wouldn't have them any other way â¤ï¸

Edit 3 lol:

Listening to Carpincho, it was almost like a joke about myself at the time. I felt lost in my writing, be it life things, having been burnt out from writing a lot, or wanting to try something new but not having many other tools to use in that regard. So it's like I started to get self-conscious about my silly writing, because I was sad that "that's all I had" in my toolset. Once again, I really love Carpincho now, it's very strong in what it is and where it came from. Very transparent. It is just an analysis where it comes from internally though. Elkosaurus was interested in making that aesthetic intentionally, while Carpincho was like that because it was frustrated that it was the only thing I knew how to do. So it was more of a criticism of it itself. It was also with HARRY where I had been okay again with that style, and the style itself was interesting again in a light-hearted way. It was almost like a turning point of no longer being insecure about it, and embracing it in that regard. It wasn't the specific intent to be balls-to-the-wall for HARRY though, it was more about overcoming that insecurity itself, and allowing it to be all there too. Sometime in the future, I want to use my own self-confidence to make that bold statement, probably a heavy album, as well as a silly album. I'm not sure yet whether this will be the same project or not. Ideally it would be both, but I feel like having it combined could be new to me as well. I want to make something like Elkosaurus but also like "Maggot Twat", "clowncore", and "Time of Orchids - Melonwhisper".

name: Raise to Conflict
description:
One could call this my sixth album, recorded back in mid 2019! This was a project Justin and I started working on together, which just ended up being this song. I think it turned out great, so I thought I'd make it into its own album also.

Edit Sep. 9, 2025:

Going back through some files, organizing things into better archived folders. Had a thought that I might not have encoded the original file as nicely as it could have been. There is only merely a 320k MP3 file of this song which exists. I had converted it to M4A back when adding it to my library. Looking back now, my not too deep knowledge of audio formats means I probably took the MP3, reencoded it to AAC for my own use (M4A), then simply to upload to Bandcamp, just converted that to a WAV. Not necessary to have done that. Since there is only a source MP3 to my knowledge, today I reencoded that directly to a WAV file, omitting the extra compression step which had likely removed data making the lack of lossless even more apparent. Albeit probably not very noticeable, at least now the quality is partially better here. I now see that the recording itself isn't constructed fully enough to where it would "matter" too much, it really was just a fun demo, glad we recorded it. Still, even then, all the bytes we can muster, why not? :D

name: Distant Utopia
description: My fifth album, written back in late 2018! I felt like this project was a sequel/spin off of the last story, but in new waters (pun not intended). This has a dark and mysterious vibe of a successful utopia, which hides a greater evil underneath. This "take place under water", I guess, haha. I was going to continue this story, but I didn't do anything else with it since 2018. It was just on my computer until late 2021, when I decided to make it into its own album.

name: Spectrum
description: My fourth album, also released back in mid 2017! I wanted to extend my ideas from Septem Numero onwards, going to a new section of the story. This is a less-sad, yet still mysterious outlook from the last section. This is the last part of that story.

name: Septem Numero
description: My third album, released back in mid 2017! I started taking a new approach with this one. It's a space-themed kind of sound, and it's fairly mysterious...

name: LIVE @ MEDINA BLOCK
description:
Teenage Supremacy was a band a few of us from school were in together. We only played one live show, and there's not much to document it's existence, other than a few hard to find social media pages. I thought I'd bring this to light with a remaster from the video of the show, to hopefully make the audio a little easier to listen to. This is the only audio we have from our sessions for the most part, so there's only so much one can do to make the audio sound a little tidier. I tried my best with my limited knowledge in mastering, hope you enjoy!

- Brandon

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R_n7dfBztDw

name: Ultimate Chaos
description: My second album / single, also from back in 2016! This one was more of a standalone song, as I didn't have any other projects in the works at the time. I had just finished up "Made in merica", so it couldn't really release with that. One of my favorites for sure!

name: Made in merica
description: My first album, from back in 2016! I started out using GarageBand's sample loops, and just messed around with them until something interesting happened.
